Having eight plane surfaces; thus, in the shape or form of an octahedron .

octahedrite.explanation: Titanium dioxid, crystallizing in the tetragonal system, the fundamental and commonly occurring form being an acute square octahedron (whence the name); anatase.

A meteoric iron with octahedral structure, which is usually distinctly marked by the lamellæ of kamacite, tænite, and plessite, seen in the Widmannstättian figures. Most iron meteorites fall in this class. See meteorite .
Titanium dioxide occurring in acute octahedral crystals.

octahedroid.explanation: In mathematics , a four-dimensional body bounded by 8 cubes.

octahedron.explanation: A solid bounded by eight faces.
A solid bounded by eight faces. The regular octahedron is contained by eight equal equilateral triangles.
a polyhedron with eight faces ; the regular octahedron has regular triangles as faces and is one of the Platonic solids .
any polyhedron having eight plane faces

octahydrate.explanation: A hydrate whose solid contains eight molecules of water of crystallization per molecule, or per unit cell

octamerism.explanation: The state of having parts or organs in series of eight: used specifically in zoölogy and botany.

octamerous.explanation: zoology and botany , having the parts in series of eight. Often written 8- merous. Also octomerous .
Having parts in groups of eight

octameter.explanation: Verse written in lines of eight metrical feet.
A single line of such verse.
prosody , consisting of eight measures (monopodies or dipodies).
In prosody , a verse or period consisting of eight measures. This word is little used, except in the sense of ‘octapody’ by some writers on modern versification who confound measure with foot.

A verse containing eight feet; as, --

Deep" in|to" the | dark"ness | peer"ing, | long" I | stood" there | wond'"ring, | fear"ing.
A molecule composed of eight monomer units bound to each other, usually in a linear array.
A line of verse containing eight metrical feet
a verse line having eight metrical feet

octandria.explanation: A Linnæan class of plants, in which the flowers have eight stamens not united to one another or to the pistil.

octandrian.explanation: Of or pertaining to the Octandria; having eight distinct stamens.

octane.explanation: Any of various isomeric alkanes with the formula C 8 H 18 , found in petroleum and used as a fuel and solvent.

An oily hydrocarbon, C 8 H 18 , of the paraffin series. It occurs in petroleum, and is one of the chief constituents of ligroin. It boils at 124° C. The name is sometimes given to diisobutyl (C 8 H 18 ).

Any one of a group of metametric hydrocarbons (C8H18) of the methane (paraffin) series. The most important is a colorless, volatile, inflammable liquid, found in petroleum, and a constituent of gasoline or ligroin.
Any of the eighteen isomeric aliphatic hydrocarbons (C8H18) found in petroleum , especially an iso-octane 2,2,4 trimethyl-pentane; they are used as fuels and solvents .
any isomeric saturated hydrocarbon found in petroleum and used as a fuel and solvent

octangle.explanation: A plane figure with eight angles, and therefore with eight sides; an octagon.
A geometric figure with eight corners , an octagon .

octangular.explanation: of or relating to or shaped like an octagon

octangularness.explanation: The property of being octangular, or of having eight angles.

octanol.explanation: Octyl alcohol, C 8 H 17 .OH, derived from octane. It is a liquid which boils at 195.5° C. The acetate occurs in the oil of Heracleum Sphondylium , and the butyrate in the oils of H. giganteum and Pastinaca sativa.
Any of many isomers of the saturated aliphatic alcohol having eight carbon atoms, but especially the simple primary alcohol n-octanol; its esters are used in perfumery

octant.explanation: The area enclosed by two radii at a 45° angle and the intersected arc.
An instrument based on the principle of the sextant but employing only a 45° angle, used as an aid in navigation.
The position of a celestial body when it is separated from another by a 45° angle.
One of eight parts into which three-dimensional space is divided by three usually perpendicular coordinate planes.
Each of the eight regions into which space is divided by three copunctal non-costraight planes.
The eighth part of a circle.

In astronomy , that position or aspect of two heavenly bodies, especially a planet and the sun, when half-way between conjunction or opposition and quadrature, or distant from one another by the eighth part of a circle, or 45°.

An instrument used by seamen for measuring angles, resembling a sextant or quadrant in principle, but having an arc the eighth part of a circle, or 45°. By double reflection it can measure an arc of 90°. See sextant . Hadley's quadrant is really an octant.
The eighth part of a circle; an arc of 45 degrees.
The position or aspect of a heavenly body, as the moon or a planet, when half way between conjunction, or opposition, and quadrature, or distant from another body 45 degrees.
An instrument for measuring angles (generally called a quadrant ), having an arc which measures up to 9O°, but being itself the eighth part of a circle. Cf. Sextant .
One of the eight parts into which a space is divided by three coördinate planes.
The eighth part of a circle ; an arc of 45 degrees.
: The eighth part of a disc ; a sector of 45 degrees; half a quadrant .
: An instrument for measuring angles , particularly of elevation .
a measuring instrument for measuring angles to a celestial body; similar to a sextant but with 45 degree calibration

octapeptide.explanation: A polypeptide, such as angiotensin, that is composed of eight amino acids.
An oligopeptide having eight amino acids .

octapla.explanation: A polyglot book (especially a Bible) in eight parallel columns. The name is especially given to Origen's Hexapla with the addition of a fifth and a sixth version.

octapodic.explanation: prosody , consisting of or containing eight feet; being or constituting an octapody.

octapody.explanation: In prosody , a meter, period, or verse consisting of eight feet. An octapody exceeds the limits of a colon, and is generally written as two lines. See heptapody .

octarch.explanation: botany , having eight centripetally developed xylem plates: said of some radial vascular cylinders.

octarchy.explanation: Government by eight persons, or a region inhabited by eight affiliated communities each having its own chief or government.
A government consisting of eight people

octasemic.explanation: ancient prosody , containing or amounting to eight semeia (moræ) or units of time; having a magnitude of eight normal shorts: as, the orthius has an octasemic thesis; the dochmius and greater spondee are octasemic feet.

octastich.explanation: A strophe, stanza, or poem consisting of eight verses or lines.

octastrophic.explanation: prosody , consisting of or containing eight strophes or stanzas: as, an octastrophic poem.

octastyle.explanation: Having eight frontal columns in the portico, as in some Greek temples.
architecture , having, or characterized by the presence of, eight columns, as a portico or a building having eight columns in front.
A building having eight columns in front; especially, a Greek or Roman temple having that number of columns in the front row of the portico.
Having eight columns in the front row (of a portico etc.)

octateuch.explanation: A collection of eight books; specifically, the first eight books of the Old Testament considered as forming one volume or series of books. Also Octoteuch .
A collection of eight books; especially, the first eight books of the Old Testament.
A collection of eight books ; especially, the first eight books of the Old Testament .

octaval.explanation: Of, pertaining to, or relating to an octave .
Octonary ; expressed in base-8; octal , octonal.

octavalent.explanation: Having a valence of eight; capable of being combined with, exchanged for, or compared with, eight atoms of hydrogen; -- said of certain atoms or radicals.

octavarium.explanation: In the Roman Catholic Church , a modern office-book containing lections, etc., for use within the octaves of festivals.

octave.explanation: The interval of eight diatonic degrees between two tones of the same name, the higher of which has twice as many vibrations per second as the lower.
A tone that is eight diatonic degrees above or below another given tone.
Two tones eight diatonic degrees apart that are sounded together.
The consonance that results when two tones eight diatonic degrees apart are sounded.
A series of tones included within this interval or the keys of an instrument that produce such a series.
An organ stop that produces tones an octave above those usually produced by the keys played.
The interval between any two frequencies having a ratio of 2 to 1.
The eighth day after a feast day, counting the feast day as one.
The entire period between a feast day and the eighth day following it.
A group or series of eight.
A group of eight lines of poetry, especially the first eight lines of a Petrarchan sonnet.
A poem or stanza containing eight lines.
A rotating parry in fencing.
pianoforte- and harpsichordmaking , to reinforce the tone of a digital by adding a string tuned an octave above the usual tone of the digital.
In fencing , the eighth guard: point low, hand moving to the right.
music , noting a tone, note, instrument, organ-stop, etc., whose pitch is an octave above the ordinary pitch or any pitch taken for reference: as, the piccolo is an octave flute.

The eighth day from a festival, the feast-day itself being counted as the first: as, Low Sunday is the octave of Easter. The octave necessarily falls on the same day of the week as the feast from which it is counted.

The prolongation of a festival till the eighth day inclusive; a period consisting of a feastday and the seven days following: as, St. John the Evangelist's day (December 27th) is within the octave of Christmas. See outas .
In music : A tone on the eighth diatonic degree above or below a given tone; the next higher or lower replicate of a given tone.
The interval between any tone and a tone on the eighth degree above or below it.
The harmonic combination of two tones at the interval thus described.

In a scale, the eighth tone from the bottom, or, more exactly, the tone with which the repetition of the scale begins; the upper key-note or tonic; the eighth: solmizated do , like the lower key-note.

In a standard system of tones selected for artistic use, a division or section or group of tones an octave long, the limits of which are fixed by reference to a given or assumed standard tone whose exact pitch may be defined.

In organ-building, a stop whose pipes give tones an octave above the normal pitch of the digitals used; specifically, such a stop of the diapason variety. Also known as the principal. Also called octave-flute, octavestop.
Any interval resembling the musical octave in having the vibration-ratio of 1:2.
Specifically, in versification : A stanza of eight lines; especially, the ottava rima (which see).
The first two quatrains or eight lines in a sonnet. See sonnet .
A small cask of wine containing the eighth part of a pipe.
Consisting of eight; eight.
The eighth day after a church festival, the festival day being included; also, the week following a church festival.
The eighth tone in the scale; the interval between one and eight of the scale, or any interval of equal length; an interval of five tones and two semitones.
The whole diatonic scale itself.
The first two stanzas of a sonnet, consisting of four verses each; a stanza of eight lines.
See under Double .
a small flute, the tones of which range an octave higher than those of the German or ordinary flute; -- called also piccolo . See Piccolo .
A small cask of wine, the eighth part of a pipe.
An interval of twelve semitones spanning eight degrees of the diatonic scale , representing a doubling or halving in pitch.
The pitch an octave higher than a given pitch.
A poetic stanza consisting of eight lines; usually used as one part of a sonnet .
The eighth defensive position, with the sword hand held at waist height, and the tip of the sword out straight at knee level.
The day that is one week after a feast day in the Latin Rite of the Catholic Church .
An eight day period beginning on a feast day in the Latin Rite of the Catholic Church .
Consisting of eight ; eight in number.
a feast day and the seven days following it

octavina.explanation: A spinet tuned an octave higher than the usual form.

octavo.explanation: The page size, from 5 by 8 inches to 6 by 9.5 inches, of a book composed of printer's sheets folded into eight leaves.
A book composed of octavo pages.
A sheet of paper evenly folded to make eight leaves and sixteen pages.
A form of type containing eight pages.
A book or pamphlet every section or gathering of which contains eight leaves, each leaf supposed to be one eighth of the sheet printed: usually written 8 vo.
A book composed of sheets each of which is folded into eight leaves; hence, indicating more or less definitely a size of book so made; -- usually written 8vo or 8°.
Having eight leaves to a sheet

A sheet of paper 7 to 10 inches high and 4.5 to 6 inches wide, the size varying with the large original sheet used to create it. Made by folding the original sheet three times to produce eight leaves.
the size of a book whose pages are made by folding a sheet of paper three times to form eight leaves

octene.explanation: An unsaturated oily hydrocarbon, C 8 H 16 , of the ethylene series. It boils at 125° C. Also called octylene and caprylene.
Any of many isomeric alkenes having eight carbon atoms and one double bond ; some of them are used in the manufacture of polymers

octennial.explanation: Happening every eighth year; also, lasting a period of eight years.

octet.explanation: A composition for eight voices or eight instruments.
A group of eight singers or eight instrumentalists.
A set of eight valence electrons in an atom or ion, forming a stable configuration.
In music , a composition for eight voices or instruments, or a company of eight singers or players. Sometimes, but not usually, equivalent to a double quartet. Also ottetto, octuor, octiphonium.
A composition for eight parts, usually for eight solo instruments or voices.
A group of eight singers or eight musicians.
A group or set of eight of something.
A group of eight musicians performing together.
A composition for such a group of musicians.
A byte of eight bits . Abbreviation: o
A group of three bits , representing eight possible values.
eight people considered as a unit
a set of eight similar things considered as a unit
the cardinal number that is the sum of seven and one
a musical composition written for eight performers
eight performers or singers who perform together

octette.explanation: a set of eight similar things considered as a unit
eight people considered as a unit
eight performers or singers who perform together
a musical composition written for eight performers

octic.explanation: mathematics , of the eighth degree or order.
An algebraic function or form of the eighth degree; a quantic of the eighth degree.
Of the eighth degree or order.
Of the eighth degree or order.
A quantic of the eighth degree.

octile.explanation: In statistics , a group containing one eighth of the total number of observations or of observed objects arranged upon a curve of frequency: usually marked off, as upper and lower octiles , to right and left of the abscissal points which bound the upper and lower quartiles.
Any of the quantiles which divide an ordered sample population into eight equally numerous subsets.

octillion.explanation: The cardinal number that is equal to 10 27 .
The cardinal number that is equal to 10 48 .
In Great Britain, the number produced by involving a million to the eighth power.
In French and United States usage, one thousand raised to the ninth power.

According to the French method of numeration (which method is followed also in the United States) the number expressed by a unit with twenty-seven ciphers annexed. According to the English method, the number expressed by a unit with forty-eight ciphers annexed. See numeration .
A thousand trillion trillion , a billion billion billion : 1 followed by 27 zeros, 1027.
A quadrillion quintillion : 1 followed by 48 zeros, 1048.
the number that is represented as a one followed by 27 zeros

octillionth.explanation: The ordinal number that matches the number octillion in a series.
One of an octillion equal parts.
The quotient of unity divided by an octillion.
The ordinal form of the number octillion .
The person or thing in the octillionth position.
One of a octillion equal parts of a whole.

octine.explanation: An oily hydrocarbon, C 8 H 14 , of the acetylene series. Two varieties, 1 - octine and 2- octine , are known; they boil at 131–132° C. and 133–134° C. respectively. Also called caprylidene .

octoate.explanation: A salt of an octoic acid; a caprylate.

octobass.explanation: A very large double bass requiring two musicians , one to finger and one to bow

octocentenary.explanation: The eight-hundredth anniversary of an event.

octocoralla.explanation: Coralligena , including the octomerous Actinozoa , or that group in which are developed eight chambers of the enterocœle and eight tentacles, the latter being comparatively broad, flattened, and serrate or even pinnatifid: opposed to Hexacoralla. See cut under Coralligena .

octocorallan.explanation: One of the Octocoralla ; an octomerous coral.

octocoralline.explanation: A member of the Octocoralla ; an octocorallan.

octodecimal.explanation: crystallography , having eight faces on the middle part and five on each of the two ends.

octodecimo.explanation: The page size, 4 by 6.5 inches, of a book composed of printer's sheets folded into 18 leaves or 36 pages.
A book composed of octodecimo pages.
Having eighteen leaves to a sheet

A book composed of sheets each of which is folded into eighteen leaves; hence; indicating more or less definitely a size of book, whose sheets are so folded; -- usually written 18mo or 18°, and called eighteenmo .
A size of a sheet of paper resulting from folding and cutting a sheet of paper into eighteenths (3.5"-4.5" x 4.9"-5.9").
A book consisting of pages of that size.

octodianome.explanation: A surface of the fourth degree with eight double points.

octodon.explanation: The typical genus of Octodontidæ , founded by Bennett in 1832. It contains several species of South American rodents with the superficial aspect of rats, such as O. cumingi. See cut under degu .
[ lowercase ] A species of this genus; an octodont.
In entomology , a genus of coleopterous insects.

octodont.explanation: A member of the genus Octodon or the family Octodontidæ ; an octodon.
Of or pertaining to the Octodontidæ , a family of rodents which includes the coypu, and many other South American species.
Any of the Octodontidae, a family of rodents including the coypu and many other South American species .

octofid.explanation: botany , cleft or separated into eight segments, as a calyx.
Cleft or separated into eight segments, as a calyx.
Cleft or separated into eight segments .

octofoil.explanation: In heraldry , a figure having eight lobes or eight subdivisions, like separate leaflets. It is used as the mark of cadency for the ninth son.

octogamy.explanation: The act or fact of marrying eight times.

octogenarian.explanation: Being between 80 and 90 years of age.
A person between 80 and 90 years of age.
A person eighty or eighty-odd years of age.
A person eighty years, or more, of age.
One who is between the age of eighty and eighty-nine , inclusive.
Being between the age of 80 and 89, inclusive.
Of or relating to an octogenarian.
someone whose age is in the eighties

octogenarianism.explanation: The state of being an octogenarian; the characteristics of an octogenarian.

octogild.explanation: A pecuniary compensation for an injury, of eight times the value of the thing.

octoglot.explanation: A book or manuscript written in eight tongues.

octogynia.explanation: botany , in the Linnean system, those orders of plants which have eight pistils.
A Linnaean order of plants having eight pistils.

octogynous.explanation: botany , having eight pistils. Also octagynous .

octoic.explanation: Pertaining to, derived from, or resembling, octane; -- used specifically, to designate any one of a group of acids, the most important of which is called caprylic acid .
Pertaining to, derived from, or resembling octane ; used specifically to designate any of a group of acids including caprylic acid .

octolocular.explanation: botany , having eight cells, as certain capsules.
Having eight cells or compartments, as for seeds .

octonarius.explanation: In Lat. pros. , a verse consisting of eight feet, especially an iambic or trochaic octapody (tetrameter).

octonary.explanation: Of or relating to the number eight.
Consisting of eight members or of groups containing eight.
A group or set of eight.
Of or pertaining to the number eight.
the cardinal number that is the sum of seven and one

octonion.explanation: A nonassociative extension of a quaternion .

octopede.explanation: An animal having eight feet, as a spider.

octopetalous.explanation: Having eight petals or flower leaves.

octoploid.explanation: Having eight haploid sets of chromosomes in a body cell.
having eight complete sets of chromosomes in a single cell
a cell or organism that has eight complete sets of chromosomes

octopod.explanation: Any of various cephalopod mollusks of the order Octopoda, which includes the octopuses, having eight sucker-bearing arms.
Mollusca , eight-footed or eight-armed, as an octopus; pertaining to the Octopoda , or having their characters; octocerous.
An octopus, or octopod cephalopod; any member of the Octopoda.
Any animal with eight feet or foot-like parts.
Any cephalopod mollusks of the order Octopoda.
a cephalopod with eight arms but lacking an internal shell

octopus.explanation: Any of various carnivorous marine cephalopod mollusks chiefly of the family Octopodidae, having a soft body, eight arms with suckers, a large distinct head, and a mouth with a strong beak.
Something, such as a multinational corporation, that has many powerful, centrally controlled branches.
The typical genus of Octopodidæ and Octopoda.
[ lowercase ; pl. octopi (-pī).] A species or an individual of the genus Octopus ; an octopod; a poulpe; a devilfish. See also cut under cuttlefish .
Hence Figuratively, any centralized organization which has many branches and secret connections, and thereby maintains an oppressive hold upon the public.
A genus of eight-armed cephalopods, including numerous species, some of them of large size. See devilfish .
Any member of the genus Octopus.
Something resembling an octopus in having numerous controlling arms or branches that reach widely and influence many activities; -- used mostly of organizations, such as diversified corporations.

Any of several marine molluscs / mollusks , of the family Octopodidae, having no internal or external protective shell or bone (unlike the nautilus , squid or cuttlefish ) and eight arms each covered with suckers .
The flesh of these marine molluscs eaten as food.
An organization that has many powerful branches controlled from the centre.
tentacles of octopus prepared as food
bottom-living cephalopod having a soft oval body with eight long tentacles

octoroon.explanation: A person having white ancestors except for one black great-grandparent. Used especially as a classification under certain European colonial legal systems and now considered offensive.
The offspring of a quadroon and a white person; a person having one eighth negro blood.
The offspring of a quadroon and a white person; a mestee.
an offspring of a quadroon and a white parent; a person who is one-eighth black

octose.explanation: A synthetic sugar, C 8 H 16 O 8 , containing eight carbon atoms in the molecule.
A sugar or saccharide containing eight carbon atoms .

octospore.explanation: A name employed by Janczewski for one of the eight carpospores produced by certain florideous algæ of the family Porphyraceæ.

octosporous.explanation: botany , eight-spored; containing eight spores, as the asci of many fungi and lichens. See ascus .

octostichous.explanation: botany , eight-ranked: a term employed in phyllotaxy to indicate those plants in which the leaves are arranged on the stem in eight vertical ranks, as in the holly and aconite, and the radical leaves of Plantago.
In eight vertical ranks, as leaves on a stem.
In eight vertical ranks , as leaves on a stem .

octosyllabic.explanation: In prosody , a line consisting of eight syllables.
Consisting of or containing eight syllables.
having or characterized by or consisting of eight syllables

octosyllable.explanation: A line of verse containing eight syllables.
A poem having eight syllables in each line.
line of verse with eight syllables
a verse line having eight syllables or a poem of octosyllabic lines

octothorp.explanation: A typographic symbol (#) having two vertical lines intersected by two horizontal lines. It is also called the crosshatch , hash , numeral sign and number sign ; in the U. S. it is commonly called the pound sign , especially to designate the symbol as used on digital telephone dials, but this can be confusing to Europeans who think of the pound sign as the symbol for the British pound. It is commonly used as a symbol for the word number.

octothorpe.explanation: The hash or square symbol ( # ), used mainly in telephony and computing

octoyl.explanation: A hypothetical radical (C7H15.CO.), regarded as the essential residue of octoic acid.
A hypothetical radical , C8H15O, regarded as the essential residue of octoic acid.

octroi.explanation: A concession, grant, or privilege, particularly a commercial privilege, as an exclusive right of trade, conceded by government to a particular person or company.
A tax or duty levied at the gates of cities, particularly in France and certain other countries of the European continent, on articles brought in.
The barrier or place where such duties are levied and paid; also, the service by which they are collected.
A privilege granted by the sovereign authority, as the exclusive right of trade granted to a guild or society; a concession.
A tax levied in money or kind at the gate of a French city on articles brought within the walls.
A privilege granted by the sovereign authority , such as the exclusive right of trade granted to a guild or society ; a concession .
A tax levied in money or kind at the gate of a French city on articles brought within the walls.
a tax on various goods brought into a town

octuple.explanation: Consisting of eight parts or members.
Eight times as much in size, strength, number, or amount.
To multiply or be multiplied by eight.

octuplet.explanation: One of eight offspring delivered at a single birth.
A group or combination of eight associated by common properties or behavior.
In music , a group of eight notes intended to take the place of six. Also ottamole .
one of a group of eight babies born from the same mother during the same birth.

octuplex.explanation: In telegraphy , an eightfold system; a system permitting of the simultaneous transmission of eight messages over one wire.
telegraphy , to adjust or arrange (a telegraphic system) for the simultaneous sending of eight messages.

octuplicate.explanation: A set of eight like or identical things.

octyl.explanation: Relating to or being a hydrocarbon unit, C 8 H 17 , that can occur as a substituent in an organic compound or as an ion or radical.
A hypothetical alcohol radical (C 8 H 17 ), the bestknown compound of which is octyl hydrid (C 8 H 18 ), one of the constituents of American petroleum. Also called capryl .
A hypothetical hydrocarbon radical regarded as an essential residue of octane, and as entering into its derivatives.
Any of very many isomeric univalent hydrocarbon radicals, C8H17, formally derived from octane by the loss of a hydrogen atom

octylene.explanation: A hydrocarbon (C 8 H 16 ) obtained by heating octylic alcohol with sulphuric acid or fused zinc chlorid.
Any one of a series of metameric hydrocarbons (C8H16) of the ethylene series. In general they are combustible, colorless liquids.

octyne.explanation: Any of many isomeric alkynes having eight carbon atoms and one triple bond

ocular.explanation: Of or relating to the eye.
Resembling the eye in form or function.
Of or relating to the sense of sight.
Seen by the eye; visual.
The eyepiece of an optical instrument.
Something which is conveyed to the mind through actual sight.
The eye.
In Echinoidea , an ocular plate.
ocular movements; the ocular (optic) nerve.
ocular proof; ocular demonstration or evidence.
entomology , pertaining to the compound eyes: distinguished from ocellar .
In optics , the eyepiece of an optical instrument, as of a telescope or microscope. See eyepiece .
The eyepiece of an optical instrument, as of a telescope or microscope.
Depending on, or perceived by, the eye; received by actual sight; personally seeing or having seen.
Of or pertaining to the eye; optic.
Of, or relating to the eye , or the sense of sight
Resembling the eye
Seen by the eye; visual
The eyepiece of a microscope or other optical instrument
relating to or using sight
of or relating to or resembling the eye
visible
combination of lenses at the viewing end of optical instruments

ocularly.explanation: By the eye, or by actual sight.
By means of the eye ; visually .

oculary.explanation: Of or pertaining to the eye; ocular; optic.
Of or pertaining to the eye .

oculate.explanation: Having spots or holes resembling eyes; ocellated.
Having spots or holes resembling eyes; ocellated .

oculiferous.explanation: oculiferous tentacles of a snail; the oculiferous ophthalmites of a crustacean. Also oculigerous .

oculiform.explanation: In the form of an eye; resembling an eye.

oculist.explanation: A physician who treats diseases of the eyes; an ophthalmologist.
A physician whose specialty is diseases or defects of the eye; one skilled in treatment of the eyes; an ophthalmologist.
One skilled in treating diseases of the eye.
a person skilled in testing for defects of vision in order to prescribe corrective glasses
a medical doctor specializing in the diagnosis and treatment of diseases of the eye

oculomotor.explanation: Of or relating to movements of the eyeball.
Of or relating to the oculomotor nerve.
Of or pertaining to the movement of the eye; -- applied especially to the common motor nerves (or third pair of cranial nerves) which supply many of the muscles of the orbit.
Of or pertaining to movement of the eyeball
supplies extrinsic muscles of the eye

oculonasal.explanation: Of or pertaining to the region of the eye and the nose.
Pertaining to the eyes and nose .

oculus.explanation: An eyelike opening or ornament, especially.
A circular opening at the apex of a dome.
In architecture , a circular window, usually a small one without tracery or other special subdivision; also an opening at the summit of a dome-shaped vault.
In anatomy , the eye; an eye; specifically, a compound eye.
In botany , an eye; a leaf-bud.
A European plant, Inula Oculus-Christi , having astringent properties.
A round window, usually a small one.
A window or other opening that has an oval or circular shape (as of an eye ).

ocydrome.explanation: A bird of the genus Ocydromus.

ocydromus.explanation: In ornithology , a genus of birds of the family Rallidæ , founded by Wagler in 1830, having the wings too short to fly with.
In entomology , a genus of coleopterous insects.

ocypoda.explanation: The typical genus of Ocypodidæ : so Called from their swiftness of foot.

ocypodan.explanation: A crab of the genus Ocypoda.

ocypode.explanation: A crab of the family Ocypodidæ.

ocypodian.explanation: One of a tribe of crabs which live in holes in the sand along the seashore, and run very rapidly, -- whence the name.
A member of the crab family Ocypodidae .

od.explanation: An alleged force or natural power, supposed, by Reichenbach and others, to produce the phenomena of mesmerism, and to be developed by various agencies, as by magnets, heat, light, chemical or vital action, etc.; — also called odyle or the odylic force.

oda.explanation: A room in an Eastern harem; also the occupants of such a room. See odalisk .

odal.explanation: An East Indian climbing shrub, Sarcostigma Kleinii , bearing bright orange-red drupes.

Among the early and medieval Teutonic peoples, esp. Scandinavians, the heritable land held by the various odalmen constituting a family or kindred of freeborn tribesmen; also, the ownership of such land. The odal was subject only to certain rights of the family or kindred in restricting the freedom of transfer or sale and giving certain rights of redemption in case of change of ownership by inheritance, etc., and perhaps to other rights of the kindred or the tribe. Survivals of the early odal estates and tenure exist in Orkney and Shetland, where it is usually called by the variant form udal .
Noting, or pert. to, odal land or ownership.

odalisk.explanation: A female slave in the harems of the East, especially in that of the Sultan of Turkey.

odalisque.explanation: A woman slave in a harem.
An artistic representation, often highly eroticized, of such a slave.
A female slave or concubine in the harem of the Turkish sultan.
A female slave in a harem , especially one in the Ottoman seraglio .
A desirable or sexually attractive woman.
a woman slave in a harem

odalman.explanation: A man or woman having odal , or able to share in it by inheritance.

odax.explanation: A genus of labroid fishes, representing the subfamily Odacinæ.

odd.explanation: Deviating from what is ordinary, usual, or expected; strange or peculiar: synonym : strange .
Being in excess of the indicated or approximate number, extent, or degree. Often used in combination.
Constituting a remainder.
Small in amount.
Being one of an incomplete pair or set.
Remaining after others have been paired or grouped.
Designating an integer not divisible by two, such as 1, 3, and 5.
Not expected, regular, or planned.
Remote; out-of-the-way.
Something that is numerically odd.
odd glove; two or three odd volumes of a series.
odd way of doing things; an odd appearance.
even.
odd files of a company (that is, the files numbered 1, 3, 5, and so on).
odd one or four odd.
and after a number or quantity, or without and when it takes the place of a unit appended to a ten.
odd trifles; to read a book at odd times.
, etc. (see eccentric ), grotesque, droll, comical.
Not paired with another, or remaining over after a pairing; without a mate; unmatched; single
Not divisible by 2 without a remainder; not capable of being evenly paired, one unit with another.
Left over after a definite round number has been taken or mentioned; indefinitely, but not greatly, exceeding a specified number; extra.
Remaining over; unconnected; detached; fragmentary; hence, occasional; inconsiderable
Different from what is usual or common; unusual; singular; peculiar; unique; strange.
Single ; sole ; singular ; not having a mate.
Singular in excellence; unique ; sole; matchless ; peerless ; famous .
Singular in looks or character; peculiar ; eccentric .
Strange , unusual .
Occasional ; infrequent.
Left over , remaining when the rest have been grouped
Casual , irregular , not planned.

odd.category: not comparable, in combination with a number, not comparable
odd.explanation: About , approximately .
Not divisible by two .
not divisible by two
an indefinite quantity more than that specified
of the remaining member of a pair, of socks e.g.
not used up
not easily explained
beyond or deviating from the usual or expected

oddball.explanation: A person with an unusual or odd personality; an eccentric person.
Exotic , not mainstream , such as an oddball word or an oddball computer program.
a person with an unusual or odd personality

odder.explanation: comparative form of odd : more odd

oddest.explanation: superlative form of odd : most odd .

oddity.explanation: The state or quality of being odd; strangeness.
The quality of being odd; singularity; strangeness; whimsicality.
A peculiarity; a singularity; an odd way.
A singular person or thing; one characterized by oddness.
The quality or state of being odd; singularity; queerness; peculiarity.
something unusual -- perhaps worthy of collecting
eccentricity that is not easily explained

oddly.explanation: In a peculiar manner; strangely; queerly; curiously.
In a manner measured by an odd number.
In a peculiar manner; strangely; queerly; curiously.
In a manner measured by an odd number.
in a manner differing from the usual or expected

oddment.explanation: Something remaining over; a thing not reckoned or included; an article belonging to a broken or incomplete set; a remnant; a trifle; an odd thing or job: usually in the plural.
An odd thing, or one that is left over, disconnected, fragmentary, or the like; something that is separated or disconnected from its fellows
A piece of cloth that is left over after the rest has been used or sold.
Something unusual, and perhaps worthy of collecting.
Odds and ends; a motley assortment of things.
Something left over, such as a piece of cloth; a remnant or offcut .
something unusual -- perhaps worthy of collecting
a piece of cloth that is left over after the rest has been used or sold

oddments.explanation: A collection containing a variety of miscellaneous things.

oddness.explanation: The state of being odd, or not even.
the state or quality of being odd
the result or product of being odd
eccentricity that is not easily explained
the parity of odd numbers (not divisible by two)

odds.explanation: A certain number of points given beforehand to a weaker side in a contest to equalize the chances of all participants.
The ratio of the probability of an event's occurring to the probability of its not occurring.
The likelihood of the occurrence of one thing rather than the occurrence of another thing, as in a contest.
A ratio expressing the amount by which the stake of one bettor differs from that of an opposing bettor.
An amount or degree by which one thing exceeds or falls short of another.
( at odds ) In disagreement; in conflict.
( by all odds ) In every possible way; unquestionably.
betting , the amount or proportion by which the bet of one party to a wager exceeds that of the other: as, to lay or give odds.
You that are so good a Gamester ought to give me Odds.

Difference in favor of one and against another; excess of one of two things or numbers over the other; inequality; advantage; superiority; hence, excess of chances; probability. The odds are often expressed by a ratio
Quarrel; dispute; debate; strife; -- chiefly in the phrase at odds .
in dispute; at variance.
it is probable; same as odds are, but no longer used.
it is probable.
that which is left; remnants; fragments; refuse; scraps; miscellaneous articles.
low odds; poor chances.

The ratio of winnings to stake in betting situations.
the likelihood of a thing occurring rather than not occurring
the ratio by which one better's wager is greater than that of another

ode.explanation: A lyric poem of some length, usually of a serious or meditative nature and having an elevated style and formal stanzaic structure.
A choric song of classical Greece, often accompanied by a dance and performed at a public festival or as part of a drama.
A classical Greek poem modeled on the choric ode and usually having a three-part structure consisting of a strophe, an antistrophe, and an epode.
A lyric poem expressive of exalted or enthusiastic emotion, especially one of complex or irregular metrical form; originally and strictly, such a composition intended to be sung.
The music to which such a poem is set.
In ancient prosody , the fourth part of the parabasis of a comedy. See parabasis . Also called the strophe.
In the Gr. Ch. : One of nine canticles from Scripture, sung whole or in part on different days of the week at lauds (orthros). ; ;
One of a series of songs or hymns, normally nine in number, called the canon of odes (see canon , 13), sung to a musical tone, generally at lauds (orthros).
A short poetical composition proper to be set to music or sung; a lyric poem; esp., now, a poem characterized by sustained noble sentiment and appropriate dignity of style.
one who makes, or who traffics in, odes; -- used contemptuously.
A short poetical composition proper to be set to music or sung; a lyric poem; esp., now, a poem characterized by sustained noble sentiment and appropriate dignity of style.
a lyric poem with complex stanza forms

odelet.explanation: A little ode; a short ode.

odelsthing.explanation: The larger house of the Storthing or parliament of Norway.
The lower house of the Norwegian Storthing. See legislature .

odeon.explanation: A kind of theater in ancient Greece, smaller than the dramatic theater and roofed over, in which poets and musicians submitted their works to the approval of the public, and contended for prizes; -- hence, in modern usage, the name of a hall for musical or dramatic performances.
An ancient Greek or Roman building used for performances of music and poetry .
A modern theatre or concert hall .

odeum.explanation: A small building of ancient Greece and Rome used for public performances of music and poetry.
A contemporary theater or concert hall.
In anc. Gr. arch. , one of a class of buildings akin to theaters, designed primarily for the public performance of musical contests of various kinds.
Hence At the present day, a name sometimes given to a theater, or to a hall or other structure devoted to musical or dramatic representations.

odible.explanation: Fitted to excite hatred; hateful; odious.

odic.explanation: Of or pertaining to od. See Od .
Of or pertaining to od (alleged natural force).

odically.explanation: In terms of the hypothetical force called od .

odiferous.explanation: Having or giving off an odor; odoriferous.

odinism.explanation: The worship of Odin and other deities of Northern mythology; the mythology and religious belief of the ancient Scandinavian and Germanic races before the introduction of Christianity.
Worship of Odin; broadly, the Teutonic heathenism.

The modern name given to the Pre-Christian faith of Northern Europe as practiced by such groups as Angles, Saxons, Jutes, Vikings etc. Also known as Wodenism, Wotanism , Asatru , Heathenism, Norse Paganism and other names.

odinite.explanation: In petrography , an aphanitic porphyry, with few small phenocrysts of labradorite and augite in a ground-mass of feldspar prisms and needles of hornblende.
A monoclinic-domatic mineral containing aluminum , hydrogen , iron , magnesium , manganese , oxygen , silicon , and titanium .

odious.explanation: Arousing or deserving hatred or strong dislike. synonym : hateful .
odious person; an odious sight or smell.
Causing or provoking hatred, repugnance, or disgust; offensive; disagreeable; repulsive
Arousing or meriting strong dislike , aversion , or intense displeasure .

odiously.explanation: in an offensive and hateful manner

odiousness.explanation: The state or quality of being odious; hatefulness; the quality that deserves or may excite hatred, disgust, or repugnance; the state of being hated or loathed: as, the odiousness of sin.

odist.explanation: The writer of an ode or of odes.
A writer of an ode or odes.
A writer of an ode or odes.

odium.explanation: The state or quality of being odious.
A state of disgrace resulting from hateful or detestable conduct.
Censure or blame; reproach; enmity incurred.
Intense hatred or dislike; loathing; abhorrence.
The quality that provokes hatred; offensiveness.
The state of being intensely hated as the result of some despicable action; opprobrium; disrepute; discredit; reproach mingled with contempt.
the enmity peculiar to contending theologians.
Hatred ; dislike ; as, his conduct brought him into odium, or, brought odium upon him.
The quality that provokes hatred ; offensiveness .
state of disgrace resulting from detestable behavior

odling.explanation: Some kind of trickery or swindling. The word is found only in the following passage:

odobenus.explanation: type genus of the Odobenidae: walruses

odograph.explanation: An instrument for recording the distance and course traveled by a vehicle.
A machine for registering the distance traversed by a vehicle or pedestrain.
A device for recording the length and rapidity of stride and the number of steps taken by a walker.

odology.explanation: The so-called science of the hypothetical foree called od . See od .

odometer.explanation: An instrument that indicates distance traveled by a vehicle.
An instrument extensively used for measuring the distance passed over by any wheeled vehicle, and also in topographical surveying in regions traversed by roads.
An instrument attached to a vehicle or connected, as by a flexible cable, to the wheel of a vehicle, which measures the distance traversed.
An instrument attached to the wheel of a vehicle, to measure the distance traversed.
A wheel used by surveyors , which registers distance traversed.
a meter that shows mileage traversed

odometrical.explanation: Of or pertaining to the odometer, or to measurements made with it.
Of or pertaining to the odometer .

odometry.explanation: The measurement by some mechanical contrivance of distances traveled. See odometer .
Measurement of distances by the odometer.
Measurement of distances by the odometer .

odonate.explanation: Any of numerous predatory insects of the order Odonata, which includes the dragonflies and damselflies, characterized by a long, slender, often brightly colored body, two pairs of transparent veined wings, large compound eyes, and an aquatic larval stage.
large primitive predatory aquatic insect having two pairs of membranous wings

odontagra.explanation: Toothache of supposed rheumatic or gouty origin.

odontalgia.explanation: an ache localized in or around a tooth

odontaspididae.explanation: sand sharks; in some classifications coextensive with family Carcharhinidae

odontaspis.explanation: A genus of fossil selachians, typical of the family Odontaspididæ.
type and sole genus of Carchariidae: sand sharks

odontiasis.explanation: the eruption through the gums of baby teeth

odontoblast.explanation: One of the cells forming the outer surface of dental pulp that produces the dentin of a tooth.
A cell by which dentine is developed; a cell which produces dentinal tissue, the special substance which largely composes teeth.
One of the more or less columnar cells on the outer surface of the pulp of a tooth; an odontoplast. They are supposed to be connected with the formation of dentine.
One of the cells which secrete the chitinous teeth of Mollusca.
A cell on the outer surface of dental pulp that produces tooth dentin

odontocete.explanation: A subdivision of Cetacea, including the sperm whale, dolphins, etc.; the toothed whales.
Any member of the cetacean suborder Odontoceti of toothed whales .

odontoclast.explanation: One of the cells which bring about the absorption of the root of a deciduous tooth.

odontogenesis.explanation: The formation and development of teeth

odontogenic.explanation: Of or pertaining to the formation and development of teeth
That originates in the tissues of the teeth

odontogeny.explanation: The origin and development of teeth; the embryology of dentition.
Generation, or mode of development, of the teeth.
The generation , or mode of development , of the teeth .

odontoglossum.explanation: An ornamental genus of orchids of the tribe Vandeæ and the subtribe Oncidieæ , known by the free and spreading sepals, the lip not spurred and free from the long unappendaged column.
Any of vary many orchids of the genus Odontoglossum
any of numerous and diverse orchids of the genus Odontoglossum having racemes of few to many showy usually large flowers in many colors

odontognathous.explanation: conchology , having the jaws surmounted by well-marked transverse ridges: applied to the restricted Helicidæ.
Having toothlike ridges on the jaw

odontograph.explanation: An instrument invented by Willis for laying out the forms of the teeth of geared wheels or rackgears.
A templet or guide used in cutting gears in any form of gear-cutter.
An instrument for marking or laying off the outlines of teeth of gear wheels.
An instrument for marking or laying off the outlines of teeth of gear wheels .

odontographic.explanation: A curve which has been laid out by the use of an odontograph.

odontography.explanation: A scientific description of the teeth .

odontoid.explanation: Of or relating to the odontoid process.
The odontoid process of the axis or second cervical vertebra.
Having the form of a tooth; toothlike.
Of or pertaining to the odontoid bone or to the odontoid process.
a separate bone, in many reptiles, corresponding to the odontoid process.
the anterior process of the centrum of the second vertebra, or axis, in birds and mammals. See Axis .
Resembling a tooth , especially in shape

odontolcae.explanation: An extinct order of ostrichlike aquatic birds having teeth, which are set in a groove in the jaw. It includes Hesperornis, and allied genera. See hesperornis .

odontolite.explanation: A fossil tooth; specifically, a fossil tooth or bone of a bright-blue color, occurring in the Tertiary. Compare bone-turquoise .
A fossil tooth colored a bright blue by phosphate of iron. It is used as an imitation of turquoise, and hence called bone turquoise .
A fossil tooth coloured a bright blue by iron phosphate , used as an imitation turquoise .

odontologist.explanation: A specialist in odontology; one who is versed in the systematic study of the teeth.

odontology.explanation: The study of the structure, development, and abnormalities of the teeth.
The science of dentition; that branch of anatomical science which relates to the teeth. It includes odontography and odontogeny.
The science which treats of the teeth, their structure and development.
The study of the structure and development of teeth
The branch of dentistry dealing with abnormalities of teeth
the branch of medicine dealing with the anatomy and development and diseases of the teeth

odontoloxia.explanation: Irregularity or obliquity of the teeth.

odontoma.explanation: A small tumor composed of dentin, formed in connection with a tooth.

odontonecrosis.explanation: Extensive caries or loss of vitality of the greater part of a tooth.

odontophoral.explanation: Odontophora , or having their characters; odontophoran.

odontophoran.explanation: A member of the Odontophora , as a gastropod, pteropod, or cephalopod.

odontophore.explanation: A structure in most mollusks over which the radula is drawn back and forth during feeding.
The whole radular apparatus, buccal mass, lingual ribbon, or “tongue” of certain mollusks.

A special structure found in the mouth of most mollusks, except bivalves. It consists of several muscles and a cartilage which supports a chitinous radula, or lingual ribbon, armed with teeth. Also applied to the radula alone. See radula .
a projection in the mouths of most molluscs ; it is used, with the radula to break up food

odontophorus.explanation: In ornithology , the typical genus of Odontophorinæ.
genus of Central and South American crested partridges resembling quails; sometimes placed in a distinct subfamily or isolated in a distinct family

odontoplerosis.explanation: The proeess of plugging or filling a tooth-cavity.

odontopteris.explanation: A genus of fossil ferns established by Brongniart (1822), so closely allied to Neuropteris that many species have been differently referred to one or the other of these genera by various authors.

odontopteryx.explanation: A genus of fossil birds from the London clay (Lower Eocene) of England, having tooth-like projections on the mandible and believed to be related to the gannets ( Steganopodes ).
An extinct Eocene bird having the jaws strongly serrated, or dentated, but destitute of true teeth. It was found near London.

odontornithes.explanation: Aves having true teeth implanted in separate sockets or in a continuous groove.
A group of Mesozoic birds having the jaws armed with teeth, as in most other vertebrates. They have been divided into three orders: Odontolcæ, Odontotormæ, and Saururæ.

odontorrhagia.explanation: Profuse bleeding from the socket of an extracted tooth.

odontoscope.explanation: A small mirror, attached at an angle to a long handle, used in the examination of the teeth.

odontostomatous.explanation: Having toothlike mandibles; -- applied to certain insects.

odontotherapia.explanation: The treatment or care of the teeth; dental therapeutics.

odontotherapy.explanation: The medical care of the teeth; dental medicine.

odontotormae.explanation: Aves represented by Ichthyornis and related genera from the Cretaceous of North America.

odophone.explanation: A scale or gamut of scents.

odor.explanation: A quality of something that is perceived by the sense of smell: synonym : smell .
Scent; fragrance; smell, whether pleasant or offensive: when used without a qualifying adjunct, the word usually denotes an agreeable smell.
Figuratively, repute; reputation; esteem: as, to be in bad odor with one's acquaintances.
Synonyms Scent, Perfume , etc. See smell , n.
Any smell, whether fragrant or offensive; scent; perfume.
to be out of favor, or in bad repute.
Any smell , whether fragrant or offensive; scent ; perfume .
any property detected by the olfactory system
the sensation that results when olfactory receptors in the nose are stimulated by particular chemicals in gaseous form

odorant.explanation: Any substance that has a distinctive smell , especially one added to something (such as household gas) for safety purposes

odorate.explanation: A perfume-giving substance; a substance that diffuses odor.

odorator.explanation: An atomizer used for diffusing odoriferous liquid extracts or perfumes.

odored.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of odor .
having an odor , especially having a specified odor

odoriferous.explanation: Having or giving off an odor.
Bearing or yielding an odor; perfumed; usually, sweet of scent; fragrant.

odoriferousness.explanation: The property of being odoriferous; fragrance: sweetness of scent.

odorimeter.explanation: An instrument for measuring and recording the objective intensity of olfactory stimuli: opposed to and correlated with olfactometer.

odorimetry.explanation: The science which is concerned with the objective measurement of olfactory stimuli: correlated with photometry and phonometry .

odorize.explanation: cause to smell or be smelly

odorized.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of odorize .

odorizer.explanation: A device to add odor to a gas.

odorizes.explanation: Third-person singular simple present indicative form of odorize .

odorous.explanation: Having or emitting an odor or scent, esp. a sweet odor; fragrant; sweet-smelling.
having odor or a characteristic odor

odorousness.explanation: The property of being odorous, or of exciting the sensation of smell.

odour.explanation: Any smell , whether fragrant or offensive; scent ; perfume .
Something which produces a scent; incense , a perfume .
any property detected by the olfactory system
the sensation that results when olfactory receptors in the nose are stimulated by particular chemicals in gaseous form

ods.explanation: A corruption of God's; -- formerly used in oaths and ejaculatory phrases.

odum.explanation: Same as iroko . Sometimes written odoom.

odylic.explanation: Of or pertaining to odyle; odic.
Of or pertaining to odyle; odic .

odylism.explanation: The doctrine of odic or odylic force. See od .

odylization.explanation: The supposed process of conveying animal magnetism (odylic force) from one person to another. Also spelled odylisation .

odynerus.explanation: A genus of wasps of the family Vespidæ or the restricted family Eumenidæ ; the burrowing wasps, which dig holes for their nests in walls or in the ground, sometimes to the depth of several inches.

odyssey.explanation: An extended adventurous voyage or trip.

An epic poem, attributed to Homer, in which are celebrated the adventures of Odysseus (Ulysses) during ten years of wandering, spent in repeated endeavors to return to Ithaca, his native island, after the close of the Trojan war.
An epic poem attributed to Homer, which describes the return of Ulysses to Ithaca after the siege of Troy.
a Greek epic poem (attributed to Homer) describing the journey of Odysseus after the fall of Troy
a long wandering and eventful journey

oecoid.explanation: Brücke's name for the colorless stroma of red blood-corpuscles. Also written oikoid and œkoid.
The colorless porous framework, or stroma, of red blood corpuscles from which the zooid, or hemoglobin and other substances of the corpuscles, may be dissolved out.

oeconomus.explanation: A married priest (chiefly Orthodox Christian and Uniate usage), as opposed to a hieromonk .

) A priest or other person who serves as the bursar or finance officer of a diocese or religious institution (chiefly Roman Catholic usage), an episcopal oeconomus temporarily takes charge of church property in the event of an episcopal vacancy.
A Byzantine title given to the chief steward or treasurer of a household or institution.

oecumenic.explanation: concerned with promoting unity among churches or religions

oecumenical.explanation: concerned with promoting unity among churches or religions

oecus.explanation: An apartment, room, or hall in an ancient Roman dwelling house.

oedema.explanation: An excessive accumulation of serum in tissue spaces or a body cavity
A similar swelling in plants caused by excessive accumulation of water
swelling from excessive accumulation of watery fluid in cells, tissues, or serous cavities

oedipal.explanation: Of, relating to, or characteristic of the Oedipus complex.

oedipally.explanation: In a manner related to an Oedipus complex . Adverb form of oedipal .

oedogoniales.explanation: simple or branched filamentous freshwater green algae

oedogonium.explanation: type genus of Oedogoniaceae; freshwater green algae having long unbranched filaments; usually free-floating when mature

oeillade.explanation: A glance , especially an amorous one; an ogle

oelet.explanation: An eye, bud, or shoot, as of a plant; an oilet.

oenanthate.explanation: A salt or ester of oenanthic acid; ; also called enanthate .

oenanthol.explanation: A colorless, limpid, aromatic liquid (C 7 H 14 O) produced in the distillation of castor-oil.
An oily substance (C6H15.CHO) obtained by the distillation of castor oil, recognized as the aldehyde of œnanthylic acid, and hence called also œnanthaldehyde .

oenanthyl.explanation: The hypothetical radical (C 7 H 13 O) of œnanthylic acid and its derivatives.
A hydrocarbon radical formerly supposed to exist in œnanthic acid, now known to be identical with heptyl.

oenanthylic.explanation: Pertaining to, derived from, or containing, œnanthyl; specifically, designating an acid formerly supposed to be identical with the acid in œnanthic ether, but now known to be identical with heptanoic acid.

oenin.explanation: An anthocyanin , the 3- glucoside of malvidin and the red pigment in red wine .

oenocyte.explanation: A large secretory cell found in clusters underlying the epidermis of larval abdominal segments .

oenological.explanation: Of or pertaining to oenology , the study of wine

oenology.explanation: The scientific study of wines and winemaking.

oenomania.explanation: An insatiable desire for wine or other intoxicating liquors; dipsomania.
Same as delirium tremens (which see, under delirium ).

oenomel.explanation: An ancient Greek beverage consisting of wine and honey.
A drink made of wine mixed with honey. Compare mead , metheglin , and hydromel.
A beverage made of wine and honey.

oenometer.explanation: A hydrometer specially adapted for determining the alcoholic strength of wines.

oenophile.explanation: A person who has a fondness for wine . A person who has learned to appreciate wine.

oenothera.explanation: chiefly North American herbs with usually nocturnal flowers

oersted.explanation: The centimeter-gram-second electromagnetic unit of magnetic field strength, equal to the magnetic intensity one centimeter from a unit magnetic pole.
In electricity , the unit of magnetic reluctance.

The C. G. S. unit of magnetic reluctance or resistance, equal to the reluctance of a centimeter cube of air (or vacuum) between parallel faces. Also, a reluctance in which unit magnetomotive force sets up unit flux.
The CGS unit of magnetizing field (symbol Oe ), defined as 1000/4π (≈79.5774715) amperes per meter of flux path .
the magnetic field strength 1 cm from a unit magnetic pole

oes.explanation: Plural form of o ., the name of the letter O.

oesophagitis.explanation: inflammation of the esophagus; often caused by gastroesophageal reflux

oesophagus.explanation: The tube that carries food from the pharynx to the stomach .
the passage between the pharynx and the stomach

oestradiol.explanation: the most powerful female hormone that occurs naturally; synthesized and used to treat estrogen deficiency and breast cancer

oestrian.explanation: Of or pertaining to the gadflies.

oestriol.explanation: a naturally occurring estrogenic hormone; a synthetic form is used to treat estrogen deficiency

oestrogen.explanation: a general term for female steroid sex hormones that are secreted by the ovary and responsible for typical female sexual characteristics

oestrone.explanation: a naturally occurring weak estrogenic hormone secreted by the mammalian ovary; synthesized (trade name Estronol) and used to treat estrogen deficiency

oestrual.explanation: Of or pertaining to sexual desire; -- mostly applied to brute animals

oestruation.explanation: The condition of being œstrual, or the period during which this condition exists; sexual desire or heat; rut.
The state of being under œstrual influence, or of having sexual desire.

oestrus.explanation: The climax or height of the period of sexual desire in female mammals. This is preceded by the procestrum and followed by the metœstrum.
A vehement urging; a stimulus; an incitement.
[ capitalized ] The typical genus of Œstridæ.
A genus of gadflies. The species which deposits its larvæ in the nasal cavities of sheep is œstrus ovis .
The periodical sexual impulse of animals; the period during which female animals are most receptive to males; heat; rut.
A biting fly of the genus Oestrus ; a botfly .
A female animal's readiness to mate ; heat , rut .
applies to nonhuman mammals: a state or period of heightened sexual arousal and activity
type genus of the Oestridae: sheep botflies
applies to nonhuman mammals: a state or period of heightened sexual arousal and activity

oeuvre.explanation: The sum of the lifework of an artist, writer, or composer.
The complete body of an artist's work .
the total output of a writer or artist (or a substantial part of it)

of.explanation: Derived or coming from; originating at or from.
Away from; at a distance from.
So as to be separated or relieved from.
From the total or group comprising.
Set aside for; taken up by.
During or on a specified time.
of, off , in composition. See etymology.
An abbreviation of Order of Friars Minor .
of the island; Switzerland is north of Italy; within an hour of his death; upward of a year.
of his money; to cure one of a fever; to break one of a habit.

offender.explanation: One who offends; one who transgresses or violates a law, whether human or divine; one who infringes rules and regulations; one who acts contrary to the rights of others, or to social rule or custom; one who displeases or annoys; one who gives offense, or incurs the dislike or resentment of another.

Synonyms Offender, Delinquent , culprit. Offender differs from delinquent in that a delinquent is, strictly, a negative transgressor, one who neglects to comply with the requirements of the law, whereas an offender is a positive transgressor, one who violates law or social rule. Both are general words, covering the offenses or delinquencies under divine or human laws, social usages, etc.

In architecture , a horizontal break in a wall or other member, marking a diminution of its thickness. See set-off .
A terrace: as, grounds laid out in offsets.

In printing , a faulty transfer of superabundant or undried ink on a printed sheet to any opposed surface, as the opposite page. Also known as set-off.
10. A branch pipe; also, a more or less abrupt bend in a pipe, made to bring the axis of one part of the pipe out of line with the axis of another part.
To set off; to place over against; to balance.
To form an offset in, as in a wall, rod, pipe, etc.

An abrupt bend in an object, as a rod, by which one part is turned aside out of line, but nearly parallel, with the rest; the part thus bent aside.

A more or less distinct transfer of a printed page or picture to the opposite page, when the pages are pressed together before the ink is dry or when it is poor; an unitended transfer of an image from one page to another; called also setoff .

offspring.explanation: The organism or organisms resulting from sexual or asexual reproduction.
A child or children of a parent or parents.
The result or product of something.

Progeny; descendants, however remote from the stock; issue: a collective term, applied to several or all descendants (sometimes, exceptionally, to collateral branches), or to one child if the sole descendant.

Synonyms Offspring, Issue, Progeny, Posterity, Descendants. Offspring and progeny apply to the young of man or beast; the rest usually only to the human race. Offspring and issue usually imply more than one, but may refer to one only; progeny and posterity refer to more than one, and generally to many: offspring and issue refer generally to the first generation, the rest to as many generations as there may be in the case, posterity and descendants necessarily covering more than one. Issue is almost always a legal or genealogical term, referring to a child or children of one who has died. Posterity implies an indefinite future of descent.
That which is produced; a child or children; a descendant or descendants, however remote from the stock.

ohelo.explanation: The Hawaiian huckleberry, Vaccinium reticulatum , a low shrub found in the high mountains of several islands of the group, covering large open tracts in some places. The shining fleshy berry, though astringent, is not unpleasant to the taste, and makes a good preserve. It is the principal food of the mountain wild goose. It was formerly used as a propitiatory offering to the fire-goddess Pele, and. is still celebrated in the songs of the natives.
A small red or yellow berry growing on the shrub (Vaccinium reticulatum) of volcanic parts of the Hawaiian islands of Hawaii and Maui, or the shrub itself.

Either of two trees of the myrtle family native to Hawaii , the lehua (Metrosideros polymorpha) and the Malay apple (Syzygium malaccense).

ohm.explanation: The SI-derived unit of electrical resistance of a conductor through which a current of one ampere flows when subjected to a one-volt potential across its terminals.
In electricity , the unit of resistance (see resistance ).
An abbreviation of On His (or Her ) Majesty's Service.

The standard unit in the measure of electrical resistance, being the resistance of a circuit in which a potential difference of one volt produces a current of one ampére. As defined by the International Electrical Congress in 1893, and by United States Statute, it is a resistance substantially equal to 109 units of resistance of the C. G. S. system of electro-magnetic units, and is represented by the resistance offered to an unvarying electric current by a column of mercury at the temperature of melting ice 14.4521 grams in mass, of a constant cross-sectional area, and of the length of 106.3 centimeters. As thus defined it is called the international ohm .
the statement of the fact that the strength or intensity of an electrical current is directly proportional to the electro-motive force, and inversely proportional to the resistance of the circuit.

In the International System of Units , the derived unit of electrical resistance ; the electrical resistance of a device across which a potential difference of one volt causes a current of one ampere . Symbol: Ω
a unit of electrical resistance equal to the resistance between two points on a conductor when a potential difference of one volt between them produces a current of one ampere
German physicist who formulated Ohm's law (1787-1854)

ohmage.explanation: Electrical resistance expressed in ohms as the unit.

oil machinery; hence, figuratively, to render oily and bland; make smooth and pleasing.

The general name for a class of bodies which have all or most of the following properties in common: they are neutral bodies having a more or less unctuous feel and viscous consistence, are liquid at ordinary temperatures, are lighter than water, and are insoluble in it, but dissolve in alcohol and more readily in ether, and take fire when heated in air, burning with a luminous smoky flame.

etc. (Old Chem.), a complex oil obtained by the distillation of animal substances, as bones. See Bone oil, under Bone .
See under Drying , and Essential .

See under Fixed .
a bag, cyst, or gland in animals, containing oil.

any beetle of the genus Meloe and allied genera. When disturbed they emit from the joints of the legs a yellowish oily liquor. Some species possess vesicating properties, and are used instead of cantharides.
a fixed box or reservoir, for lubricating a bearing; esp., the box for oil beneath the journal of a railway-car axle.

a pale yellowish green, like oil.

A variety of hone slate, or whetstone, used for whetting tools when lubricated with oil.

Spermaceti, white wax, oil of almonds, and glycerin.

That which serves to anoint; any soft unctuous substance used for smearing or anointing; an unguent.

okapi.explanation: A ruminant mammal (Okapia johnstoni) of the central African rainforest, having a reddish-brown body, whitish-gray cheeks, horizontal whitish stripes on the legs and hindquarters, and short horns in the male. The okapi is closely related to the giraffe.
A member of the giraffe family, discovered by Sir Harry Johnston, in 1902, in the forest region near Lake Albert, Africa.

A peculiar mammal ( Okapia johnstoni ) closely related to the giraffe, discovered in the deep forests of Belgian Congo in 1900. It is smaller than an ox, and somewhat like a giraffe, except that the neck is much shorter. Like the giraffe, it has no dewclaws. There is a small prominence on each frontal bone of the male. The color of the body is chiefly reddish chestnut, the cheeks are yellowish white, and the fore and hind legs above the knees and the haunches are striped with purplish black and cream color.

A large ruminant mammal , Okapia johnstoni, found in the rainforests of the Congo , related to the giraffe , but with a much shorter neck, a reddish brown coat and zebra -like stripes on its hindquarters .
similar to the giraffe but smaller with much shorter neck and stripe on the legs

okay.explanation: being satisfactory or in satisfactory condition
in a satisfactory or adequate manner

okayed.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of okay .

oke.explanation: A Middle English form of oak .

A plant, Hibiscus esculentus , an esteemed vegetable, cultivated in the East and West Indies, the southern United States, etc. See gumbo .

old ; a house a century old.

new continent , consisting of North and South America.

A fat, liquid at ordinary temperatures, but solidifying at temperatures below 0° C., found abundantly in both the animal and vegetable kingdoms (see palmitin ). It dissolves solid fats, especially at 30-40° C. Chemically, olein is a glyceride of oleic acid; and, as three molecules of the acid are united to one molecule of glycerol to form the fat, it is technically known as triolein . It is also called elain .
Any naturally-occurring greasy or oily substance related to fat
a naturally occurring glyceride of oleic acid that is found in fats and oils

olenid.explanation: Any member of the trilobite family Olenidae.

a spread made chiefly from vegetable oils and used as a substitute for butter

Art or process of producing the pictures known as oleographs.
A process of identifying oils by their oleographs.

a spread made chiefly from vegetable oils and used as a substitute for butter

It is so contrived as to allow of a small quantity of a volatile solvent being used to extract the oil, being distilled back upon the material under treatment, and filtered through it a number of times in succession. See Soxhlet's extraction apparatus .
An instrument for ascertaining the weight and purity of oil; an elaiometer.
An instrument for determining the weight and purity of oil .

a naturally occurring mixture of a resin and an essential oil; obtained from certain plants

the faculty that enables us to distinguish scents
