A government run by only a few, often the wealthy .
Those who make up an oligarchic government.
A state ruled by such a government.
a political system governed by a few people

oligemia.explanation: In pathology , that state of the system in which there is a deficiency of blood. Compare anemia .

oligist.explanation: Hematite or specular iron ore; -- prob. so called in allusion to its feeble magnetism, as compared with magnetite.

oligochaeta.explanation: An order of Annelida which includes the earthworms and related species, including some small freshwater species.

oligochaete.explanation: Any of various annelid worms of the class (or subclass) Oligochaeta, including the earthworms and aquatic species found chiefly in freshwater, which lack the appendages typical of polychaetes.
A worm of the order Oligochæta.
Any of an order of hermaphroditic terrestrial and aquatic annelids (including the earthworms) having bristles borne singly along the length of the body; a member of the Oligochaeta.
any of various hermaphroditic aquatic and terrestrial annelid worms , of the class Oligochaeta , that have single bristles along the body
hermaphroditic terrestrial and aquatic annelids having bristles borne singly along the length of the body

oligochaetous.explanation: Of or pertaining to the Oligochæta.

oligochete.explanation: Of or pertaining to the Oligochæta.

oligochrome.explanation: oligochrome decoration of a building or a room.
A design executed in few colors.

oligochromemia.explanation: In pathology , scantiness of hemoglobin in red bloodcorpuscles.

oligochronometer.explanation: An instrument for recording very brief periods of time.

oligocythemia.explanation: In pathology , a condition of the blood in which there is a paucity of red corpuscles.

oligodendroglia.explanation: Neuroglia consisting of cells similar to but smaller than astrocytes, found in the central nervous system and associated with the formation of myelin.
tissue ( neuroglia ) consisting of glial cells that are smaller than astrocytes and form the myelin sheath
tissue consisting of glial cells with sheetlike processes that form the myelin sheath of nerve fibers

oligodendroglioma.explanation: A glioma believed to originate from the oligodendrocytes of the brain or from a glial precursor cell.

oligodynamic.explanation: physical , produced by extremely small forces, or by small quantities of an active substance.
That is active in very small quantities ; used especially to describe the sterilizing effect of some heavy metals against bacteria

oligohydramnios.explanation: A deficit of amniotic fluid in the amniotic sac , causing distinctive deformations of the foetus .

oligomenorrhea.explanation: Infrequent or light menstrual periods in women of child-bearing age.

oligomer.explanation: A polymer consisting of at least 2 and as many as 100 monomers.

A molecule composed of a small number of linked monomer units; a short polymer; -- compounds called oligomers have less than one hundred monomer units and usually less than thirty. Oligomers of increasing length are called dimer , trimer , tetramer , pentamer , hexamer , heptamer , octamer , nonamer , decamer , etc. In colloquial laboratory jargon, they may also be referred to as nine-mer , ten-mer , eleven-mer , twelve-mer , etc., especially for oligomers of greater than eight units.
A compound intermediate between a monomer and a polymer , normally having a specified number of units between about five and a hundred.

oligomeric.explanation: Of, pertaining to, or being an oligomer .

oligomerization.explanation: The formation of an oligomer from a monomer

oligomerous.explanation: Having few members in each set of organs.
Having only a few members in a particular organ

oligometochia.explanation: Sparing use of participles or participial clauses in composition: opposed to polymetochia.

oligomycin.explanation: Any of a group of toxic macrolides , produced by Streptomyces bacteria , that are used as antibiotics

oligomyoid.explanation: ornithology , having few or imperfectly differentiated muscles of the syrinx: applied to a lower series of birds of the order Passeres , such as the Clamatores or Mesomyodi , and synonymous with mesomyodian , but of less exact signification.
Having few or imperfect syringeal muscles; -- said of some passerine birds ( Oligomyodi ).

oligonephria.explanation: Those insects which possess but few urinary or Malpighian tubules. This grouping of insects shows no relation to classification or phylogeny. Distinguished from Polynephria .

oligonite.explanation: A variety of siderite or carbonate of iron, containing 25 per cent. of manganese protoxid, found at Ehrenfriedersdorf in Saxony.

oligonucleotide.explanation: A short polymer of two to twenty nucleotides.
A short sequence of nucleotides (RNA or DNA), typically with twenty or fewer base pairs .

oligophagous.explanation: Feeding on a limited number of foods, usually within one taxonomic family.
that feed on a restricted range of food

oligophagy.explanation: feeding on few specific types of food (e.g. a single plant genus )

oligopolist.explanation: A member of an oligopoly ; one of a small number of sellers with undue influence over a market .

oligopolistic.explanation: Having the character of, or dominated by, an oligopoly

oligopoly.explanation: A market condition in which sellers are so few that the actions of any one of them will materially affect price and have a measurable impact on competitors.
An economic condition in which a small number of sellers exert control over the market of a commodity .
(economics) a market in which control over the supply of a commodity is in the hands of a small number of producers and each one can influence prices and affect competitors

oligoprothesy.explanation: In philology , the habit of using few prepositions.

oligopsony.explanation: A market condition in which purchasers are so few that the actions of any one of them can materially affect price and the costs that competitors must pay.
An economic condition in which a small number of buyers exert control over the market price of a commodity .

oligosaccharide.explanation: A carbohydrate that consists of a relatively small number of monosaccharides.
a polysaccharide of low molecular weight , being a polymer of between three and seven monosaccharide units
any of the carbohydrates that yield only a few monosaccharide molecules on complete hydrolysis

oligosiderite.explanation: A name given by Daubrée to a class of meteoric stones, or aerolites, in which the grains of metallic iron are in relatively small quantity. See meteorite .
A meteorite characterized by the presence of but a small amount of metallic iron.
A meteorite characterised by a small amount of metallic iron .

oligosyllable.explanation: A word of three or fewer syllables: distinguished from polysyllable .

oligosynthetic.explanation: (of a language) using a relatively small number of morphemes which combine synthetically to form compound words. Example languages include aUI, Ygyde, Kali-sise, and Vuyamu.

oligotrichia.explanation: A condition in which the growth of hair is scanty.

oligotrophic.explanation: Lacking in plant nutrients and having a large amount of dissolved oxygen throughout. Used of a pond or lake.

oligotrophic.category: geography, of a body of water
oligotrophic.explanation: being deficient in plant nutrients , such as nitrogen or phosphorus

oligotrophy.explanation: the quality of having a low level of nutrients and minerals

oligotropic.explanation: entomology , visiting but few flowers: applied to bees or other insects.

oliguria.explanation: In pathology , scantiness of urine; diminished secretion of urine.
A decreased production in the volume of urine .
abnormally small production of urine; can be a symptom of kidney disease or obstruction of the urinary tract or edema or an imbalance of fluids and electrolytes in the body
production of an abnormally small amount of urine

olinia.explanation: A genus of plants constituting the family Oliniaceæ.

olio.explanation: A heavily spiced stew of meat, vegetables, and chickpeas.
A mixture or medley; a hodgepodge.
A collection of various artistic or literary works or musical pieces; a miscellany.
Vaudeville or musical entertainment presented between the acts of a burlesque or minstrel show.
A savory dish composed of a great variety of ingredients, as stewed meat, herbs, etc.
A miscellany; a collection of various pieces: chiefly applied to a musical collection.
A dish of stewed meat of different kinds.
A rich, thick, Spanish stew consisting of meat and vegetables.
A mixture or medley, a hotchpotch .
A collection of various musical, theatrical or other artistic works; a miscellany .
By extension of the above, Vaudeville or similar miscellaneous musical or theatrical entertainment skits presented between the main acts of minstrel or burlesque shows.

oliphant.explanation: A hunter's or warrior's horn made of ivory: used in the middle ages, more frequently as a decorative piece of furniture than as a musical instrument.

olitory.explanation: kitchen - or vegetable - in the compounds kitchen-garden, vegetable-garden.
A vegetable or other pot-herb of the kinds commonly grown in kitchen-gardens.
Of or pertaining to, or produced in, a kitchen garden; used for kitchen purposes.
Of or pertaining to a kitchen garden ; used for culinary purposes.

oliva.explanation: In conchology : [ capitalized ] The typical genus of Olividæ , founded by Bruguière in 1789; the olives or olive-shells.
Pl. olivas (-väz). Any species of Oliva ; an olive-shell. See cut at olive-shell.
Pl. olivæ (-vē). In anatomy , the olivary body of the brain.
A genus of polished marine gastropod shells, chiefly tropical, and often beautifully colored.

olivaceous.explanation: zoology and botany , of an olive-green color; olive-green.
Resembling the olive; of the color of the olive; olive-green.
Having the color of a green olive.

olivary.explanation: an oval prominence on each side of the medulla oblongata; -- called also olive .

olivaster.explanation: Of the color of the olive; tawny.
Of the color of the olive ; tawny .

olive.explanation: A widely cultivated evergreen tree (Olea europaea) native to the Mediterranean region, having fragrant white flowers, gray-green lance-shaped leathery leaves, and edible fruit with oil-rich flesh surrounding a hard stone.
The small oval fruit of this tree, usually changing in color from green to black as it ripens, used for food and as a source of oil.
Any of various similar or related plants, such as the Russian olive.
A yellow green of low to medium lightness and low to moderate saturation.
Elæocarpus cyaneus. Compare olive-nut .
Notelæa ovata. See dunga-runga and Notelæa.
The Queensland olive, Olea paniculata. See marblewood , 2.

The oil-tree, Olea Europæa , cultivated from the earliest times in Syria and Palestine, and thence in remote antiquity distributed throughout the whole Mediterranean region: in recent times it has been successfully planted in Australia, southern California, and elsewhere.
The fruit of the common olive-tree, a small ellipsoid drupe (the “berry”), bluish-black in color when fully ripe.
A tree of some other species of Olea , or of some other genus resembling the olive. See Olea , and phrases below.
The color of the unripe olive; a color composed of yellow, black, red, and white in such proportions as to form a low-toned dull green, slightly yellow.
Same as oliva , 1.
A perforated plate in the strap of a satchel or traveling-bag, through which the stud or button passes to fasten it.
A long oval button over which loops of braid are passed as a fastening for cloaks, etc.
In anatomy , the olivary body of the medulla oblongata.
In conchology , an olive-shell.
In ornithology , the oyster-catcher, Hæmatopus ostrilegus.

One of various trees of other genera: in Europe, Elæagnus angustifolia, Rhus Cotinus , and Thymelæa Sanamunda ( Daphne Thymelæa ); in the West Indies, Bontia daphnoides, Ximenia Americana, Terminalia Buceras , and T. capitata; in India, Putranjiva Roxburghii.
Approaching the color of the olive; of a peculiar dark brownish, yellowish, or tawny green.

A tree ( Olea Europæa ) with small oblong or elliptical leaves, axillary clusters of flowers, and oval, one-seeded drupes. The tree has been cultivated for its fruit for thousands of years, and its branches are the emblems of peace. The wood is yellowish brown and beautifully variegated.
The fruit of the olive. It has been much improved by cultivation, and is used for making pickles. Olive oil is pressed from its flesh.
Any shell of the genus Oliva and allied genera; -- so called from the form. See Oliva .
The oyster catcher.
The color of the olive, a peculiar dark brownish, yellowish, or tawny green.
One of the tertiary colors, composed of violet and green mixed in equal strength and proportion.
An olivary body. See under Olivary .
A small slice of meat seasoned, rolled up, and cooked.
a species of Elæagnus ( Elæagnus angustifolia ), the flowers of which are sometimes used in Southern Europe as a remedy for fevers.
A child.
to offer to make peace (with a rival or enemy).
brown with a tinge of green.
a dark brownish green, like the color of the olive.
an oil expressed from the ripe fruit of the olive, and much used as a salad oil, also in medicine and the arts.
olivenite.
a name given to the oleaster or wild stock of the olive; also variously to several trees more or less resembling the olive.
An evergreen tree , Olea europaea, cultivated since ancient times in the Mediterranean for its fruit and the oil obtained from it.
The small oval fruit of this tree, eaten ripe (usually black) or unripe (usually green).
The wood of the olive tree.
A dark yellowish- green color , that of an unripe olive.
An olivary body , part of the medulla oblongata .
A component of a plumbing compression joint; a ring which is placed between the nut and the pipe and compressed during fastening to provide a seal.
Of a grayish green color , that of an unripe olive.
evergreen tree cultivated in the Mediterranean region since antiquity and now elsewhere; has edible shiny black fruits
one-seeded fruit of the European olive tree usually pickled and used as a relish
hard yellow often variegated wood of an olive tree; used in cabinetwork

olived.explanation: Decorated or furnished with olive trees.
Decorated or furnished with olive trees .

olivella.explanation: A genus of gastropods of the family Olividæ. O. biplicata was used as money by Indians in California.

oliveness.explanation: Olive color; the state of being olivaceous in color.
The state or condition of being olive in colour.

olivenite.explanation: A mineral, Cu 2 (AsO 4 )(OH), a basic arsenate of copper, that is brown, olive green, or gray in color and found in copper deposits.
An arseniate of copper, usually of an olive-green color, occurring in prismatic crystals, and also in reniform, granular, and fibrous crusts.
An olive-green mineral, a hydrous arseniate of copper (Cu2(AsO4)(OH)); olive ore.
An orthorhombic copper arsenate mineral with the chemical formula Cu2AsO4OH.
rare green to black mineral consisting of hydrated copper arsenate that is found in copper deposits

oliver.explanation: A small tilt hammer , worked by the foot .

oliverian.explanation: An adherent of Oliver Cromwell; an admirer of the character or policy of Cromwell.

olivet.explanation: A false pearl; especially, in French industries, a pearl of the kind manufactured for export to savage peoples. Compare false pearl, Roman pearl , under pearl.

olivetan.explanation: A member of an order of Benedictine monks, founded in 1313, at Siena, Italy: the name was derived from the mother-house at Monte Oliveto, near Siena.

olivewood.explanation: The wood of the common olive.
The name of two trees, Elæodendron orientale of Mauritius and Madagascar, and E. australe of Australia.
An Australian name given to the hard white wood of certain trees of the genus Elæodendron, and also to the trees themselves.
The wood of the olive tree
Any of several ornamental trees of the genus Cassine

olivil.explanation: A bitter crystalline substance, C 14 H 18 O 5 +H 2 O, which occurs in the gum and other parts of the olive-tree. It is easily oxidized to vanillin. Also called olivite .
A white, brilliant, starchy powder obtained from the gum of the olive-tree.
A white crystalline substance, obtained from an exudation from the olive, and having a bitter-sweet taste and acid proporties.
A white crystalline substance, obtained from an exudation from the olive , and having a bittersweet taste and acid properties.

olivine.explanation: A mineral silicate of iron and magnesium, principally (Mg, Fe) 2 SiO 4 , found in igneous and metamorphic rocks and used as a structural material in refractories and in cements.
A common name of the yellowish green mineral chrysolite, esp. the variety found in eruptive rocks. It is a silicate of magnesium and iron ((Mg,Fe)SiO4).
Any of a group of olive green magnesium - iron silicate minerals that crystallize in the orthorhombic system.
a mineral consisting of magnesium iron silicate; a source of magnesium

olivinite.explanation: In petrography , a name given by Eichstädt (1887) to a variety of peridotite or hornblendepicrite containing olivin and its decomposition-products, with hornblende and augite and occasionally a little anorthite.

olla.explanation: A rounded earthenware pot or jar, used especially for cooking or for carrying water.
In Spanish countries, an earthen jar or pot used for cooking and other purposes, or a dish of meat and vegetables cooked in such a jar.

A large porous earthenware jar or jug in universal use in the southwestern parts of the United States and Territories for holding drinking-water, which is kept cool by the evaporation of moisture through the substance of the jar.
In archaeology , a form of vase more properly called stamnos .
A favorite Spanish dish consisting of a mixture of all kinds of meat, cut into small pieces and stewed, with various kinds of vegetables.
Hence— Any incongruous mixture or miscellaneous collection.
A pot or jar having a wide mouth; a cinerary urn, especially one of baked clay.
A dish of stewed meat; an olio; an olla-podrida.
a cooking-pot or earthenware jar used in Spain and Spanish-speaking countries
A pot used for cooling water by evaporation in Latin America .
A cinerary urn in ancient Rome .
leaf or strip from a leaf of the talipot palm used in India for writing paper

ollamh.explanation: in Irish history, a man of science or learning , equivalent to a university professor

ollav.explanation: In Irish history, a man of science or learning , equivalent to a university professor

ollie.explanation: A skateboarding maneuver in which the rider lifts the board into the air by pressing down on it with the rear foot, raising the front foot, and then raising the rear foot.
A similar maneuver in snowboarding in which the rider lifts the front foot and then the rear foot to spring into the air without going off a ramp.
a manoeuvre wherein one catches air by lifting the front and tail ends off the ground at the same time; a hop .

olm.explanation: The local name of the blind cave-salamander, Proteus anguinus , of Carniola, adopted as a common name. See cut at Proteus.
A European cave-dwelling aquatic salamander ( Proteus anguinus ) with permanent external gills.
a cave - dwelling amphibian , Proteus anguinus of the genus Proteus , having external gills ; it is found along the coast from northeastern Italy to Montenegro
European aquatic salamander with permanent external gills that lives in caves

olneya.explanation: A genus of small trees of the polypetalous order Leguminosæ , the tribe Galegeæ , and the subtribe Robinieæ , known by the wingless glandular pod with rigid valves, and the thick capitate stigma.

ologist.explanation: One who is versed in or professor of an ‘ology’; a scientist.

ology.explanation: A science the name of which ends in - ology ; hence, any science or branch of knowledge.
A termination in many words taken from the Greek or formed of Greek elements, especially words denoting a science or department of knowledge. See the etymology.

A termination of some nouns of Greek origin (few or none of this kind being newly formed) in which - ology implies ‘a gathering.’ Examples are anthology , a gathering of flowers (distinguished from anthology , the science of flowers, a word of modern formation), and carpology.
A colloquial or humorous name for any science or branch of knowledge.
Any branch of learning, especially one ending in “ -logy ”.
an informal word (abstracted from words with this ending) for some unidentified branch of knowledge

olor.explanation: A genus of Cygninæ or swans, containing such as are white in plumage, without a frontal knob, and with a complicated windpipe.

oloroso.explanation: A type of sherry , darker and smoother than fino sherry, used as a base for sweetened sherries.

olpe.explanation: In Greek antiquity : A leathern oil-flask used in the palæstra, etc.

A small pouring- or dipping-vase, somewhat of the form of the oinochoë, but in general with an even rim and no spout, and having the neck more open. In some examples, as in the cut, the rim is trifoliate.
Originally, a leather flask or vessel for oils or liquids; afterward, an earthenware vase or pitcher without a spout.
Originally, a leather flask or vessel for oils or liquids; afterward, an earthenware vase or pitcher without a spout.

olpidium.explanation: A genus of zygomycetous fungi, with immotile plasmodia, round or slightly elongated sporangia, and ellipsoidal zoöspores. Thirteen species are known.

olympianism.explanation: In the religious system of the ancient Greeks, the worship of the twelve greater gods, dwellers in Olympus: distinguished from the older Pelasgic traditions and fom the later mythology.
Worship of the Olympian gods, esp. as a dominant cult or religion.

olympionic.explanation: An ode on an Olympic victory.
An ode in honor of a victor in the Olympic games.

olynthiac.explanation: One of the speeches of Demosthenes known as the Olynthiac orations.

om.explanation: A combination of letters invested with peculiar sanctity both in the Hindu religions and in Buddhism.
A sacred, mystical syllable used in prayer and meditation.

omadhaun.explanation: A fool; a simpleton: a term of abuse common in Ireland and to a less extent in the Gaelic-speaking parts of Scotland. Also omadawn, amadan.
A fool, someone who is out of their senses, simpleton.

omander.explanation: The wood of Diospyros ebenaster, a kind of ebony found in Ceylon .

omasum.explanation: The third division of the stomach of a ruminant animal, located between the abomasum and the reticulum.
The third stomach of a ruminant; the psalterium or manyplies. See abomasum .
The third division of the stomach of ruminants. See manyplies , and Illust. under ruminant .
The third part of the stomach of a ruminant .
the third compartment of the stomach of a ruminant

omber.explanation: A game at cards, borrowed from the Spaniards, and usually played by three persons.

ombre.explanation: A card game, played by three players with 40 cards, that was popular in Europe during the 1600s and 1700s.
A game at cards borrowed from the Spaniards, usually played by three persons, though sometimes by two, four, or five, with a pack of forty cards, the eights, nines, and tens being thrown out.
A large Mediterranean food fish ( Umbrina cirrhosa ): -- called also umbra , and umbrine .
A card game , borrowed from the Spaniards, and usually played by three persons.
A large Mediterranean food fish (Umbrina cirrhosa): -- called also umbra , and umbrine .

ombrifuge.explanation: A protection or refuge from rain.

ombrology.explanation: The scientific knowledge of rain; also, a treatise or discourse about rain.

ombrometer.explanation: A machine or an instrument designed to measure the quantity of rainfall. See rain-gage .
An instrument for measuring the rain that falls; a rain gauge.

ombrophile.explanation: Any plant that flourishes in a rainy environment

ombrophilous.explanation: phytogeography , said of plants or their parts, chiefly their foliage, or of the abstract character. Ombrophilous character is manifested by the fact that the leaves or other parts are wettable: opposed to ombrophobous .
Capable of thriving in areas of heavy rainfall

ombrophobous.explanation: phytogeography , said of plants or their parts, chiefly the foliage. Ombrophobous character is usually shown by a water-shedding or unwettable surface (due to hairs or a waxy covering), as in the common Caladium , in Impaticns , etc. Other adaptations, as the form or position of the leaf, assist in shedding or escaping water.

ombrophoby.explanation: In phytogeography , the condition of being ombrophobous.

ombudsman.explanation: A man who investigates complaints and mediates fair settlements, especially between aggrieved parties such as consumers or students and an institution or organization.
A government official, especially in Scandinavian countries, who investigates citizens' complaints against the government or its functionaries.
An appointed official whose duty is to investigate complaints , generally on behalf of individuals such as consumers or taxpayers , against institutions such as companies and government departments .

A designated internal mediator in an organization whose duty is to assist members with conflict resolution and other problems and to serve as independent consultant to recommend changes to policies or procedures to improve organization effectiveness, efficiency, and humaneness .
a government appointee who investigates complaints by private persons against the government

ombudsmanship.explanation: The position or office of an ombudsman .

omega.explanation: The 24th letter of the Greek alphabet.
The last of a series; the end.
In cosmology theory, the ratio of the average density of matter in the universe to its critical density.
Relating to the end of the chain of carbon atoms that is opposite the carboxyl group in the molecule of a fatty acid.
The last letter of the Greek alphabet ( Ω , ω ); hence, figuratively, the last of anything.
The last letter of the Greek alphabet. See alpha .
The last; the end; hence, death.
the beginning and the ending; hence, the chief, the whole.

The twenty-fourth letter of the Classical and the Modern Greek alphabet, and the twenty-eighth letter of the Old and the Ancient Greek alphabet, i.e. the last letter of every Greek alphabet . Uppercase version: Ω ; lowercase: ω .
The end ; the final , last or ultimate in a series.
the last (24th) letter of the Greek alphabet
the ending of a series or sequence

omegoid.explanation: Having the form of the Greek capital letter Omega (Ω).
Having the form of the Greek capital letter omega , Ω .

omelet.explanation: A dish consisting of beaten eggs cooked until set and folded over, often around a filling.

A dish consisting of eggs beaten lightly, with the addition of milk, salt, and sometimes a little flour; it is browned in a buttered pan on the top of the stove. Omelets are some-times prepared with cheese, ham, parsley, jelly, fish, or other additions.

A dish consisting of eggs beaten up with a little flour, etc., and cooked in a frying pan until just set into a semisolid consistency; it may be folded around e.g. ham or cheese or jelly. When additional ingredients are mixed in, the names of the ingredients may be mentioned in the name of the omelet
an omelet containing chopped pieces of ham, onion, and green peppers.
beaten eggs or an egg mixture cooked until just set; may be folded around e.g. ham or cheese or jelly

omelette.explanation: A dish made with beaten eggs cooked in a frying pan without stirring, flipped over to cook on both sides, and sometimes filled or topped with cheese, chives or other foodstuffs
beaten eggs or an egg mixture cooked until just set; may be folded around e.g. ham or cheese or jelly

omen.explanation: A phenomenon supposed to portend good or evil; a prophetic sign.
To be a prophetic sign of; portend.
A casual event or occurrence supposed to portend good or evil; a sign or indication of some future event; a prognostic; an augury; a presage. See augur .

Synonyms Omen, Portent, Sign, Presage, Prognostic, Augury, Foreboding. Omen and portent are the most weighty and supernatural of these words. Omen and sign are likely to refer to that which is more immediate, the others to the more remote. Omen and portent are external: presage and foreboding are internal and subjective; the others are either internal or external. Sign is the most general. Prognostic applies to the prophesying of states of health or kinds of weather, and is the only one of these words that implies a deduction of effect from the collation of causes. Presage and augury are generally favorable, portent and foreboding always unfavorable, the rest either favorable or unfavorable. Omen and augury are most suggestive of the ancient, practice of consulting the gods through priests or augurs. A foreboding may be mistaken; the others are presumably correct. All these words have considerable freedom in figurative use. See foretell , v. t.
An occurrence supposed to portend, or show the character of, some future event; any indication or action regarded as a foreshowing; a foreboding; a presage; an augury.
To divine or to foreshow by signs or portents; to have omens or premonitions regarding; to predict; to augur.
Something which portends or is perceived to portend a good or evil event or circumstance in the future; an augury or foreboding .
To divine or predict from omens.
a sign of something about to happen

omened.explanation: Attended by, or containing, an omen or omens.
Attended by, or containing, an omen or omens; as, happy-omened day.

omens.explanation: Third-person singular simple present indicative form of omen .

omental.explanation: omental fold of peritoneum; an omental gland.
Of or pertaining to an omentum or the omenta.
Of or pertaining to an omentum or the omenta.

omentocele.explanation: Hernia of the omentum: same as epiplocele .

omentum.explanation: One of the folds of the peritoneum that connect the stomach with other abdominal organs, especially.
In anatomy , a fold or duplication of peritoneum, of two or four peritoneal layers, passing between or hanging down from certain abdominal viscera—the stomach, liver, spleen, and colon.
A free fold of the peritoneum, or one serving to connect viscera, support blood vessels, etc.; an epiploön.
Either of two folds of the peritoneum that support the viscera
a fold of peritoneum supporting the viscera

omer.explanation: An ancient Hebrew unit of dry measure equal to a tenth of an ephah, about 3.5 liters (3.7 quarts).
An offering of a sheaf or an omer of the first harvest of barley to a priest in the Temple on the second day of Passover.
A 49-day liturgical season, originally a harvest festival, from the second day of Passover to the first day of Shavuot, during which marriages are prohibited and signs of mourning are observed.
A handful of grain: a sheaf.
A Hebrew dry measure equal to the tenth part of an ephah, or 3½ quarts.
A handful of grain; a sheaf.
A Hebrew dry measure equal to the tenth part of an ephah.
A Hebrew measure, the tenth of an ephah. See ephah .
A dry measure of ancient Israel, one tenth of an ephah .

omicron.explanation: The 15th letter of the Greek alphabet.
The fifteenth letter of the Greek alphaoet (O, o ).
Lit., the little, or short, O, o; the fifteenth letter of the Greek alphabet.
the name for the 15th letter of Classical and Modern Greek . The 16th in Ancient and Old Greek .
the 15th letter of the Greek alphabet

ominate.explanation: To presage; to foreshow; to foretoken.
To presage ; to foreshow ; to foretoken .

ominous.explanation: Of or being an omen, especially an evil one.

threatening or foreshadowing evil or tragic developments

The aggregate value of the different stocks in which a loan to government is usually funded .

An animal which is able to consume both plants (like a herbivore ) and meat (like a carnivore ).
a person who eats all kinds of foods
an animal that feeds on both animal and vegetable substances

omnivorous.explanation: Eating food of any kind, including animals and plants.

Omnivora : as, omnivorous animals: often used figuratively: as, an omnivorous reader.

Having a diet which is neither exclusively carnivorous nor herbivorous .

feeding on both plants and animals

omnivorously.explanation: In the manner of an omnivore .

omnivorousness.explanation: The habit or character of being omnivorous.

Of or pertaining to the umbilicus , or navel .

Transmitted by black flies, the disease occurs in tropical regions of Africa and Central America.

An infection with nematodes of the genus Onchocerca, especially Onchocerca volvulus . Untreated, such infections can cause serious dermatological problems, and in advanced cases may lead to blindness. In certain areas of tropical Africa the blindness caused by onchocerciasis is called river blindness .
A disease caused by a worm of the genus Onchocerca, especially as transmitted to humans by flies and often causing blindness ; common in tropical Africa.

infestation with slender threadlike roundworms (filaria) deposited under the skin by the bite of black fleas; when the eyes are involved it can result in blindness; common in Africa and tropical America

Any of the genus Oncidium of tropical orchidaceous plants .

oncost.explanation: In coal-mining , the cost of upkeep, making and maintaining shafts and roads, pumping, etc. The engineers and others employed on this work are paid by time.
The indirect expenditure incurred for the purpose of increasing the productive power of organized labor.

In cost accounting, expenditure which is involved in the process of manufacture or the performance of work and which cannot be charged directly to any particular article manufactured or work done (as where different kinds of goods are produced), but must be allocated so that each kind of goods or work shall bear its proper share.
The cost of upkeep, making and maintaining shafts, roads, pumping, etc.
The indirect expenditure incurred for the purpose of increasing the productive power of organised labour.

oncotomy.explanation: In surgery , the incision into, or the excision of, a tumor.

ondoyant.explanation: Wavy; having the surface marked by waves or slightly depressed furrows.

Characterized by unity; undivided.
Of the same kind or quality.

one side of the room to the other.
one age.
one often implies social obscurity or insignificance, and thus conveys more or less contempt.
self : used reflexively.

one was formerly used before the article the or an , or a pronoun, followed by an adjective, often in the superlative (as “ one the best prince”), where now the pronoun one , followed by of and a plural noun (partitive genitive), would be used (as “one of the best princes”). The first whole number, consisting of a single unit; unity.

one are — As antecedent to a relative pronoun, one who being equivalent to any person who , or to he who, she who , without distinction of gender.
one ? this portrait is a fine one.
being, person , or the like.

people, they, we (if the speaker does not except himself from the general statement), you (the person addressed being taken as an example of others in general), or the impersonal passive may be substituted: as, one cannot be too careful ( we cannot, you cannot, they cannot, people cannot be too careful); one knows not when (it is not known when). One is sometimes virtually a substitute for the first person, employed by a speaker who does not wish to put himself prominently forward: as, one does not like to say so, but it is only too true; one tries to do one's best. One's self or oneself is the corresponding reflexive: as, one must not praise one's self.
capitalized ] A certain being, namely the Deity; God: the name being avoided from motives of reverence or from reserve.
To cause to become one; to gather into a single whole; to unite; to assimilite.
Being a single unit, or entire being or thing, and no more; not multifold; single; individual.

Pointing out a contrast, or denoting a particular thing or person different from some other specified; -- used as a correlative adjective, with or without the .
Closely bound together; undivided; united; constituting a whole.
Single in kind; the same; a common.
Single; unmarried.

A systematic arrangement of all of the important categories of objects or concepts which exist in some field of discourse, showing the relations between them. When complete, an ontology is a categorization of all of the concepts in some field of knowledge, including the objects and all of the properties, relations, and functions needed to define the objects and specify their actions. A simplified ontology may contain only a hierarchical classification (a taxonomy ) showing the type subsumption relations between concepts in the field of discourse. An ontology may be visualized as an abstract graph with nodes and labeled arcs representing the objects and relations.
The branch of metaphysics that addresses the nature or essential characteristics of being and of things that exist ; the study of being qua being.
The theory of a particular philosopher or school of thought concerning the fundamental types of entity in the universe .

The oögonia, which eventually give rise to the primary oöcytes, are homologous in the oögenesis with the spermatogonia in the spermatogenesis of the male animal of the same species.
In botany , the female sexual organ in certain cryptogamic plants.
A special cell in certain cryptogamous plants containing oöspheres, as in the rockweeds (Fucus), and the orders Vaucherieæ and Peronosporeæ.
An immature ovarian egg within a developing fetus

ooh.explanation: Used to express pleasure, satisfaction, surprise, or great joy.
To exclaim in pleasure, satisfaction, surprise, or great joy.
The sound made to imitate a ghost .
express admiration and pleasure by uttering `ooh' or `aah'

oohed.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of ooh .

ooid.explanation: A small calcium carbonate or iron coated grain found on the seafloor .

ookinete.explanation: The motile zygote of a parasite of the malaria mosquito that forms an oocyst in the mosquito's gut

oolak.explanation: A freight-canoe of the Hoogly and central Bengal, which surpasses most other river-boats in its speed under sail. It has a sharp stem, and the sides slightly rounded, and is easily steered with an oar.

oolemma.explanation: The cell membrane of an oocyte.

oolite.explanation: A sedimentary rock, usually limestone, consisting of ooliths that are cemented together.
A rock consisting of spherical grains within a mineral cortex accreted around a nucleus , often of quartz grains.

oolith.explanation: A small, round grain consisting of concentric layers of calcium carbonate, silica, or dolomite that have precipitated around a shell fragment, sand grain, pellet of alga, or other central object.

A spherical granule of which oolite is composed, formed by concentric accretion of thin layers of a mineral around a core. Calcium carbonate ( limestone ) is the most common mineral that forms ooliths, but they may also form from other minerals such as dolomite and silica .

oolitic.explanation: Of or pertaining to oölite; composed of, or resembling, oölite.
Made up of, or containing oolites

oolly.explanation: In Indian metal-working , a small lump of steel as it leaves the melting-pot, especially of Wootz steel.

oologically.explanation: From the perspective of scientific study of eggs or of a collector of eggs.

oologist.explanation: a person who studies or specializes in oology

oology.explanation: The branch of zoology that deals with eggs, especially birds' eggs.

oolong.explanation: A dark Chinese tea that has been partially fermented before drying.
A variety of black tea with the flavor of green tea. Also written oulong .
A fragrant variety of black tea having somewhat the flavor of green tea.

Chinese tea leaves that have been partially fermented before being dried

oomiac.explanation: A long, broad boat used by the Eskimos.

oomiak.explanation: A large boat made of skin, used by the Eskimos.

oompah.explanation: A rhythmic sound made by a tuba or other brass instrument.

oomycete.explanation: Any of various filamentous, often parasitic heterokonts of the division Oomycota, characterized by bearing female gametes in oogonia. Oomycetes include the downy mildews and other species that cause plant diseases such as late blight.
Any of a number of filamentous unicellular protists of the class Oomycetes; the water molds

oomycetes.explanation: nonphotosynthetic fungi that resemble algae and that reproduce by forming oospores; sometimes classified as protoctists

oont.explanation: A camel , especially an attractive camel

oopak.explanation: A variety of black tea grown in the province of Hupeh, central China.

oophore.explanation: The segment or stage of the life-cycle of the Pteridophyta and Bryophyta that bears the sexual organs. Compare sporophore , or that stage in which non-sexual organs of reproduction are borne.

An alternately produced form of certain cryptogamous plants, as ferns, mosses, and the like, which bears antheridia and archegonia, and so has sexual fructification, as contrasted with the sporophore , which is nonsexual, but produces spores in countless number. In ferns the oöphore is a minute prothallus; in mosses it is the leafy plant.
A form of some ferns and mosses that bear sexual fruit

oophorectomy.explanation: Surgical removal of one or both ovaries.

oophoric.explanation: Having the nature of, or belonging to, an oöphore.

oophoritis.explanation: inflammation of one or both ovaries

oophorosalpingectomy.explanation: surgical removal of one or both ovaries and the corresponding Fallopian tubes

oophyte.explanation: Any plant of a proposed class or grand division (collectively termed oöphytes or Oöphyta ), which have their sexual reproduction accomplished by motile antherozoids acting on oöspheres, either while included in their oögonia or after exclusion.

oophytic.explanation: Of or pertaining to an oöphyte.
of, pertaining to or characteristic of an oophyte

ooplasm.explanation: The cytoplasm of an egg or ovum

oosphere.explanation: A nonmotile female gamete formed in the oogonium of an alga, fungus, oomycete, or bryophyte.
In cryptogams, the naked nucleated spherical or ovoid mass of protoplasm in the center of the oögonium, which after fertilization develops the oöspore.
An unfertilized, rounded mass of protoplasm, produced in an oögonium.

oospore.explanation: A thick-walled zygote developed from a fertilized oosphere, especially in an oomycete.

One of the plates which in some Crustacea inclose a cavity wherein the eggs are hatched.

ootheca.explanation: The usually hardened egg case of certain invertebrates, such as a cockroach.

The part of the oviduct of certain trematode worms in which the ova are completed and furnished with a shell .

A specific act or activity.
The course of action or series of acts by which some result is accomplished; process.

In mathematics , the substitution of one quantity for another, or the act of passing from one to the other, the second quantity being definitely related to the first, either in value or in form. An operation must not be confounded with the process by which the operation is effected. Thus, there is but one operation of extracting the cube root of a number, but there are several different processes.
In war , the act of carrying out preconcerted measures by regular movements: as, military or naval operations.

In the fine arts , contrast.

A body of opposers; specifically, those members of a legislative body who are opposed to the administration for the time being, or the political party opposed to the party in power: frequently used adjectively: as, an opposition scheme; the opposition benches in the British House of Commons.
In fencing. See the quotation.
In chess , a position where the king of the player who has not the move is directly in front of that of his opponent with one vacant square between.
See the adjectives.
The act of opposing; an attempt to check, restrain, or defeat; resistance.
The state of being placed over against; situation so as to front something else.
Repugnance; contrariety of sentiment, interest, or purpose; antipathy.
That which opposes; an obstacle; specifically, the aggregate of persons or things opposing; hence, in politics and parliamentary practice, the party opposed to the party in power.

The situation of a heavenly body with respect to another when in the part of the heavens directly opposite to it; especially, the position of a planet or satellite when its longitude differs from that of the sun 180°; -- signified by the symbol �.

The relation between two propositions when, having the same subject and predicate, they differ in quantity, or in quality, or in both; or between two propositions which have the same matter but a different form.

uniaxial. Crystals belonging to the orthorhombic, monoclinic, and triclinic systems have two optic axes, and hence are biaxial.

In botany , one of the three cardinal points of temperature — namely that point at which the metabolic processes are carried on with the greatest activity.

The term is applicable not only to the factor of heat, but also to those of light, moisture, etc. The optimum for each several function must be distinguished from the total optimum for the plant, the most intense activity of a function often being injurious. According to Schimper, that condition which secures the highest intensity of a function is its absolute optimum ; that which secures its most favorable activity is its harmonic optimum ; and the harmonic optima together compose the œcological optimum for the plant.
Best possible or most desirable; -- usually under a restriction expressed or implied.

Choice; wish; preference; election.

The power or liberty of choosing; the right or power of choice; the opportunity of electing or selecting an alternative or one of several lines of conduct; the power of deciding on a course of action: as, that is not left in my option ; it is at your option to take it or leave it.
In Eng. canon law , the right, now obsolete, which an archbishop formerly had, on consecrating a bishop, of selecting a benefice in the bishop's diocese for one of his own chaplains.
On stock and other exchanges, a privilege, secured by the payment of a certain premium or consideration, either of calling for the delivery, or
of making delivery, of a certain specified amount of some particular stock or kind of produce, at a specified price, and within specified limits of time.
A wishing; a wish.
Synonyms Option, Choice, Preference, Election. Option is the right of choice, the freedom to choose between two or more: as, “there is no option ,”

Choice is primarily the act of choosing, but, by extension, may be the same as option : as, he gave him the choice. Preference is primarily the state of mind determining the choice, and secondarily the act of choosing. Election emphasizes the leaving of some while choosing others. Choice and preference may apply to that which is chosen; the others not.
The power of choosing; the right of choice or election; an alternative.
The exercise of the power of choice; choice.

An image of external objects fixed on the retina by the photochemical action of light on the visual purple .

optometry.explanation: The practice or profession of an optometrist.

The measurement of the visual powers in general (including the acuteness of the perception of form, of light, and of colors — eidoptometry, photoptometry, and chromatoptometry respectively), of the extent of the visual field (perioptometry), of the accommodative and refractive states of the eye (dioptometry), and of the position and movements of the eyeball. (ophthalmostatometry and ophthalmotropometry).

As defined (with minor variations) in the statutes of various States of the United States
“The employment of subjective and objective mechanical means to determine the accomodative and refractive states of the eye and the scope of its function in general.”
“The employment of any means, other than the use of drugs, for the measurement of the powers of vision and adaptation of lenses for the aid thereof.”

opulence.explanation: Synonyms Opulence, Wealth, Riches, Affluence. All these words imply not only the possession of much property, but the possession of it under such circumstances that it can be and is enjoyed. They seem contrasted not only with theīr opposites, but with the possession of a moderate amount. Opulence is a dignified and strong word for wealth. Wealth and riches may mean the property possessed, and riches generally does mean it; the others do not. Affluence suggests the flow of wealth to one, and resulting free expenditure for objects of desire. There is little difference in the strength of the words.
wealth as evidenced by sumptuous living

opulent.explanation: Possessing or exhibiting great wealth; affluent.
Characterized by extravagance or rich abundance; lavish or luxuriant.

or this (before this); or long (before long).
your .

or , presenting a choice between any two in the series: as, he may study law or medicine or divinity, or he may enter into trade. The correlations are — Either … or (in archaic or poetical use also or … or ).
… or (rarely or … or ), in indirect questions.
or a figure with four equal sides and equal angles.
Or sometimes begins a sentence, in this case expressing an alternative with the foregoing sentence, or merely a transition to some fresh argument or illustration.
her ( their ).
tor, -sor , of Latin origin, forming nouns of agent from verbs.
odor, horror, terror, honor , etc., or concrete, as in arbor , a tree, etc. It is not felt or used as an English formative.
major, minor, junior, senior, prior , but also commonly in nouns, as major, minor, prior, junior, senior , etc. It is not felt or used as an English formative.
ator.
ordeal, ort , and a few other words now obsolete.
oriental ; of Oregon.
Ere; before; sooner than.
See under Ever , and Ere .
A particle that marks an alternative. It corresponds to either . It often connects a series of words or propositions, presenting a choice of either.
Yellow or gold color, -- represented in drawing or engraving by small dots.

Connects at least two alternative words , phrases , clauses , sentences , etc. each of which could make a passage true . In English , this is the " inclusive or ." The " exclusive or " is formed by " either ...or".
Logical union of two sets of values. There are two forms, an exclusive or and an inclusive or .
Counts the elements before and after as two possibilities.
otherwise ; a consequence of the condition that the previous is false
Connects two equivalent names.
The gold or yellow tincture on a coat of arms .
Of gold or yellow tincture on a coat of arms.
Early (on).
Earlier , previously .
Before ; ere .
a room in a hospital equipped for the performance of surgical operations
a state in northwestern United States on the Pacific

ora.explanation: A margin, or border, in technical uses; specifically, in entomology , the inflexed or inferior lateral margin of the prothorax, often separated from the antepectus by a suture.
The day wind which blows from the south up the valley of lake Garda, in northern Italy.
A money of account among the Anglo-Saxons, valued, in the Domesday Book, at twenty pence sterling.
Plural form of os .; mouths or openings , especially of the cervix .
A unit of money among the Anglo-Saxons .

orabassu.explanation: A South American monkey of the genus Callithrix, esp. Callithrix Moloch .

orach.explanation: One of several Old World plants of the genus Atriplex , especially A. hortensis , the garden-orach. See Atriplex and mountain-spinach.
A genus (Atriplex) of herbs or low shrubs of the Goosefoot family, most of them with a mealy surface.
a plant ( Atriplex hortensis ), often used as a pot herb; -- also called mountain spinach .
Any of several plants , of the genus Atriplex , found in dry habitats, that have edible leaves resembling spinach.
any of various herbaceous plants of the genus Atriplex that thrive in deserts and salt marshes

orache.explanation: Any of various plants of the genus Atriplex, especially A. hortensis, having edible leaves that taste somewhat like spinach.
Any of various edible plants of the genus Atriplex, especially A. hortensis or A. patula.
any of various herbaceous plants of the genus Atriplex that thrive in deserts and salt marshes

oracle.explanation: A shrine consecrated to the worship and consultation of a prophetic deity, as that of Apollo at Delphi.
A person, such as a priestess, through whom a deity is held to respond when consulted.
The response given through such a medium, often in the form of an enigmatic statement or allegory.
A person considered to be a source of wise counsel or prophetic opinions.
An authoritative or wise statement or prediction.
A command or revelation from God.
In the Bible, the sanctuary of the Temple.

In classical antiquity : An utterance given by a priest or priestess of a god, in the name of the god and, as was believed, by his inspiration, in answer to a human inquiry, usually respecting some future event, as the success of an enterprise or battle, or some proposed line of conduct.
The deity who was supposed to give such answers to inquiries.
The place where oracular answers were given; the sanctuary, temple, or adytum whence the supposed supernatural responses proceeded.
Hence, by extension — The communications, revelations, or instruction delivered by God to or through his prophets: rarely used in the singular: as, the oracles of God; the divine oracles.
The sanctuary or most holy place in the temple, in which was deposited the ark of the covenant (1 Ki. vi. 19): sometimes used for the temple itself.
A source or repository of the divine will that may be consulted or drawn upon.
An uncommonly wise person, whose opinions are of great authority, and whose determinations are not disputed.
A wise saying or an authoritative decision given by such a person.
Something that is looked upon as an infallible guide or standard of reference.
The answer of a god, or some person reputed to be a god, to an inquiry respecting some affair or future event, as the success of an enterprise or battle.
The deity who was supposed to give the answer; also, the place where it was given.
The communications, revelations, or messages delivered by God to the prophets; also, the entire sacred Scriptures -- usually in the plural.
The sanctuary, or Most Holy place in the temple; also, the temple itself.
One who communicates an oracle{1} or divine command; an angel; a prophet.
Any person reputed uncommonly wise; one whose decisions are regarded as of great authority.
A wise pronouncement or decision considered as of great authority.
To utter oracles.
A shrine dedicated to some prophetic deity .
A person such as a priest through whom the deity is supposed to respond with prophecy or advice.
A prophetic response, often enigmatic or allegorical , so given.
A person considered to be a source of wisdom .
A theoretical entity capable of answering some collection of questions .
To utter oracles or prophecies.
an authoritative person who divines the future
a shrine where an oracular god is consulted
a prophecy (usually obscure or allegorical) revealed by a priest or priestess; believed to be infallible

oracler.explanation: One who utters oracles; the giver of an oracle or oracular response.

oracles.explanation: Third-person singular simple present indicative form of oracle .

oracular.explanation: Of, relating to, or being an oracle.
Resembling or characteristic of an oracle.
Of or pertaining to an oracle; uttering oracles; forecasting the future.
Resembling an oracle in some way, as in solemnity, wisdom, authority, obscurity, ambiguity, dogmatism.
Of or relating to an oracle .
of or relating to an oracle
resembling an oracle in obscurity of thought

oraculous.explanation: Oracular; of the nature of an oracle.

oraculously.explanation: In an oraculous manner; like an oracle .

oraculousness.explanation: The state or condition of being oraculous .

oracy.explanation: The ability to speak , and to understand spoken language

orad.explanation: In anatomy , towards the oral opening or mouth (compare with ventral )
toward the mouth or oral region

orage.explanation: In organ-building , a stop constructed so as to produce a noise in imitation of the sound of a storm.

oral.explanation: Spoken rather than written.
Of or relating to the mouth.
Used in or taken through the mouth.
Consisting of or using speech.
Articulated through the mouth only, with the nasal passages closed.

Of or relating to the first stage of psychosexual development in psychoanalytic theory, from birth to about 18 months, during which the mouth is the chief focus of exploration and pleasure. The oral stage is followed by the anal stage.
An academic examination in which questions and answers are spoken rather than written.
In crinoids, same as oral valve (which see, under oral ).
oral orifice; oral surgery; oral gestation.
oral traditions; oral testimony; oral law.
zoology , situated on the same part or side of the body as the mouth: opposed to aboral or anal.
Uttered by the mouth, or in words; spoken, not written; verbal
Of or pertaining to the mouth; surrounding or lining the mouth.
Relating to the mouth ; mouthly .
Spoken rather than written.
A spoken test or examination , particularly in a language class.
A physical examination of the mouth .
oral sex .
using speech rather than writing
a stage in psychosexual development when the child's interest is concentrated in the mouth; fixation at this stage is said to result in dependence, selfishness, and aggression
of or involving the mouth or mouth region or the surface on which the mouth is located
of or relating to or affecting or for use in the mouth
an examination conducted by spoken communication

orale.explanation: A veil worn by the Pope at solemn pontifical celebrations; the fanon. See fanon , 3 .
In craniometry , the anterior terminal point of the sutura incisiva, on the inner face of the alveolar process.

oralism.explanation: The theory or practice of teaching hearing-impaired or deaf persons to communicate by means of spoken language.
The system of teaching deaf-mutes by means of ordinary speech or lip-language, without the use of the hand-manual.

A philosophy of education for the deaf, opposed to manualism , that uses spoken language consisting of lipreading , speech , the process of watching mouth movements, and mastering breathing techniques.

oralist.explanation: One who speaks correctly and with precision.
One who advocates or uses the oral system in teaching deaf-mutes.

orality.explanation: Capability of being orally conveyed to another.

oralization.explanation: The process of making (the muscular movements in eating, etc.?) more distinctly oral or concerned with the mouth muscles (and thereby more manageable for ‘oral’ or vocal utterance).

orally.explanation: By, with, or in, the mouth.
by spoken rather than written means
(of drugs) through the mouth rather than through injection; by_mouth

orang.explanation: large long-armed ape of Borneo and Sumatra having arboreal habits

orange.explanation: Any of several evergreen trees of the genus Citrus of Southeast Asia, widely cultivated in warm regions and having fragrant white flowers and round fruit with a yellowish or reddish rind and a sectioned, pulpy interior, especially the sweet orange and the bitter orange.
The fruit of any of these trees, having a sweetish, acidic juice.
Any of several similar plants, such as the Osage orange and the mock orange.

The hue of that portion of the visible spectrum lying between red and yellow, evoked in the human observer by radiant energy with wavelengths of approximately 590 to 630 nanometers; any of a group of colors between red and yellow in hue, of medium lightness and moderate saturation.
Of the color orange.
Made from oranges.
Tasting or smelling like oranges.
Orange lodge; an Orange emblem. See Orangeman .
A mordant acid coal-tar color of the monoazo type prepared by combining diazotized para-nitraniline with salicylic acid. Also called alizarin yellow R .
Same as orange T .

The fruit of the orange-tree, a large globose berry of eight or ten membranous cells, each containing several seeds which are packed in a pulp of fusiform vesicles, distended with an acidulous refreshing juice.
A rather low branching evergreen fruit-tree, Citrus Aurantium , with greenish-brown bark, elliptical or ovate coriaceous leaves, the petiole often winged, and fragrant white flowers.
A reddish-yellow color, of which the orange is the type.
In heraldry , a roundel tenné. See roundel .

The Carolina cherry-laurel, Prunus Caroliniana. It is a small tree with glossy coriaceous leaves, wild and cultivated for ornament in the southern United States. Its foliage, bark, and fruit contain prussic acid, and the leaves are often fatal to animals browsing upon them. Also called mock-orange and wild peach.
See toothache-tree .
Of or pertaining to an orange; of the color of an orange; reddish yellow.

The fruit of a tree of the genus Citrus ( Citrus Aurantium ). It is usually round, and consists of pulpy carpels, commonly ten in number, inclosed in a leathery rind, which is easily separable, and is reddish yellow when ripe.
The tree that bears oranges; the orange tree.
The color of an orange; reddish yellow.
See Mandarin .
any species of shrubs of the genus Philadelphus, which have whitish and often fragrant blossoms.
an Australian shrub ( Citriobatus parviflorus ); also, its edible yellow berries.
a tanager of Jamaica ( Tanagra zena ); -- so called from its bright orange breast.
a large, handsome cowry ( Cypræa aurantia ), highly valued by collectors of shells on account of its rarity.
an inconspicuous annual American plant ( Hypericum Sarothra ), having minute, deep yellow flowers.
an oily, terpenelike substance obtained from orange rind, and distinct from neroli oil, which is obtained from the flowers.
a kind of black tea.
an orange-colored apple with acid flavor.
the orangelike fruit of a shrubby species of nightshade ( Solanum Quitoense ), native in Quito.
any species of scale insects which infests orange trees; especially, the purple scale ( Mytilaspis citricola ), the long scale ( Mytilaspis Gloveri ), and the red scale ( Aspidiotus Aurantii ).
An evergreen tree of the genus Citrus such as Citrus aurantium .
The fruit of an orange tree; a citrus fruit with a slightly sour flavour.
The colour of a ripe orange (the fruit); a color midway between red and yellow.
Having the colour of the fruit of an orange tree; yellowred ; reddish-yellow.
To color orange.
To become orange.
any citrus tree bearing oranges
a river in South Africa that flows generally westward to the Atlantic Ocean
round yellow to orange fruit of any of several citrus trees
any pigment producing the orange color
of the color between red and yellow; similar to the color of a ripe orange
orange color or pigment; any of a range of colors between red and yellow

orangeade.explanation: A beverage of orange juice, sugar, and water.
A drink made of orange-juice and water sweetened.
A drink made of orange juice and water, corresponding to lemonade ; orange sherbet.
A soft drink or a soda with an orange flavour.
A mixture of soda water and orange juice .
sweetened beverage of diluted orange juice

orangeat.explanation: Sugared or candied orange-peel, a sweetmeat.

orangeism.explanation: The principles which the Orange lodges (see Orangeman ) are formed to uphold; the maintenance and ascendancy of Protestantism, and opposition to Romanism and Romish influence in civil government.
Attachment to the principles of the society of Orangemen; the tenets or practices of the Orangemen.

orangeleaf.explanation: An evergreen rubiaceous shrub of New Zealand, Coprosma lucida.

orangeness.explanation: The quality of being orange in colour.
orange color or pigment; any of a range of colors between red and yellow

oranger.explanation: A ship or vessel employed in carrying oranges.
comparative form of orange : more orange

orangeroot.explanation: An American ranunculaceous plant ( Hidrastis Canadensis ), having a yellow tuberous root; -- also called yellowroot , golden seal , etc.

orangery.explanation: A sheltered place, especially a greenhouse, used for growing orange trees and other delicate plants in cool climates.
A place where oranges are cultivated; particularly, a glass house for preserving orange-trees during winter.
A place for raising oranges; a plantation of orange trees.
A greenhouse in which orange trees are grown.
a place where oranges are grown; a plantation of orange trees in warm climes or a greenhouse in cooler areas

orangewood.explanation: fine-grained wood of an orange tree; used in fine woodwork

orangey.explanation: Resembling, or flavoured with, oranges (the fruit).

orangier.explanation: comparative form of orangey : more orangey

orangiest.explanation: superlative form of orangey : most orangey .

orangish.explanation: of the color between red and yellow; similar to the color of a ripe orange

orangist.explanation: One who raises oranges; a planter of orange-groves.

orangite.explanation: An orange-colored variety of the rare thorium silicate called thorite , from near Brevig in Norway.
An orange-yellow variety of thorite , found in Norway .

orangutan.explanation: Either of two large arboreal apes, Pongo pygmaeus of Borneo or P. abelii of Sumatra, having a shaggy reddish-brown coat, very long arms, and no tail.
An arboreal anthropoid ape genus Pongo consisting of two species, Pongo pygmaeus of Borneo and Pongo abelii of Sumatra , having a shaggy reddish - brown coat , very long arms , and no tail .
large long-armed ape of Borneo and Sumatra having arboreal habits

orant.explanation: In anc. art , a female figure in an attitude of prayer; a female adorant.
In early Christian art , a female figure standing with arms outspread or slightly raised in prayer, symbolizing the church as engaged in adoration and intercession.
An image of a person with hands up in prayer .

orarian.explanation: One who lives on the sea-coast.
Of or pertaining to a coast.
Of or pertaining to a coast .

orarion.explanation: In the Gr. Ch. , the deacon's stole, as distinguished from the epitrachelion or priest's stole. It is worn over the left shoulder, and is somewhat wider than the Western stole.

orarium.explanation: A Latin book of private prayer, especially that issued in England under Henry VIII. in 1546, or the one published under Elizabeth in 1560.
A handkerchief or scarf used in waving applause in the circus.
A stole: replaced in the Western Church by the name stola about the ninth century. See orarion and stole.
A scarf affixed to the crozier, in use as early as the thirteenth century.

orate.explanation: To speak in a formal, often pompous manner.
To speak formally; to give a speech .
To speak passionately ; to preach for or against something.

orated.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of orate .

orates.explanation: Third-person singular simple present indicative form of orate .

oration.explanation: A formal speech, especially one given on a ceremonial occasion.
A speech delivered in a high-flown or pompous manner.
A formal speech or discourse; an eloquent or weighty address.

An elaborate discourse, delivered in public, treating an important subject in a formal and dignified manner; especially, a discourse having reference to some special occasion, as a funeral, an anniversary, a celebration, or the like; -- distinguished from an argument in court, a popular harangue, a sermon, a lecture, etc..
To deliver an oration; to speak.

orationer.explanation: One who presents a supplication or petition; a petitioner.

orator.explanation: An eloquent and skilled public speaker.
A public speaker; one who delivers an oration; a person who pronounces a discourse publicly on some special occasion; a pleader or lawyer.
An eloquent public speaker; one who is skilled as a speaker; an eloquent man: as, he writes and reasons well, but is no orator.
A spokesman; an advocate; a defender; one who defends by pleading; one who argues in favor of a person or a cause.
In law , the plaintiff or petitioner in a bill or information in chancery.
An orationer; a petitioner; one who offers a prayer or petition.
An officer of English universities: see the quotation.
A public speaker; one who delivers an oration; especially, one distinguished for his skill and power as a public speaker; one who is eloquent.
In equity proceedings, one who prays for relief; a petitioner.
A plaintiff, or complainant, in a bill in chancery.

An officer who is the voice of the university upon all public occasions, who writes, reads, and records all letters of a public nature, presents, with an appropriate address, those persons on whom honorary degrees are to be conferred, and performs other like duties; -- called also public orator .
Someone who orates or delivers an oration .
A skilled and eloquent public speaker .
a person who delivers a speech or oration

oratorian.explanation: A member of a Roman Catholic oratory

oratorical.explanation: Of, relating to, or characteristic of an orator or oratory.
oratorical flourishes; to speak in an oratorical way.

of, or relating to oratory or an orator
characteristic of an orator or oratory

oratorio.explanation: A musical composition for voices and orchestra, telling a usually sacred story without costumes, scenery, or dramatic action.
A place of worship; a chapel; an oratory.
A form of extended musical composition, more or less dramatic in character, based upon a religious (or occasionally a heroic) theme, and intended to be performed without dramatic action and scenery.
The words or text of an oratorio; an oratorio libretto.

A more or less dramatic text or poem, founded on some Scripture nerrative, or great divine event, elaborately set to music, in recitative, arias, grand choruses, etc., to be sung with an orchestral accompaniment, but without action, scenery, or costume, although the oratorio grew out of the Mysteries and the Miracle and Passion plays, which were acted.
Performance or rendering of such a composition.
A musical composition on a religious theme ; similar to opera but with no costume , scenery or acting .
a musical composition for voices and orchestra based on a religious text

oratorship.explanation: The position or office of orator, as the public oratorship in an English university. See orator , 6.

oratory.explanation: The art of an orator; the art of speaking well, or of speaking according to the rules of rhetoric, in order to please or persuade; the art of public speaking. The three principal branches of this art are deliberative, epidictic , and judicial oratory. See epidictic .
Exercise of eloquence; eloquent language; eloquence: as, all his oratory was spent in vain.
Prayer; supplication; the act of beseeching or petitioning.
Pl. oratories (-riz). A place for prayer or worship.
The art of an orator; the art of public speaking in an eloquent or effective manner; the exercise of rhetorical skill in oral discourse; eloquence.
A place of orisons, or prayer; especially, a chapel or small room set apart for private devotions.
a society of priests founded by St. Philip Neri, living in community, and not bound by a special vow. The members are called also oratorians .
The art of public speaking , especially in a formal , expressive , or forceful manner.
Eloquence ; the quality of artistry and persuasiveness in speech or writing .
addressing an audience formally (usually a long and rhetorical address and often pompous)

oratress.explanation: A woman who makes public addresses.

oratrix.explanation: In law , a female petitioner or female plaintiff in a bill in chancery.

A female plaintiff , or complainant , in equity pleading .

orb.explanation: A sphere or spherical object.
A celestial body, such as the sun or moon.
The earth.
One of a series of concentric transparent spheres thought by ancient and medieval astronomers to revolve about the earth and carry the celestial bodies.
A globe surmounted by a cross, used as a symbol of monarchial power and justice.
An eye or eyeball.
Something of circular form; a circle or orbit.

Hence The earth or one of the heavenly bodies; in particular, the sun or the moon.
The eye; an eyeball: so called from its spheroidal shape, and the comparison between its luminous brilliancy and that of the stars.
A hollow globe; specifically, in ancient astronomy , a hollow globe or sphere supposed to form part of the solar or sidereal system.
The globe forming part of royal regalia; the monde or mound.
In astrology , the space within which the astrological influence of a planet or of a house is supposed to act.

A blank window or panel.

To form into an orb or circle.
To encircle; to surround; to inclose.
A spherical body; a globe; especially, one of the celestial spheres; a sun, planet, or star.
One of the azure transparent spheres conceived by the ancients to be inclosed one within another, and to carry the heavenly bodies in their revolutions.
A circle; esp., a circle, or nearly circular orbit, described by the revolution of a heavenly body; an orbit.
A period of time marked off by the revolution of a heavenly body.
The eye, as luminous and spherical.
A revolving circular body; a wheel.
A sphere of action or influence.
Same as Mound , a ball or globe. See 1st Mound .
A body of soldiers drawn up in a circle, as for defense, esp. infantry to repel cavalry.

The state of being orbate , or deprived of parents or children; privation , in general; bereavement .

orbed.explanation: Having the form of an orb; round.
Having the form of an orb ; round ; spherical .

orbicular.explanation: Circular and flat. Used especially of leaves.
petrography , in phanerocrystal-line igneous rocks, having large spheroidal aggregations of minerals, in radial or concentric groups of megascopic crystals: as, orbicular granite, orbicular diorite.
entomology , having a regularly rounded surface and bordered by a circular margin: as, the orbicular pronotum of a beetle.
botany , having the shape of a flat body with a nearly circular outline: as, an orbicular leaf. Also orbiculate .
In entomology , a circular mark or spot nearly always found on the anterior wings of the noctuid moths.
Resembling or having the form of an orb; spherical; circular; orbiculate.
Circular or spherical in shape; round .
having the shape of a sphere or ball

orbicularis.explanation: In anatomy , a muscle surrounding an orifice, as that of the mouth or eyelids; a sphincter.

orbicularness.explanation: The state of being orbicular; sphericity.

orbiculate.explanation: That which is orbiculate; especially, a solid the vertical section of which is oval, and the horizontal section circular.
Made, or being, in the form of an orb; having a circular, or nearly circular, or a spheroidal, outline.
a leaf whose outline is nearly circular.

orbiculation.explanation: The state or quality of being orbiculate; orbicularness.
The state or quality of being orbiculate .

orbiculoidea.explanation: A genus of neotrematous brachiopods of the family Discinidæ , having circular chitinous shells, the pedicle passage being in the form of a slit which extends from the beak of the pedicle-valve forward, and closed behind, as growth advances, by a listrium. It is common in all rocks from the Lower Silurian to the Cretaceous.

orbit.explanation: The path of a celestial body or an artificial satellite as it revolves around another body due to their mutual gravitational attraction.
One complete revolution of such a body.
The path of a body in a field of force surrounding another body; for example, the movement of an atomic electron in relation to a nucleus.
A range of activity, experience, or knowledge.
A range of control or influence: synonym : range .
Either of two bony cavities in the skull containing an eye and its external structures.

Track; course; path, especially a path, as that in a circle or an ellipse, which returns into itself; specifically, in astronomy , the path of a planet or comet; the curve-line which a planet describes in its periodical revolution round its central body or center of revolution: as, the orbit of Jupiter or Mercury.
A small orb, globe, or ball.

In ornithology , the orbita, or circumorbital region of a bird's head; the skin of the eyelids and adjoining parts.

The path described by a heavenly body in its periodical revolution around another body.
An orb or ball.

orbite.explanation: In petrography , a fine-grained diorite-porphyry with phenocrysts of hornblende and lime-soda feldspar.

orbited.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of orbit .
