The opinions of Origen of Alexandria, who lived in the 3d century, one of the most learned of the Greek Fathers. Prominent in his teaching was the doctrine that all created beings, including Satan, will ultimately be saved.

origenist.explanation: A follower of Origen of Alexandria; one who held or professed to hold the doctrines held by or attributed to Origen.
A member of a sect mentioned by Epiphanius as followers of some unknown person named Origen. He attributes shameful vices to them, but supplies no further information concerning them.
A follower of Origen of Alexandria.

origin.explanation: The point at which something comes into existence or from which it derives or is derived.
Ancestry.
The fact of originating; rise or derivation.
The point of attachment of a muscle that remains relatively fixed during contraction.
The point of intersection of coordinate axes, as in the Cartesian coordinate system.
Beginning of existence; rise or first manifestation; first stage or indication of being or existence.
That from which anything derives its being or nature; source of being or existence; cause or occasion; fountain; source: as, the origins of a nation.
Hence, parentage; ancestry; pedigree; extraction; birth.
In mathematics , the fixed starting-point from which measurement or motion starts; specifically, in analytical geometry , the point from which the coördinates are measured.
In anatomy : The proximal, larger, or more fixed one of the two ends or attachments of a muscle; the part or place whence a muscle usually acts: opposed to insertion.
The first existence or beginning of anything; the birth.
That from which anything primarily proceeds; the fountain; the spring; the cause; the occasion.
The point of attachment or end of a muscle which is fixed during contraction; -- in contradistinction to insertion .
the point where the axes intersect. See Note under Ordinate .
The beginning of something.
The source of a river, information, goods, etc.
The point at which the axes of a coordinate system intersect
The proximal end of attachment of a muscle to a bone that will not be moved by the action of that muscle.
an arbitrary point on the earth's surface, chosen as the zero for a system of coordinates.
ancestry
the place where something begins, where it springs into being
the point of intersection of coordinate axes; where the values of the coordinates are all zero
the descendants of one individual
an event that is a beginning; a first part or stage of subsequent events
properties attributable to your ancestry
the source of something's existence or from which it derives or is derived

original.explanation: Preceding all others in time; first.
Not derived from something else; fresh and unusual.
Showing a marked departure from previous practice; new: synonym : new .
Productive of new things or new ideas; inventive.
Being the source from which a copy, reproduction, or translation is made.
A first form or model from which others are made or developed.
An authentic work of art.
A work that has been composed firsthand or used to make a copy, reproduction, or translation.
A person with a creative or unusual personality.
A person who is appealingly odd or curious; a character.
The source from which something arises; an originator.

geology , noting those constituent minerals of an igneous rock which have crystallized from fusion during the period of consolidation: contrasted with secondary , which describes a mineral produced by alteration or decay.
original state in which man was created; the original edition of a book.
original genius.
original document; the original Greek text; the original painting.
original idea or plan; an original invention.
orig.
Origin; source; starting-point; first issue; beginning.
Hence Parentage; ancestry; pedigree; descent; derivation; extraction; birth.
That from which anything is derived; source of being or existence; cause; occasion.
A primary stock or type from which varieties have been developed: as, the dhole of India is supposed to have been the original of the dog.
Earliest condition; primal or primitive state; pristine condition, resources, etc.
First form; archetype; that which is copied, imitated, transcribed, or translated.
A work of art as first produced, and contradistinguished from a replica or duplicate made by the artist himself, and from a copy, mechanical reproduction, or imitation.
A writing, document, or literary production, as distinguished from a transcription, paraphrase, modernization, or translation; also, the language in which a work was first composed.
A person who produces a novel and unique impression; a person of marked individuality of character; an eccentric person; an oddity.
Pertaining to the origin or beginning; preceding all others; first in order; primitive; primary; pristine
Not copied, imitated, or translated; new; fresh; genuine
Having the power to suggest new thoughts or combinations of thought; inventive.
Before unused or unknown; new.
the first sin of Adam, as related to its consequences to his descendants of the human race; -- called also total depravity . See Calvinism .
Origin; commencement; source.
That which precedes all others of its class; archetype; first copy; hence, an original work of art, manuscript, text, and the like, as distinguished from a copy, translation, etc.
An original thinker or writer; an originator.
A person of marked eccentricity.
The natural or wild species from which a domesticated or cultivated variety has been derived.
First in a series or copies/versions
Newly created
Fresh, different
Pioneering
Having as its origin
An object or other creation (e.g. narrative work) from which all later copies and variations are derived
A person with a unique and interesting personality and/or creative talent
An eccentric
(of e.g. information) not secondhand or by way of something intermediary

originalist.explanation: One who has, or tends to have, original ideas.
One who aims to discover how the writers of a document intended it to be interpreted, and to interpret it in that way.

originality.explanation: The capacity to act or think independently.
The quality or state of being original.
The quality or state of being original.
Ability to create new and original ideas, works of art, theories, etc.; ability to express oneself in an original manner; creativity; -- of people.
The quality of being original or novel .
The capacity to think independently or be inventive .
the quality of being new and original (not derived from something else)
the ability to think and act independently

originally.explanation: In the original time, or in an original manner; primarily; from the beginning or origin; not by derivation, or imitation.
At first; at the origin; at the time of formation or costruction.
As it was in the beginning.
with reference to the origin or beginning

originalness.explanation: The quality or state of being original.
The quality of being original; originality.
The state or condition of being original .

originary.explanation: Of, pertaining to or causing the origin of something

originate.explanation: To bring into being; create or start.
To come into being; start: synonym : stem .
To take first existence; to have origin or beginning; to begin to exist or act.
To give an origin or beginning to; to cause to be; to bring into existence; to produce as new.
begin a trip at a certain point, as of a plane, train, bus, etc.
come into existence; take on form or shape

originated.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of originate .

originates.explanation: Third-person singular simple present indicative form of originate .

origination.explanation: The act of bringing into existence; creation; production; invention; causation.
The act of arising or beginning or coming into existence; derivation or commencement of being or existence; beginning; first stage or state.
Starting-point; point of derivation or departure.
Mode of production or bringing into being.
The act or process of bringing or coming into existence; first production.
Mode of production, or bringing into being.
The process of bringing something into existence .
The act of bringing something into existence.
the act of starting something for the first time; introducing something new
an event that is a beginning; a first part or stage of subsequent events

originative.explanation: Having power, or tending, to originate, or bring into existence; originating.
having the ability or power to create

originator.explanation: Someone who originates , creates or founds something.

originist.explanation: One who writes on the origin of things.

orignal.explanation: The American moose, Alces americana , one of whose former technical names was Cervus orignal.

orihyperbola.explanation: One of the two species of the oriconic.

orillion.explanation: In fortification , a rounding of earth, faced with a wall, raised on the shoulder of those bastions that have casemates, to cover the cannon in the retired flank, and prevent their being dismounted.

orillon.explanation: A semicircular projection made at the shoulder of a bastion for the purpose of covering the retired flank, -- found in old fortresses.
A semicircular projection made at the shoulder of a bastion for the purpose of covering the retired flank , found in old fortresses .

orinasal.explanation: a speech sound produced with both the oral and nasal passages open (as French nasal vowels)

oriole.explanation: Any of various Eurasian, African, or Australian birds of the family Oriolidae, the males of which often have black and bright yellow or green plumage.
Any of various similar birds of the family Icteridae found throughout the Americas, the males of which have primarily black and yellow or orange plumage.
A bird of Europe, Oriolus galbula , so called from its rich yellow color massed with black; also, any bird of the family Oriolidœ.
Any American hangnest of the family Icteridœ and subfamily lcterinœ , as the Baltimore oriole and orchard-oriole.

Any one of various species of Old World singing birds of the family Oriolidæ . They are usually conspicuously colored with yellow and black. The European or golden oriole ( Oriolus galbula , or Oriolus oriolus ) has a very musical flutelike note.
In America, any one of several species of the genus Icterus, belonging to the family Icteridæ . See Baltimore oriole , and Orchard oriole, under orchard .
Any of various colourful passerine birds , the New World orioles from the family Icteridae and the Old World orioles from the family Oriolidae .
mostly tropical songbird; the male is usually bright orange and black
American songbird; male is black and orange or yellow

oriskanian.explanation: Oriskany and Oriskany sandstone , under sandstone.

orismology.explanation: The science of defining or explaining technical terms; lexicography applied to scientific nomenclature and terminology.
That department of natural history which treats of technical terms; the science of defining technical terms.

orisphere.explanation: In Bolyaian geom. , a boundary surface; that surface which arises from the revolution of the boundary line about one of its axes. See limit-surface .

orkneyan.explanation: Of or pertaining to the Orkney islands.

orlage.explanation: A Middle English form of orloge, horology.

orle.explanation: In heraldry : A bearing, usually considered as a subordinary, like a border but not reaching the edge of the escutcheon, so that the field is seen outside of it as well as within.
A band of small objects taking the form of an orle: as, an orle of mullets. It is more commonly blazoned in orle (which see, below).
A circlet set upon a helmet, which supports the crest and is often used in modern heraldry without the helmet, furnishing the only support or base for the crest.
The rim of a shield; especially, the metal rim of a shield composed of wood, osier, or the like, and visible as a projecting rim on its face.
A bearing, in the form of a fillet, round the shield, within, but at some distance from, the border.
The wreath, or chaplet, surmounting or encircling the helmet of a knight and bearing the crest.
round the escutcheon, leaving the middle of the field vacant, or occupied by something else; -- said of bearings arranged on the shield in the form of an orle.
A bordure which runs around the outline of a shield without touching the edge.

orleanism.explanation: The political principles or ambitions of the Orleanists; adherence to the dynastic claims of the Orleanists.
the political philosophy of the Orleanists

orleans.explanation: A wool-and-cotton fabric for women's wear.
A cloth made of worsted and cotton, -- used for wearing apparel.
A variety of the plum. See under Plum .
a city on the Loire river in north central France; site of the siege of Orleans by the English (1428-1429)
a long siege of Orleans by the English was relieved by Joan of Arc in 1429

orlet.explanation: A boss, stud, or some similar protuberance.
Specifically, in architecture , a fillet under the ovolo of a capital. Also orle . When the fillet is at the top or bottom of a shaft, it is called a cincture.

orlo.explanation: A wind instrument of music in use among the Spaniards.

orlop.explanation: The lowest deck of a ship, especially a warship, having at least four decks.
Nautical , the deck below the berth-deck in a ship, where the cables were formerly coiled.
The lowest deck of a vessel, esp. of a ship of war, consisting of a platform laid over the beams in the hold, on which the cables are coiled.
The platform over the hold of a ship that makes up the fourth or lowest deck , hence in full called orlop deck , especially of a warship .

ormer.explanation: A European abalone (Haliotis tuberculata) found chiefly in the Channel Islands.

An ear-shell or sea-ear; an abalone or haliotid; a large marine shell of the family Haliotidæ : formerly a local English (Channel Islands) name of H. tuberculata , more fully called Guernsey ormer , or Guernsey ear-shell , which is abundant there and is used as food. See cut under abalone .
An abalone or sea-ear , particularly Haliotis tuberculata, common in the Channel Islands.
an abalone found near the Channel Islands

ormolu.explanation: Any of several copper and zinc or tin alloys resembling gold in appearance and used to ornament furniture, moldings, architectural details, and jewelry.
Gold-leaf prepared for gildingbronze, brass, or the like.
Hence Gilded bronze prepared for metal mountings of elegant furniture and similar decorative purposes.
Fine brass, sometimes colored and treated with lacquer to give it brilliancy: used for imitation jewelry, chandeliers, and similar fine metal-work.

A variety of brass made to resemble gold by the use of less zinc and more copper in its composition than ordinary brass contains. Its golden color is often heightened by means of lacquer of some sort, or by use of acids. Called also mosaic gold .
a varnish applied to metals, as brass, to give the appearance of gold.
Golden or gilded brass or bronze used for decorative purposes.
Made from golden or gilded brass or bronze.
To decorate with gilded ormolu articles.
brass that looks like gold; used to decorate furniture

ornament.explanation: Something that decorates or adorns; an embellishment.
A person considered as a source of pride, honor, or credit.
A note or group of notes that embellishes a melody.
To furnish with ornaments.
To be an ornament to.
Any accessory, adjunct, or trapping that serves for use or for both use and adornment, or such accessories, adjuncts, or trappings collectively; hence, equipment, vesture, dress, attire, etc.

Something added as an embellishment; that which embellishes or adorns; whatever lends or is intended to lend grace or beauty to that to which it is added or belongs, as a jewel, a rhetorical embellishment, etc.
An honorary distinction; a decoration; a mark of honor.
One who adds luster to one's sphere or surroundings: as, he is an ornament of his profession.
Embellishment or adornments collectively or in the abstract; adornment; ornamentation; decoration: as, a thing suitable for either use or ornament.
Outward appearance; mere display.
Synonyms Embellishment, adornment. See adorn .
ornament a building with sculpture or painting.
Adorn, Ornament, Decorate , etc. See adorn.
That which embellishes or adorns; that which adds grace or beauty; embellishment; decoration; adornment.
To adorn; to deck; to embellish; to beautify.
An element of decoration .
A Christmas tree decoration
A musical flourish that are unnecessary to the overall melodic or harmonic line, but serve to decorate or "ornament" that line.
To decorate .
To add to.
be an ornament to
make more attractive by adding ornament, colour, etc.
something used to beautify

ornamental.explanation: Of, relating to, or serving as an ornament or decoration.
Something that serves as ornamentation, especially a plant grown for its beauty.
Specifically, a plant or vine which is grown only for the beauty of its flowers or foliage.
ornamental appendages; neither useful nor ornamental.
An accessory; an embellishment; an adornment.
Serving to ornament; characterized by ornament; beautifying; embellishing.
Serving to ornament ; characterized by ornament; beautifying; embellishing.
any plant grown for its beauty or ornamental value
serving an esthetic rather than a useful purpose

ornamentalism.explanation: The character of being ornamental; also, a tendency to attach too much importance to ornament.
Any artistic or architectural style characterised by ornamentation .

ornamentalist.explanation: One who is versed in ornamentation; an artist who devotes himself especially to executing details of ornament.

ornamentality.explanation: The character of being ornamental; capacity of ornamenting; also, an ornament.

ornamentation.explanation: The act or process of decorating, adorning, or embellishing.
The state of being decorated, adorned, or embellished.
Something that decorates or adorns; an embellishment.
The act or process of ornamenting or of producing ornament.
Ornament in general; the whole mass of ornament applied to an object or used in combination: as, the ornamentation of a building.
In zoology , the colors, markings, hairs, spines, etc., on the surface of an animal.
The act or art of ornamenting, or the state of being ornamented.
The ornaments embellishing an object, collectively.
The act or process of decorating etc.
the act of adding extraneous decorations to something

ornamented.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of ornament .

ornamenter.explanation: One who ornaments or decorates; a decorator.

ornaments.explanation: Third-person singular simple present indicative form of ornament .

ornate.explanation: Elaborately, heavily, and often excessively ornamented.
Elaborate or showy, as in style.
Elaborately adorned or decorated; beautifully sumptuous.
Finely finished, as a style of composition.
marked by elaborate rhetoric and elaborated with decorative details

ornateness.explanation: The state of being ornate or adorned.
high-flown style; excessive use of verbal ornamentation
an ornate appearance; being elaborately (even excessively) decorated

ornation.explanation: The act of ornamenting; the fact of being ornamented or adorned; ornamentation.

ornature.explanation: The act of ornamenting; ornamentation; adornment; the process of rendering more polished or bringing to perfection; refinement.
That which is added or used for embellishment; ornament; decoration.

ornerier.explanation: comparative form of ornery : more ornery

orneriest.explanation: superlative form of ornery : most ornery .

ornery.explanation: Mean-spirited, disagreeable, and contrary in disposition; cantankerous.
Mischievous , prankish , teasing , disagreeable but in a good way.
having a difficult and contrary disposition

ornis.explanation: An avifauna; the fauna of a region in so far as it is composed of birds: as, the ornis of South America; a rich and varied ornis.

ornithic.explanation: Of, relating to, or characteristic of birds.

ornithichnite.explanation: In geology , one of the footmarks, at first supposed to be those of gigantic birds, or of bird-like reptiles (ornithosaurs), occurring abundantly in the Triassic sandstone of Connecticut and elsewhere. They are now believed to have been made by dinosaurian reptiles.
The footmark of a bird occurring in strata of stone.
The footmark of a bird occurring in strata of stone .

ornithine.explanation: An amino acid, C 5 H 12 N 2 O 2 , not found in proteins, formed by hydrolyzing arginine and important in the formation of urea.
An amino acid , 2,5-diaminopentanoic acid, that is not present in protein , but is an intermediate in the biosynthesis of urea .
an amino acid that does not occur in proteins but is important in the formation of urea

ornithischia.explanation: Dinosauria containing the Iguanodon and other species which have the bones of the pelvis arranged much like those of a bird. It is practically equivalent to the Ornithopoda of other writers. Contrasted with Saurischia.
extinct terrestrial reptiles having bird-like pelvises: armored dinosaurs (thyreophorans); boneheaded and horned dinosaurs (marginocephalians); duck-billed dinosaurs (euronithopods)

ornithischian.explanation: Any of various herbivorous dinosaurs of the order Ornithischia, having a pubic bone that points down and backward like that of modern birds, usually a horny beak or bill, and including the hadrosaurs and stegosaurs.
Ornithischia by Seeley; having the bones of the pelvis like those of a bird.
Any of a group of dinosaurs , of the order Ornithischia , that have hips characteristic of birds
herbivorous dinosaur with a pelvis like that of a bird

ornithobiography.explanation: Ornithological biography; the life-history of birds.

ornithodelph.explanation: Any member of the group Ornithodelphia , or egg-laying mammals: contrasted with didelph and monodelph.

ornithodelphia.explanation: Mammalia , represented by the monotremes or oviparous mammals, and conterminous with the order Monotremata : so called from the ornithic character of the reproductive or urogenital organs.

ornithodelphian.explanation: A member of the Ornithodelphia ; a monotreme or protothere.

ornithogalum.explanation: A genus of ornamental plants of the order Liliaceæ and the tribe Scilleæ , known by the spreading distinct perianth-segments and flattened filaments.

ornitholite.explanation: A fossil bird; the fossilized remains of a bird. The oldest fossil known to be that of a bird is Jurassic. See cut under Archæopteryx .
The fossil remains of a bird.
A stone of various colors bearing the figures of birds.
The fossil remains of a bird .
A stone of various colours bearing the figures of birds.

ornithologic.explanation: Of or relating to ornithology ; ornithological .

ornithologist.explanation: One who is versed in ornithology or makes a special study of birds.
One skilled in ornithology; a student of ornithology; one who describes birds.
A person who studies or practices ornithology

ornithology.explanation: The branch of zoology that deals with birds.
That branch of zoölogy which relates to birds; the scientific study or knowledge of birds.
That branch of zoölogy which treats of the natural history of birds and their classification.
A treatise or book on this science.
The branch of zoology that deals with the scientific study of birds .
the branch of zoology that studies birds

ornithomancy.explanation: Divination by means of birds; ornithoscopy; augury.
Divination by means of birds, their flight, etc.
Divination by means of birds , their flight , etc.

ornithomantist.explanation: One who divines by means of birds.

ornithomimid.explanation: lightly built medium-sized dinosaur having extremely long limbs and necks with small heads and big brains and large eyes

ornithon.explanation: A building in which birds are kept; an aviary.

ornithopappi.explanation: Archæopteryx , and conterminous with the subclass Saururæ : correlated with Pteropappi (or Odontotormæ ) and with Dromæopappi (or Odontolcæ ). See cut under Archæopteryx .
An extinct order of birds. It includes only the Archæopteryx.

ornithophilous.explanation: botany , bird-fertilized: applied to flowers in which the pollen is conveyed to the stigma and fertilization accomplished by the agency of birds.

ornithopod.explanation: Any of various herbivorous ornithischian dinosaurs of the group Ornithopoda, often having specialized dentition for grinding plant food, and including the hadrosaurs.
Ornithopoda : as, an ornithopod reptile. Also ornithopodous .
An ornithic dinosaur; a member of the Ornithopoda.
A type of bipedal , herbivorous , bird-hipped dinosaur from the Cretaceous period, found on all seven continents .

ornithopter.explanation: A machine shaped like an aircraft that is held aloft and propelled by wing movements.
A flying-machine in which an attempt is made to imitate the oscillatory movement of the wings of a bird.
An aircraft that generates lift through the flapping of its wings.
heavier-than-air craft that is propelled by the flapping of wings

ornithorhynchus.explanation: The typical and only genus of the family Ornithorhynchidæ.
[ lowercase ] An animal of this genus; a duckbill.
A genus of monotremes including the platypus ( Ornithorhyncus anatinus ). See Duck mole, under duck .
type genus of the family Ornithorhynchidae

ornithosauria.explanation: An order of extinct flying reptiles; -- called also Pterosauria .

ornithosaurian.explanation: Ornithosauria , or having their characters; pterosaurian; pterodactyl.
An ornithosaur; a member of the Ornithosauria , as a pterosaurian or pterodactyl.

ornithoscelida.explanation: Reptilia and Aves , the ornithic modification being especially well marked in the pelvic arch and limb, whence the name.
A group of extinct Reptilia, intermediate in structure (especially with regard to the pelvis) between reptiles and birds.

ornithoscelidan.explanation: Any of the Dinosauria , formerly known as Ornithoscelida.

ornithoscopist.explanation: One who studies or practises ornithoscopy; an augur.

ornithoscopy.explanation: Inspection or observation of birds with reference to divination; ornithomancy; augury.
Observation of birds and their habits.

ornithosis.explanation: The avian disease psittacosis when transmitted to humans
an atypical pneumonia caused by a rickettsia microorganism and transmitted to humans from infected birds

ornithotomist.explanation: One who practises the dissection of birds, or is versed in the anatomy of birds.
One who is skilled in ornithotomy.
One who is skilled in ornithotomy .

ornithotomy.explanation: The art or practice of dissecting birds; the anatomy of birds; the science of the anatomical structure of birds.
The anatomy or dissection of birds.
The anatomy or dissection of birds .

orobanchaceae.explanation: brown or yellow leafless herbs; sometimes placed in the order Scrophulariales

orobanchaceous.explanation: Orobanchaceæ , or broom-rape family of plants.

orobanche.explanation: A genus of parasitic plants, type of the order Orobanchaceæ , distinguished by its two-lipped flowers and unequally four-cleft calyx; the broom-rape.

orocentral.explanation: In crinoids, a name given by P. H. Carpenter to a plate supposed to be the correlative of the dorsocentral.

orodiagnosis.explanation: Diagnosis based upon the effect of the administration of a specific therapeutic serum, or upon the agglutination of specific pathogenic bacteria caused by the addition of blood-serum drawn from a patient suspected of the disease caused by such bacteria. See serum diagnosis .

orogen.explanation: The rock deformed by an orogeny

orogenesis.explanation: The process of mountain-making or upheaval: opposed to epirogeny .
The process of mountain formation by deformation of the Earth's crust. See also orogeny .

orogenic.explanation: Concerned with orogeny ; pertaining to the creation of mountains .

orogeny.explanation: The process of mountain formation, especially by a folding and faulting of the earth's crust.
the process of mountain building by the upward folding of the Earth 's crust .
the process of mountain formation (especially by the upward displacement of the earth's crust)

orograph.explanation: A surveyors' instrument designed for military use, to replace the engineers' chain and level. It records on paper an accurate profile of the country over which it is rolled.
A machine for use in making topographical maps. It is operated by being pushed across country, and not only records distances, like the perambulator, but also elevations.

orographic.explanation: Of or pertaining to the physical features of mountains , or to orography
Of or pertaining to the effects of mountains on weather

orography.explanation: The study of the physical geography of mountains and mountain ranges.
That division of physical geography or physiography which has to do with the relations and development of the mountain-chains of the regions described.
That branch of science which treats of mountains and mountain systems; orology.
the scientific study, or a physical description of mountains
the orographic features of a region

oroheliograph.explanation: In photography , a camera, devised by Noë, by which a panoramic view of the horizon may be taken. A vertical lens to which is attached a silvered mirror of peculiar shape is employed to focus the panoramic view from the entire horizon on a horizontal sensitive plate.

A camera for obtaining a circular panoramic view of the horizon. The photographic plate is placed horizontally with a vertical lens above. A mirror of peculiar shape reflects light from the entire horizon to the lens, by means of which it is focused upon the plate.

orohippus.explanation: A genus of fossil horses, of the family Equidæ , based upon remains from the Eocene of North America, having four toes on the fore feet and three on the hind feet. There are several species, all of very small size, only about as large as a fox.
[ lowercase ] A species of the above genus.
A genus of American Eocene mammals allied to the horse, but having four toes in front and three behind.

orohydrographic.explanation: physical geography , of or pertaining to relief (mountains, etc.) and drainage.

oroide.explanation: An alloy of copper, zinc, and tin, used in imitation gold jewelry.

An alloy of copper, tin, and other metals resembling gold in appearance, and used in the manufacture of cheap watchcases, jewelry, etc. The term is also used adjectively: as, oroide jewelry. Also called oreide .
An alloy, chiefly of copper and zinc or tin, resembling gold in color and brilliancy.
An alloy of copper and zinc or tin that has a gold color. It is used in making inexpensive jewelry .
alloy of copper and tin and zinc; used in imitation gold jewelry

orologist.explanation: A describer of mountains; one versed in orology.

orology.explanation: The science or description of mountains.
the study or science of mountains , in particular how they are formed

orometer.explanation: A form of aneroid barometer provided with two scales, one giving barometric pressures, the other the approximate elevation above the sea-level where the observation is made; a mountain-barometer.
An aneroid barometer having a second scale that gives the approximate elevation above sea level of the place where the observation is made.

orometry.explanation: In physical geography , the measurement of mountains, especially with regard to averages of altitudes.

oronasal.explanation: Relating to the mouth and nose.
Of or pertaining to the mouth and the nose

orontium.explanation: A genus of monocotyledonous plants of the order Araceæ , belonging to the suborder Pothoideæ and the tribe Symplocarpeæ , allied to the skunk-cabbage.
one species of aquatic plant: golden club

oropharyngeal.explanation: Of or pertaining to both the mouth and the pharynx
Of or pertaining to the oropharynx
of or relating to or located near the oropharynx

oropharynx.explanation: The part of the pharynx between the soft palate and the epiglottis.
The pharynx proper, directly continuous with the cavity of the mouth: distinguished from nasopharynx . See cut under mouth .
the oral part of the pharynx , reaching from the uvula to the level of the hyoid bone
cavity formed by the pharynx at the back of the mouth

orotund.explanation: elocution , characterized by strength, fullness, richness, and clearness; open, mellow, rich, and musical: applied to the voice or manner of utterance.

orphrey.explanation: A band of elaborate embroidery decorating the front of certain ecclesiastical vestments.

orpiment.explanation: Arsenic trisulfide, As 2 S 3 , a yellow mineral used as a pigment.

realgar; the red sulphide of arsenic.

perennial northern temperate plant with toothed leaves and heads of small purplish-white flowers

orpine.explanation: Any of various succulent plants of the family Crassulaceae, especially the Eurasian species Hylotelephium telephium syn. Sedum telephium, having clusters of reddish-purple flowers.

A succulent herbaceous plant, Scdum Telephium , common in gardens, native in the northern Old World, sometimes becoming wild in America.

perennial northern temperate plant with toothed leaves and heads of small purplish-white flowers

orrery.explanation: A mechanical model of the solar system or parts of it.

A plant from which orris-root is obtained. Also orrice .

Galloon and gimp used in upholstery.

A peculiar pattern in which gold lace or silver lace is worked; especially, one in which the edges are ornamented with conical figures placed at equal distances, with spots between them.

A morsel left at a meal; a fragment; refuse; -- commonly used in the plural.
A fragment ; a scrap of leftover food ; any remainder; a piece of refuse.
To turn away from with disgust; refuse .

ortalid.explanation: A member of the dipterous family Ortalidæ.

ortalidian.explanation: Any one of numerous small two-winged flies of the family Ortalidæ . The larvæ of many of these flies live in fruit; those of others produce galls on various plants.

orthis.explanation: A genus of protrematous brachiopods having a straight hinge, subquadrate valves with ribbed exterior, well-developed teeth and sockets, and no calcified brachidium. The genus has been greatly subdivided, and is now restricted to a comparatively few species which occur in the early Silurian rocks.
An extinct genus of Brachiopoda, abundant in the Paleozoic rocks.

: the intersection of the three lines that can be drawn flowing from the three corners of a triangle to a point along the opposite side where each line intersects that side at a 90 degree angle; in an acute triangle , it is inside the triangle; in an obtuse triangle , it is outside the triangle.

Sensitive to all colours except red

Common or potash feldspar, a silicate of aluminium and potassium, occurring in monoclinic crystals and also massive.
Common or potash feldspar crystallizing in the monoclinic system and having two cleavages at right angles to each other. See feldspar .

Potassium aluminum silicate , K Al Si 3 O 8, a common feldspar of igneous , plutonic , and metamorphic rocks . Orthoclase is the main feldspar of pegmatite occurrences, where it is most commonly flesh-colored. Orthoclase is used in the ceramic and glass industries and as a decorative gravel.
a white or colored monoclinic feldspar

orthoclastic.explanation: Breaking in directions at right angles to each other; -- said of the monoclinic feldspars.

The diagonal or lateral axis in a monoclinic crystal which is at right angles with the vertical axis.

orthodontia.explanation: That branch of dentistry which is concerned with the straightening of irregular teeth.

the branch of dentistry dealing with the prevention or correction of irregularities of the teeth

orthodox.explanation: Adhering to the accepted or traditional and established faith, especially in religion.

Of or relating to Orthodox Judaism.
Adhering to what is commonly accepted, customary, or traditional.
A member of an Eastern Orthodox church.
capitalized ] Of or pertaining to the Greek Church.

Orthodox, Evangelical. (See the definitions of these terms.) It is natural for all who care about their doctrinal beliefs to claim the titles that indicate correctness of belief. Hence orthodox is a part of the name of the Greek Church; to the Roman Catholic orthodox means faithful to the tenets of the Roman Church; in the doctrinal contests of America orthodox has generally meant Calvinistic, especially as opposed to Unitarianism and Universalism; in England it has as generally meant High-church, as opposed to Low-church or evangelical. Evangelical , meaning in harmony with the Gospel, has been claimed somewhat similarly and for a like reason, but has been especially applied to those who emphasize the doctrine of salvation by faith in Christ alone.
Sound in opinion or doctrine, especially in religious doctrine; hence, holding the Christian faith; believing the doctrines taught in the Scriptures; -- opposed to heretical and heterodox .
According or congruous with the doctrines of Scripture, the creed of a church, the decree of a council, or the like
Adhering to generally approved doctrine or practices; conventional. Opposed to unorthodox .

Of or pertaining to the churches of the Eastern Christian rite, especially the Greek Orthodox or Russian Orthodox churches, which do not recognize the supremacy of the Pope of Rome in matters of faith.
Adhering to whatever is traditional, customary or generally accepted.
adhering to what is commonly accepted

orthodoxly.explanation: In an orthodox manner; with soundness of faith.

The state or condition of being orthodox .

The beliefs and practices of the Eastern Orthodox Church.

The character of being orthodox; correctness of opinion; soundness of doctrine, especially in theology; specifically, in theology , conformity to the faith of the Church Catholic, as represented in its primitive ecumenical creeds, or to the Greek Church, called Orthodox .
Soundness of faith; a belief in the doctrines taught in the Scriptures, or in some established standard of faith; -- opposed to heterodoxy or to heresy .
Consonance to genuine Scriptural doctrines; -- said of moral doctrines and beliefs.
By extension, said of any generally accepted doctrine or belief; the orthodox practice or belief.
Conformity to established and accepted beliefs (usually of religions).
a belief or orientation agreeing with conventional standards
the quality of being orthodox (especially in religion)

orthodromic.explanation: Passing along neurological impulses in a normal (expected) direction.

orthodromics.explanation: The art of sailing in the are of a great circle, which is the shortest distance between two points on the earth's surface.
The art of sailing in a direct course, or on the arc of a great circle, which is the shortest distance between any two points on the surface of the globe; great-circle sailing; orthodromy.

orthodromy.explanation: The act or art of sailing on a great circle or in a straight course.
The act or art of sailing on a great circle.
The act or art of sailing on a great circle .

orthoepist.explanation: A specialist in orthoepy, especially one of a number of scholars of the 1500s and 1600s who proposed reforms of English spelling so that it would more systematically reflect pronunciation.

One who is skilled in orthoëpy.
someone who studies the way words are pronounced
a practitioner of orthoepy (especially one of the 17th or 18th century scholars who proposed to reform English spelling so it would reflect pronunciation more closely)

orthoepy.explanation: The study of the pronunciation of words.

orthogamy.explanation: In botany , direct or immediate fertilization, without the intervention of any mediate agency.

fertilization of the ovules of a plant by pollen from the same plant

orthogenesis.explanation: The hypothesis, now largely discredited, that the evolution of species is linear and driven largely by internal factors rather than by natural selection.

The direct or immediate origin of species, according to the opinion that it takes place by the ‘organic growth’ of one species into another in a definite line which is predetermined by the constitution which outward circumstances have given to each organism.
A series of similar mutations in successive generations , producing evolutionary change.

orthognathism.explanation: The orthognathous state or condition; the character of being orthognathous. Also orthognathy .
The quality or state of being orthognathous.

orthognathous.explanation: Having the front of the head, or the skull, nearly perpendicular, not retreating backwards above the jaws; -- opposed to prognathous . See Gnathic index, under gnathic .

orthogneiss.explanation: In petrography , a name given by Rosenbusch (1898) to gneiss derived from igneous rocks: opposed to paragneiss .
A gneiss derived from an igneous rock .

orthogonal.explanation: Relating to or composed of right angles.

Of or relating to a linear transformation that preserves the length of vectors.
Very different or unrelated; sharply divergent.
Of two objects, at right angles ; perpendicular to each other.
Statistically independent , with reference to variates.
Of two or more aspects of a problem, able to be treated separately.
Of two or more problems or subjects, independent of or irrelevant to each other.
having a set of mutually perpendicular axes; meeting at right angles
not pertinent to the matter under consideration

the relation of opposition between things at right angles

orthogonally.explanation: In an orthogonal manner; perpendicularly ; at right angles

One versed in orthography; one who spells words correctly.
One versed in orthography ; one who spells words correctly

orthographic.explanation: geometry , pertaining to right lines or angles.
Of or pertaining to orthography, or right spelling; also, correct in spelling
Of or pertaining to right lines or angles.

that projection which is made by drawing lines, from every point to be projected, perpendicular to the plane of projection. Such a projection of the sphere represents its circles as seen in perspective by an eye supposed to be placed at an infinite distance, the plane of projection passing through the center of the sphere perpendicularly to the line of sight.
Of a projection used in maps , architecture etc., in which the rays are parallel .

orthographically.explanation: according to the rules of proper spelling.

To spell correctly or according to usage .
To correct in regard to spelling.

orthographized.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of orthographize .

orthography.explanation: The art or study of correct spelling according to established usage.
The aspect of language study concerned with letters and their sequences in words.
The art or practice of writing words with the proper letters, according to accepted usage; the way in which words are customarily written; spelling: as, the orthography of a word.
In the following passage it is used erroneously, in burlesque:
The branch of language-study which treats of the nature and properties of letters, and of the art of writing words correctly.
In musical notation , the art or practice of representing tones and effects by the proper characters, according to accepted usage.
In draftsmanship , a geometrical representation of an elevation or section of a building; a sectional view of a fortress or the like.
The art or practice of writing words with the proper letters, according to standard usage; conventionally correct spelling; also, mode of spelling.
The part of grammar which treats of the letters, and of the art of spelling words correctly.

The method of spelling the words of a particular language; the system of symbols used for writing a language.
The branch of linguistics concerned with how languages are written.
The study of correct spelling according to established usage .
The aspect of language study concerned with letters and their sequences in words .
Spelling; the method of representing a language or the sounds of language by written symbols .

a method of representing the sounds of a language by written or printed symbols

orthologer.explanation: One who speaks correctly, or who treats of the correct use of words.

orthology.explanation: Correct speaking or the correct use of words .

orthometric.explanation: crystallography , pertaining to the three systems in which the axes are at right angles with each other. See crystallography .
Having the axes at right angles to one another; -- said of crystals or crystalline forms.
being corrected for the curvature of the Earth

orthometry.explanation: The art or practice of constructing verse correctly; the laws of correct versification.
The art or practice of constructing verses correctly; the laws of correct versification.
The art or practice of constructing verses correctly; the laws of correct poetry .

designating or relating to a form of treatment of mental disorders that seeks to restore biochemical balance in the body with large doses of vitamins and minerals

the branch of medical science concerned with disorders or deformities of the spine and joints

a specialist in correcting deformities of the skeletal system (especially in children)

The art of correct articulation ; voice training .

orthophoria.explanation: The tendency to parallelism of the visual axes.

orthophosphate.explanation: A salt of orthophosphoric acid. All phosphates of natural occurrence are orthophosphates.
Any salt or ester of orthophosphoric acid ; an ordinary phosphate

orthophosphoric.explanation: 3 PO 4 , produced by the interaction of phosphorus pentoxid or pentachlorid and water by boiling dilute nitric acid with phosphorus, or by treating the calcium phosphate of bone-earth with sulphuric acid.
Describing the ordinary form of phosphoric acid and its derivatives

orthophyric.explanation: petrography , belonging to or having the characters of orthophyre.

orthopinacoid.explanation: In crystallography , a plane of a monoclinic crystal which is parallel to the vertical axis and the lateral axis perpendicular to it. See pinacoid .
A name given to the two planes in the monoclinic system which are parallel to the vertical and orthodiagonal axes.
Either of the two planes in the monoclinic system which are parallel to the vertical and orthodiagonal axes .

orthoplasy.explanation: The definite and determinate changes in the history of the origin of species which have been attributed to organic selection.
The doctrine or opinion that the origin of species has been guided or directed by organic selection.

orthopnea.explanation: form of dyspnea in which the person can breathe comfortably only when standing or sitting erect; associated with asthma and emphysema and angina pectoris

orthopneic.explanation: Of or relating to orthopnea —a morbid condition in which respiration can be performed only in an erect posture.

orthopnoea.explanation: Shortness of breath when lying flat.

orthopoda.explanation: An extinct order of reptiles which stood erect on the hind legs, and resembled birds in the structure of the feet, pelvis, and other parts.

orthopraxis.explanation: The treatment of physical deformities by mechanical agency.

orthopraxy.explanation: The treatment of deformities in the human body by mechanical appliances.

Right belief combined with right practice , with the emphasis being on the latter, a term specially used in Latin American liberation theology, often in contrast with an orthodoxy seen as insufficiently interested in the practical and political content of faith.

orthoprism.explanation: In crystallography , a prism of a monoclinie crystal lying between the unit prism and the orthopinacoid.

orthopsychiatry.explanation: The psychiatric study, treatment, and prevention of emotional and behavioral problems, especially of those that arise during early development.
branch of psychiatry concerned with the prevention of mental illness , especially in the young

orthopter.explanation: An orthopterous insect; an orthopteran or orthopteron; any member of the Orthoptera.

A form of dirigible flying-machine or aërodrome, heavier than the air it displaces and using no gas-bag, in which the motor supplying the energy to lift and move the machine acts directly to produce motion in the desired direction.
Any insect of the order Orthoptera
heavier-than-air craft that is propelled by the flapping of wings

orthoptera.explanation: Any of very many four-winged insects , of the order Orthoptera , such as grasshoppers , crickets and locusts

orthopteran.explanation: Any of numerous insects of the order Orthoptera, having mouthparts that are adapted for chewing, usually two pairs of wings with thickened front wings and folded hind wings, and often enlarged hind legs. Orthopterans include the grasshoppers, crickets, and katydids.
An insect of the order Orthoptera.
Any of many insects of the order Orthoptera
any of various insects having leathery forewings and membranous hind wings and chewing mouthparts

orthopterist.explanation: One who studies or collects Orthoptera.

orthopteroidea.explanation: Orthoptera and occurs in the Paleozoic rocks.

orthopterologist.explanation: One who makes a specialty of the study of Orthoptera ; an orthopterist.

orthopterology.explanation: That branch of entomology which relates to Orthoptera.

orthopteron.explanation: any of various insects having leathery forewings and membranous hind wings and chewing mouthparts

orthopterous.explanation: Of or pertaining to the Orthoptera.
Of or pertaining to the Orthoptera .

orthoptic.explanation: of or relating to normal binocular vision

orthoptics.explanation: The evaluation and nonsurgical treatment of visual disorders caused by imbalance of the eye muscles, such as strabismus.
The study and treatment of muscular irregularities of the eye
treatment of defects of binocular vision (such as strabismus and amblyopia) by nonsurgical measures (especially by exercises to strengthen the eye muscles)

orthopyramid.explanation: In crystallography , a pyramid of a monoclinic crystal lying between the zone of unit pyramids and the orthodomes: it is strictly a hemipyramid, since the form includes only four planes.

orthopyroxene.explanation: Any of a number of varieties of pyroxene that crystallize in the orthorhombic system and contain no calcium and little or no aluminum.
Any pyroxene that forms orthorhombic crystals

orthorhombic.explanation: Of or relating to a crystalline structure of three mutually perpendicular axes of different length.

crystallography , noting the system of crystallography which is characterized by three unequal axes intersecting at right angles; belonging to this system: as, sulphur is orthorhombic. Also called trimetric . See crystallography .
Noting the system of crystallization which has three unequal axes at right angles to each other; trimetric. See crystallization .
having three unequal axes at right angles

orthoscope.explanation: An instrument for holding water around the eye, so that the refraction of the cornea is eliminated and the iris can be examined.
In craniometry , an instrument for drawing projections of skulls.
An instrument designed to show the condition of the superficial portions of the eye.
An instrument for examining the interior of an eye .
An instrument for drawing projections of a skull .
an ophthalmoscope with a layer of water to neutralize the refraction of the cornea

orthoscopic.explanation: Having normal vision; free from visual distortion.
Giving an undistorted image. Used of an optical instrument.
Giving an image in correct or normal proportions; giving a flat field of view.

orthosilicate.explanation: A salt of orthosilicic acid (H 4 SiO 4 ). Zinc orthosilicate (Zn 2 SiO 4 or 2ZnO. SiO 2 ) is the mineral willemite: it is often called a unisilicate , since it has an oxygen ratio of 1:1.
any salt or ester of orthosilicic acid , (M+)4 Si O 44− or Si(OR)4
any silicate mineral , such as garnet or olivine , in which the SiO4 tetrahedra do not share oxygen atoms with each other

orthosilicic.explanation: Designating the form of silicic acid having the normal or highest number of hydroxyl groups.
Of, relating to or derived from orthosilicic acid .

orthosis.explanation: The straightening, or the becoming straight, of a part.
A type of brace which either prevents , or assists movement of a limb or the spine

orthospermous.explanation: Having the seeds straight, as in the fruits of some umbelliferous plants; -- opposed to cœlospermous .
Having the seeds straight , as in the fruits of some umbelliferous plants .

orthostates.explanation: In Greek architecture , any upright support. The word usually denotes a rectangular masonry pier in distinction from a circular column.

orthostatic.explanation: Relating to or caused by standing upright.
Of, or relating to upright posture .
Of, or relating to an orthostat .
pertaining to an upright standing posture

orthostichy.explanation: In botany , a vertical rank; an arrangement of members at different heights on an axis so that their median planes coincide, as the vertical ranks of leaves on a stem.
A longitudinal rank, or row, of leaves along a stem.
A row of leaves along a stem

orthostyle.explanation: In architecture , a straight range of columns, as one of the sides of a peristyle: also used attributively.

orthosymmetry.explanation: In crystallography , right symmetry See symmetry , 6.

orthotic.explanation: An orthopedic appliance designed to straighten or support a body part.
An orthopedic appliance designed to support, straighten or improve the functioning of a body part; an orthosis

orthotics.explanation: The science that deals with the use of specialized mechanical devices to support or supplement weakened or abnormal joints or limbs.
The design, manufacture and installation of orthopedic appliances to support, straighten or improve the function of a body part

orthotoluidine.explanation: An amine base produced by the action of nascent hydrogen on orthonitrotoluene. Mixed with paratoluidine it occurs in commercial toluidine, which is a valuable material in the production, of some of the coal-tar dyes.

orthotomic.explanation: that circle which cuts three given circles at right angles.

orthotomous.explanation: Having two cleavages at right angles with one another.
Having two cleavages at right angles with one another.

orthotone.explanation: A word or form, usually enclitic or proclitic, when exceptionally retaining or acquiring an accent.
Retaining the accent; not enclitic; -- said of certain indefinite pronouns and adverbs when used interrogatively, which, when not so used, are ordinarilly enclitic.
Retaining the accent ; not enclitic ; said of certain indefinite pronouns and adverbs when used interrogatively , which, when not so used, are ordinarilly enclitic.

orthotonesis.explanation: Accentuation, under certain conditions, of a word or form usually or in other combinations unaccented; especially, accentuation of a proclitic or an enclitic: opposed to enclisis.

orthotonus.explanation: Tonic spasm in which the body is held straight.

orthotropal.explanation: Having the axis of an ovule or seed straight from the hilum and chalaza to the orifice or the micropyle; atropous.

orthotropic.explanation: Growing toward or away from a stimulus such as gravity, especially along a vertical axis. Used of a plant or plant part.
Of or relating to a bridge deck consisting of steel plates supported by ribs underneath.
botany , of or pertaining to or exhibiting orthotropism; growing vertically.
Having the longer axis vertical; -- said of erect stems.
growing vertically , either upwards or downwards
adjective for orthotropics, e.g., "An orthotropic appliance is one used in orthotropic (facial growth guidance) treatment."

orthotropism.explanation: In botany , vertical growth: a term proposed by Sachs for the habit of those organs of plants which grow more or less nearly vertically, either upward or downward, as iris-leaves, the majority of physiologically radial organs, etc. Compare plagiotropism .

orthotropous.explanation: Growing straight, so that the micropyle is at the end opposite the stalk. Used of an ovule.

botany , growing vertically or straight: applied specifically to an ovule in which the chalaza is at the evident base, and the orifice at the opposite extremity, the whole ovule being straight and symmetrical.
Growing straight and having the micropyle at the apex
(of a plant ovule) completely straight with the micropyle at the apex

orthotropy.explanation: In botany , the condition of being orthotropous: said of an ovule.

orthovanadate.explanation: The oxyanion of vanadium VO43- or any salt containing this ion

orthoxylene.explanation: That variety of xylene (C6H4(CH3)2) in which the two methyl groups are in the ortho position; a colorless, liquid, combustible hydrocarbon resembling benzene.
An aromatic hydrocarbon based on benzene with two methyl substituents bonded to adjacent carbon atoms in the aromatic ring (the ortho configuration).

orthros.explanation: In the Gr. Ch. , one of the canonical hours, corresponding to the Western lauds , but confounded by some Western writers, through a mistaken inference from the meaning of the word (‘dawn’), with matins. Orthros is a more elaborate office than lauds.
The divine office or service at dawn of the Orthodox Christian Church.

ortiga.explanation: In Spanish America, a name given to a number of stinging plants of various families, and also to those which resemble nettles in appearance. In Mexico the name is applied to the introduced ramie-fiber plant, Bœhmeria nivea ; in Porto Rico to species of Urera , including U. Caracasana and U. baccifera , which bear edible fruit; in the warm regions of Mexico to species of Cohiba , belonging to the Hydrophyllaceæ , especially to C. urens ; and in the State of Jalisco to Tournefortia hirsutissima , belonging to the Boraginaceæ. See cut at Bœhmeria.

ortol.explanation: A trade-name for a compound of o-aminophenol with hydroquinone. It is used as a developer in photography.

ortolan.explanation: A small brownish bunting (Emberiza hortulana) of Eurasia and Africa, eaten as a delicacy.
Any of several American birds, such as the bobolink and the sora.
The garden-bunting, Emberiza hortulana , a small granivorous conirostral bird of the family Fringillidæ , inhabiting parts of Europe and Africa, highly esteemed as a table delicacy.
Some small bird like or likened to or mistaken for the ortolan.
A European singing bird ( Emberiza hortulana ), about the size of the lark, with black wings. It is esteemed delicious food when fattened. Called also bunting .
In England, the wheatear ( Saxicola œnanthe ).
In America, the sora, or Carolina rail ( Porzana Carolina ). See sora .
A small European migratory bunting , Emberiza hortulana, once eaten whole as a delicacy .
Any of various similar birds, especially the bobolink , sora , or snow bunting .
brownish Old World bunting often eaten as a delicacy

ortygan.explanation: A button-quail or hemipod; a three-toed quaillike bird of the genus Turnix, Hemipodius , or Ortygis. See Turnicidæ and Hemipodii.
One of several species of East Indian birds of the genera Ortygis and Hemipodius. They resemble quails, but lack the hind toe. See turnix .
One of several species of East Indian birds of the genera Ortygis and Hemipodius, resembling quails .
any of several East Indian birds

ortyx.explanation: An American genus of Ortyginæ or Odontophorinæ , having a slight soft crest and variegated coloration; the colins or bob-whites.

orvietan.explanation: A medical composition or electuary believed to be an antidote or counter-poison.
A kind of antidote for poisons; a counter poison formerly in vogue.
A kind of antidote for poisons .

orycterope.explanation: An animal of the genus Orycteropus ; an aardvark. See cut under aardvark .
Same as oryctere (the aardvark, Orycteropus afer ).

oryctognosy.explanation: The description and systematic arrangement of minerals; mineralogy.

oryctologist.explanation: One who applies himself to or is versed in oryctology.

oryctology.explanation: The science of all that is dug up, whether organic or inorganic: formerly specifically applied to that part of geology which treats of fossils (paleontology).
An old name for mineralogy and geology.

oryx.explanation: Any of several African and Arabian antelopes of the genus Oryx, including the gemsbok, having black or brown markings on the face and long, straight or slightly curved horns.
An old name of some North African antelope, very likely the algazel: now definitely applied to several species of the genus Oryx.
[ capitalized ] A genus of orygine antelopes with long horns in both sexes, without suborbital or inguinal glands, and of large size, with thick neck, high withers, and bushy tail.
In ornithology : The red and black cardinal of the Cape of Good Hope, a kind of weaverbird, Emberiza orix of Linnæus, now Ploceus ( Pyromelana ) oryx.
Hence— [ capitalized ] A genus of weaver-birds.
[ capitalized ] In entomology , a genus of coleopterous insects of the family Scarabæidæ.
A genus of African antelopes which includes the gemsbok, the leucoryx, the bisa antelope ( Oryx beisa ), and the beatrix antelope ( Oryx beatrix ) of Arabia.
Any of several antelopes , of genus Oryx, native to Africa , the males and females of which have long, straight horns.
large African antelope with long straight nearly upright horns

oryzivorous.explanation: Having a diet rich in rice .

os.explanation: A bone.
A mouth or an opening.
In chem. , the symbol for osmium.

In geology , a Swedish term for certain elongated ridges of detrital material, generally considered to be of glacial origin, or in some not yet clearly explained way connected with the former presence of ice in the region where they occur.
Same as os extrascapulare .
An abbreviation of the Latin Ordo Sancti Augustini , Order of St. Augustine.
A mouth; a passage or entrance into any place: an anatomical term; specifically, the mouth of the womb.
An abbreviation of the Latin Ordo Sancti Benedicti , Order of St. Benedict.
Ordo Sancti Francisci , Order of St. Francis.
Bone; a bone.
A bone.
A mouth; an opening; an entrance.

One of the ridges of sand or gravel found in Sweden, etc., supposed by some to be of marine origin, but probably formed by subglacial waters. The osar are similar to the kames of Scotland and the eschars of Ireland. See eschar .
The chemical symbol for the element osmium .
An osar or esker .
Bone .
A mouth ; an opening .
In particular, either end of the cervix , internal (to the uterus ) or external (to the vagina ).
the left eye
a mouth or mouthlike opening
a hard brittle blue-grey or blue-black metallic element that is one of the platinum metals; the heaviest metal known
rigid connective tissue that makes up the skeleton of vertebrates
(computer science) software that controls the execution of computer programs and may provide various services

osages.explanation: A tribe of southern Sioux Indians, now living in the Indian Territory.

osamine.explanation: An amino compound formed by the action of alcoholic ammonia on the hexoses.

osar.explanation: os . A ridge of glacial debris of considerable longitudinal extent, showing rough water-stratification: same as eskar . Also called serpent-kame .

osazone.explanation: A yellow crystalline compound formed by the action of phenyl-hydrazine on a sugar in the presence of acetic acid.
any glycoside of an aldose or 2- ketose formed by reaction with excess of an aryl - hydrazine

oscar.explanation: A freshwater cichlid (Astronotus ocellatus) native to South America, having a spot at the base of the tail and often kept in home aquariums.

oscarella.explanation: The typical genus of the family

oscheitis.explanation: In pathology , inflammation of the scrotum.

oscheocele.explanation: A tumor of the scrotum; a scrotal hernia.

oscheoplasty.explanation: Restoration of defects in the scrotum by a surgical operation.

oscillancy.explanation: A swinging or oscillating state or condition; the state of swinging to and fro.
The state of oscillating; a seesaw kind of motion.

oscillaria.explanation: A genus of confervoid algæ, typical of the order Oscillariaceæ.
A genus of dark green, or purplish black, filamentous, fresh-water algæ, the threads of which have an automatic swaying or crawling motion. Called also Oscillatoria .

oscillate.explanation: To swing back and forth with a steady, uninterrupted rhythm.
To waver, as between conflicting opinions or courses of action; vacillate: synonym : swing .
To vary between alternate extremes, usually within a definable period of time.
To move backward and forward; to vibrate like a pendulum; to swing; to sway.
To vary or fluctuate between fixed limits; to act or move in a fickle or fluctuating manner; to change repeatedly, back and forth.
To swing back and forth , especially if with a regular rhythm .
To vacillate between conflicting opinions , etc.
To vary above and below a mean value .
be undecided about something; waver between conflicting positions or courses of action
move or swing from side to side regularly

oscillated.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of oscillate .

oscillates.explanation: Third-person singular simple present indicative form of oscillate .

oscillating.explanation: Moving in a repeated back-and-forth motion.

oscillation.explanation: In mathematics , the difference, for values of x in the interval ( x-h, x + h ;), between the lowest value that a real function fx of a real variable x cannot exceed and the highest value below which fx cannot fall.
The act of oscillating; a kind of vibration in which a body of sensible size swings backward and forward, not by virtue of its own elasticity merely; a swinging like that of a pendulum.
Variation or fluctuation, in general; wavering.
Same as vibration in the technical acoustical sense.
In music , same as beat , 7 , or beating , 5.
The act of oscillating; a swinging or moving backward and forward, like a pendulum; vibration.
Fluctuation; variation; change back and forth.
the act of oscillating or the state of being oscillated
a regular periodic fluctuation in value about some mean
(of a function) defined for each point in the domain of the function by , and describes the difference (possibly ∞) between the limit superior and limit inferior of the function near that point.
the process of oscillating between states
a single complete execution of a periodically repeated phenomenon
(physics) a regular periodic variation in value about a mean

oscillator.explanation: One who or that which oscillates.
In machinery , any oscillating machine or part of a machine, as the oscillating shuttle of a sewing-machine, or the mechanism by which a power-hammer is vibrated or tilted.
A motor in which the piston oscillates in the cylinder over a minute range at high speed. In combination with a dynamo it is used to obtain currents of high frequency.
In wireless telegraphy , that part of the transmitting apparatus which produces the electric waves or oscillations. See wireless telegraphy .
An instrument for measuring rigidity by the torsional oscillations of a weighted wire.
a tuned electronic circuit used to generate a continuous output waveform
A pattern that returns to its original state, in the same orientation and position , after a finite number of generations .
generator that produces sonic oscillations or alternating current

oscillatory.explanation: Moving, or characterized by motion, backward and forward like a pendulum; swinging; oscillating; vibratory.

oscillogram.explanation: The graph traced by an oscillograph.
An instantaneous oscilloscope trace or photograph.
The graphic trace or record made by an oscillograph.
An autographic record made by an oscillograph.
A record produced by an oscillograph or oscilloscope .
the recording produced by an oscillograph

oscillograph.explanation: A device that records oscillations, as of an electric current and voltage.
An instrument for recording alternating-current wave-forms and for the study of electrical oscillations.

An apparatus for recording graphically the motions of oscillation of any structure or element as to frequency and magnitude. The element may carry a pen or tracing-point, while a paper, borne on a fixed support, is moved before the tracer as the latter oscillates; or the principle may be reversed: used to record the effect of trains on bridges, or of moving machinery in buildings, or the effect of earth-movements on structures.
a device for making a record of the wave forms of fluctuating .

An apparatus for recording or indicating alternating-current wave forms or other electrical oscillations, especially of voltages or currents; it usually consists of a galvanometer with strong field, in which the mass of the moving part is very small and frequency of vibration very high.
An instrument for measuring alternating or varying electric current in terms of current and voltage .
a device for making a record of the wave forms of fluctuating voltages or currents

oscillographic.explanation: Of or pertaining to an oscillograph

oscillometer.explanation: A device for indicating and measuring the rolling of a ship. It consists of a motor-driven gyroscope mounted in gimbals, which maintains its absolute plane of rotation in space and, by the movement of pointers along scales attached to the frame, shows the angular departure of the vessel from the vertical.
An instrument for measuring the angle through which a ship rolls or pitches at sea.
Any of several devices that measure oscillations
A device that measures the roll (or pitch ) of a ship

oscillometric.explanation: Created by use of an oscillometer

oscilloscope.explanation: An electronic instrument that produces an instantaneous trace on the screen of a cathode-ray tube corresponding to oscillations of voltage and current.

An electronic measuring instrument which provides a visual representation of the time variation of electrical quantities, such as voltage or current. It may be used to measure the shape of a voltage pulse or the frequency of an oscillating voltage. It can also be used to measure properties of other physical variables, such as sound or light intensity, if they can be translated into electrical voltage or current.
An electronic measuring instrument that creates a visible two-dimensional graph , on a screen, of one or more continuously varying voltages or currents .
electronic equipment that provides visual images of varying electrical quantities

oscine.explanation: Any of various passerine birds of the suborder Passeri (formerly Oscines); a songbird.
Oscines : applied to those Passeres which are acromyodian and to their type of structure: as, an oscine bird; an oscine syrinx. Also oscinine, oscinian.
An oscine bird; a member of the Oscines.
A crystalline alkaloid, C 8 H 13 O 2 N, found in crude belladonine and also made from other alkaloids. It melts at 110° C. Also called pseudatropine, scopoline , and oxytropine.
passerine bird having specialized vocal apparatus
of or relating to the songbirds

oscines.explanation: Passeres , the Passeres acromyodi , a group of singing birds, characterized by having several distinct pairs of intrinsic muscles of the syrinx inserted into the ends of the upper bronchial half-rings, constituting a complex and effective musical apparatus.
Singing birds; a group of the Passeres, having numerous syringeal muscles, conferring musical ability.
two names for the suborder of typical songbirds

oscinian.explanation: Any one of numerous species of dipterous flies of the family Oscinidæ .
One of the Oscines, or singing birds.

oscinine.explanation: Of or pertaining to the Oscines.
Of or pertaining to the Oscines, or songbirds .

oscinis.explanation: A genus of dipterous insects, made the type of the family Oscinidæ , or placed in the family Chloropidæ.

oscitance.explanation: drowsiness and dullness manifested by yawning
an involuntary intake of breath through a wide open mouth; usually triggered by fatigue or boredom

oscitancy.explanation: The state of being drowsy or inattentive; dullness.
The act of gaping or yawning.
The act of gaping or yawning.
drowsiness , especially when marked by yawning
drowsiness and dullness manifested by yawning
an involuntary intake of breath through a wide open mouth; usually triggered by fatigue or boredom

oscitant.explanation: showing lack of attention or boredom

oscitation.explanation: The act of yawning or gaping from sleepiness.
The act of yawning or gaping.
The act of yawning or gaping .

oscnode.explanation: A node of a plane curve where one of the branches has a point of undulation.
A node of a plane curve where the two branches have a contact of: a higher order.

osculant.explanation: biology , touching or intermediate between two or more groups; inosculant; intergrading: said of genera, families, etc., which connect or link others together.
In mathematics , the invariant whose vanishing signifies that the quantics all vanish, and that there is a syzygetic relation between the tangential qualitics.
Adhering closely; embracing; -- applied to certain creeping animals, as caterpillars.

Intermediate in character, or on the border, between two genera, groups, families, etc., of animals or plants, and partaking somewhat of the characters of each, thus forming a connecting link; interosculant.
Kissing ; hence, touching or meeting ; clinging .
Adhering closely; applied to certain creeping animals, such as caterpillars .
Intermediate between two genera , groups , families , etc., and having some of the characteristics of each; interosculant .

oscular.explanation: mathematics , pertaining to a higher order of contact than the first.
Of or pertaining to the mouth .

osculate.explanation: To have three or more points coincident with.
geometry , to have a higher contact with; touch as closely as possible.
geometry , to have, as two loci, three or more coincident and successive points in common. See I., 2.
natural history , to share the characters of another group.
To touch closely, so as to have a common curvature at the point of contact. See Osculation , 2.
To kiss one another; to kiss.
To have characters in common with two genera or families, so as to form a connecting link between them; to interosculate. See Osculant .
To touch so as to have a common tangent at the point of contact.
have at least three points in common with
touch with the lips or press the lips (against someone's mouth or other body part) as an expression of love, greeting, etc.
be intermediate between two taxonomic groups

osculated.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of osculate .

osculates.explanation: Third-person singular simple present indicative form of osculate .

osculating.explanation: Having three or more points coincident with another

osculation.explanation: A contact, as between two curves or surfaces, at three or more common points.
In geometry , the contact between a curve and another which osculates it. See osculate .
A point of undulation where a right line has four or more coincident points in common with a curve.
The act of kissing; a kiss.
The contact of one curve with another, when the number of consecutive points of the latter through which the former passes suffices for the complete determination of the former curve.
A contact between curves or surfaces , at which point they have a common tangent
Determining whether a number is divisible by another by means of certain operations on its digits .
the act of caressing with the lips (or an instance thereof)
(mathematics) a contact of two curves (or two surfaces) at which they have a common tangent

osculatory.explanation: geometry , osculating. See osculate , v. t., 2.
In the Roman Catholic Church , a small tablet in former times kissed by priest and congregation in the mass: same as pax .
Of or pertaining to kissing; kissing.
Pertaining to, or having the properties of, an osculatrix; capable of osculation.
See Osculating circle of a curve, under Circle .
a plane which passes through three successive points of the curve.
(to a line of double curvature), a sphere passing through four consecutive points of the curve.

A religious tablet, usually carrying a representation of Christ or the Virgin Mary, which is kissed by the priest during the Mass ("kiss of peace"); it is then passed to others at the mass who also kiss it.

osculatrix.explanation: The envelop of the osculating planes of a non-plane curve.

A curve whose contact with a given curve, at a given point, is of a higher order (or involves the equality of a greater number of successive differential coefficients of the ordinates of the curves taken at that point) than that of any other curve of the same kind.

A curve whose contact with a given curve at a given point is of a higher order (or involves the equality of a greater number of successive differential coefficients of the ordinates of the curves taken at that point) than that of any other curve of the same kind.

oscule.explanation: One of the excurrent apertures of sponges.

osculum.explanation: A large opening in a sponge, through which water is expelled.
In sponges, a mouth or principal exhalent aperture; one of the orifices by which water is expelled. See cuts under Porifera and Spongilla.
One of the suckers, bothria, or fossettes on the head of a tapeworm, by means of which the animal attaches itself to its host.
A pax: apparently an erroneous abbreviation for osculatorium.
the main opening in a sponge from which water is expelled .

osella.explanation: A medal struck annually by the doges of Venice, from 1521 till the end of the republic, for presentation to various persons in the republic.

oshac.explanation: A plant of the parsley family, Dorema Ammoniacum , which yields gum ammoniac. See ammoniac and Dorema.

osiandrian.explanation: A follower of Andreas Osiander, a Lutheran theologian (1498-1552), who held that justification by faith involved the imparting to the believer of the essential righteousness of Christ.

osier.explanation: Any of several willows having long rodlike twigs used in basketry, especially Salix viminalis, native to Eurasia.
A twig of one of these shrubs or trees.
Any of several North American dogwoods, especially the red osier.
Either the round-leaved dogwood, Cornus circinata , or the alternate-leaved dogwood, C. alternifolia , the twigs of which are green.
Leucothoe racemosa , an ornamental shrub of the eastern United States with racemes of waxy white flowers borne on the under side of recurved racemes.
One of various species of willow ( Salix ) whose tough flexible branches are employed for wickerwork, withes, etc.

A kind of willow ( Salix viminalis ) growing in wet places in Europe and Asia, and introduced into North America. It is considered the best of the willows for basket work. The name is sometimes given to any kind of willow.
One of the long, pliable twigs of this plant, or of other similar plants.
a place where willows are grown for basket making.
An American shrub ( Cornus stolonifera ) which has slender red branches; -- also called osier cornel .
Made of osiers; composed of, or containing, osiers.

A kind of willow , Salix viminalis, growing in wet places in Europe and Asia, and introduced into North America. It is considered the best of the willows for basket work. The name is sometimes given to any kind of willow.
One of the long, pliable twigs of this plant, or of other similar plants.
flexible twig of a willow tree
any of various willows having pliable twigs used in basketry and furniture
