osiery.explanation: A place where osiers are grown.

osmanthus.explanation: A genus of shrubs and trees of the gamopetalous order Oleaceæ and the tribe Oleineæ , known by the imbricated corolla-lobes, and thick, hard, woody endocarp.
Any of several widely distributed evergreen flowering plants , of the genus Osmanthus .
widely distributed genus of evergreen shrubs or trees of southern United States and Middle East and China and Japan

osmate.explanation: In chem. , a salt of osmic acid.

osmaterium.explanation: One of a pair of scent organs which the larvæ of certain butterflies emit from the first body segment, either above or below.

osmatic.explanation: Having or characterized by a well-developed sense of smell.

osmazome.explanation: That part of the aqueous extract of meat which is soluble in alcohol and contains the flavoring principle.
A substance formerly supposed to give to soup and broth their characteristic odor, and probably consisting of one or several of the class of nitrogenous substances which are called extractives .
A substance formerly supposed to impart the characteristic meaty smell and taste to certain dishes.

osmerus.explanation: A genus of fishes (smelts) of the family Argentinidæ , found on the northern coasts of America and Europe.

osmeterium.explanation: An eversible organ behind the head of certain caterpillars, containing strong-smelling chemicals that deter predators.
In entomology , any organ devoted to the production of a scent or odor; specifically, a forked process found on the first segment behind the head of certain butterfly-larvæ.
One of a pair of scent organs in the larvae of certain swallowtail butterflies .

osmiamic.explanation: 8 O 3 , and it probably contains the nitroso-group.
Of, pertaining to, or designating, a nitrogenous acid of osmium, H2N2Os2O5, forming a well-known series of yellow salts.

osmic.explanation: chem. , pertaining to or obtained from osmium: as, osmic acid (H 2 OsO 4 ).
Pertaining to, derived from, or containing, osmium; specifically, designating those compounds in which it has a valence higher than in other lower compounds.
Osmic acid proper, an acid analogous to sulphuric acid, not known in the free state, but forming a well-known and stable series of salts (osmates), which were formerly improperly called osmites .

a white volatile crystalline substance, OsO4, the most stable and characteristic of the compounds of osmium. It has a burning taste, and gives off a vapor, which is a powerful irritant poison, violently attacking the eyes, and emitting a strong chlorinelike odor. Formerly improperly called osmic acid .
Pertaining to, derived from, or containing, osmium ; specifically, designating those compounds in which it has a higher valence .

osmics.explanation: The science that deals with smells and the olfactory sense.

osmidrosis.explanation: The secretion of strongly smelling perspiration. Also called bromidrosis .

osmious.explanation: Denoting those compounds of osmium in which the element has a valence relatively lower than in the osmic compounds.
(Chem.), an acid derived from osmium, analogous to sulphurous acid, and forming unstable salts. It is a brown amorphous substance.
Denoting those compounds of osmium in which the element has a valence relatively lower than in the osmic compounds.

osmiridium.explanation: A mineral that is a natural alloy of osmium and iridium with small inclusions of platinum, rhodium, and other metals, used in needles and wearing points.
A hard, corrosion-resistant alloy or osmium and iridium used in pen nibs
a hard and corrosion resistant mineral that is a natural alloy of osmium and iridium (usually containing small amounts of rhodium and platinum); used in needles and pen nibs etc.

osmite.explanation: In chem. , a name formerly given to what is now known as an osmate or osmiate ; a salt of osmic acid.

osmium.explanation: A bluish-white, hard, brittle and extremely dense metallic element, found in small amounts in osmiridium, nickel, and platinum ores. It is used as a platinum hardener and in making pen points, phonograph needles, instrument pivots, and other wear-resistant items. Atomic number 76; atomic weight 190.2; melting point 3,033°C; boiling point 5,012°C; specific gravity 22.587; valence 2, 3, 4, 6, 8. cross-reference : Periodic Table .
Chemical symbol, Os; atomic weight, 191. One of the metals of the platina group.
This, the most refractory of the metals, has, though with difficulty, been completely fused into globules by means of the electric furnace.

A rare metallic element of the platinum group with atomic number 76. It is found native as an alloy in platinum ore, and in iridosmine. It is a hard, infusible, bluish or grayish white metal, and the heaviest substance known. Its tetroxide is used in histological experiments to stain tissues. Symbol os . Atomic weight 190.2. Specific gravity 22.477.
a heavy metallic chemical element (symbol Os) with an atomic number of 76
a hard brittle blue-grey or blue-black metallic element that is one of the platinum metals; the heaviest metal known

osmogene.explanation: An apparatus to carry out the process of osmosis.

An apparatus, consisting of a number of cells whose sides are of parchment paper, for conducting the process of osmosis. It is used especially in sugar refining to remove potassium salts from the molasses.

osmolality.explanation: The molality of an ideal solution that would exert the same osmotic pressure as the solution being considered

osmolarity.explanation: The osmotic concentration of a solution , normally expressed as osmoles of solute per litre of solution .

osmology.explanation: The study of odors and of their appreciation by the senses.
The study of the phenomenon of osmosis.

osmometer.explanation: A device for measuring osmotic pressure.
An instrument or apparatus for measuring the velocity of the osmotic force.
An instrument for measuring the acuteness of the sense of smell.
An instrument for measuring the amount of osmotic action in different liquids.
Any of various devices used to measure osmotic pressure

osmometry.explanation: The act or process of measuring osmotic force by means of an osmometer.
The measuring of the intensity of odors.
The measuring of the acuteness of the sense of smell.
The study of osmosis by means of the osmometer.

osmophobia.explanation: A heightened dislike or sensitivity to smells

osmoregulation.explanation: Maintenance of an optimal, constant osmotic pressure in the body of a living organism.
The homeostatic regulation of osmotic pressure in the body in order to maintain a constant water content

osmose.explanation: To diffuse or cause to diffuse by osmosis.

The impulse or tendency of fluids to pass through porous partitions and mix or become diffused through each other; the phenomena attending the passage of fluids, whether liquids or gases, through a porous septum.
The tendency in fluids to mix, or become equably diffused, when in contact. Same as osmosis , which see.
the transportation of a liquid through a porous septum by the action of an electric current.
To cause to diffuse by osmosis.

osmosed.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of osmose .

osmoses.explanation: Third-person singular simple present indicative form of osmose .

osmosis.explanation: Diffusion of fluid through a semipermeable membrane from a solution with a low solute concentration to a solution with a higher solute concentration until there is an equal solute concentration on both sides of the membrane.
The tendency of fluids to diffuse in such a manner.
A gradual, often unconscious process of assimilation or absorption.
The diffusion of fluids through membranes. See osmose .

The tendency in fluids to mix, or become equably diffused, when in contact. It was first observed between fluids of differing densities, and as taking place through a membrane or an intervening porous structure. An older term for the phenomenon was Osmose .
The action produced by this tendency.
The net movement of solvent molecules from a region of high solvent potential to a region of lower solvent potential through a partially permeable membrane
Picking up knowledge accidentally, without actually seeking that particular knowledge.
(biology, chemistry) diffusion of molecules through a semipermeable membrane from a place of higher concentration to a place of lower concentration until the concentration on both sides is equal

osmotaxis.explanation: The movement of cells or of organisms in relation to the density or osmotic value of the liquid they are in, and not in relation to its chemical nature.

osmotic.explanation: Pertaining to, or having the property of, osmosis.

osmous.explanation: Relating to or containing osmium in a compound with a valence lower than that in a comparable osmic compound.

osmund.explanation: A bloom of iron produced in an osmund furnace. See furnace .
A fern of the genus Osmunda. Also called water-fern, St. Christopher's herb , and herb-christopher.

A fern of the genus Osmunda, or flowering fern. The most remarkable species is the osmund royal , or royal fern ( Osmunda regalis ), which grows in wet or boggy places, and has large bipinnate fronds, often with a panicle of capsules at the top. The rootstock contains much starch, and has been used in stiffening linen.
any fern of the genus Osmunda: large ferns with creeping rhizomes; naked sporangia are on modified fronds that resemble flower clusters

osmunda.explanation: Any of several ferns of the genus Osmunda, such as the cinnamon fern, having bipinnately compound sterile fronds and separate spore-bearing fertile fronds. The fibrous roots are used as a potting medium.
A genus of handsome ferns, widely distributed throughout north temperate regions, and typical of the order Osmundaceæ.

osmundaceae.explanation: large family of ferns widely distributed in temperate and tropical areas

osmundaceous.explanation: botany , pertaining to or resembling the genus Osmunda or the order Osmundaceæ.

osmundine.explanation: The roots of ferns of the genus Osmunda, used in growing orchids etc.

osnaburg.explanation: A heavy, coarse cotton fabric, used for grain sacks, upholstery, and draperies.
A coarse cloth made of flax and tow.
A species of coarse linen, originally made in Osnaburg, Germany.
A plain, coarse textile fabric made from flax , tow or jute yarns .

osoberry.explanation: Oemleria cerasiformis, the Indian plum, a shrub native to the Pacific coast and ranges of North America .
The small, blue-black, drupe -like fruit of this plant.

osone.explanation: ,( chemistry ) any 1,2- ketoaldose , especially one derived by hydrolysis of an osazone

osotriazole.explanation: any 1,2,3- triazole formed by oxidation of an osazone

osphradium.explanation: The so-called olfactory organ of mollusks; a patch or tract of specially modified epithelium of the body-wall at the base of the ctenidium, supplied with a special nerve, supposed to smell, taste, or otherwise test the water which the animal breathes, thus functioning as a special sense-organ.
The olfactory organ of some Mollusca. It is connected with the organ of respiration.
The olfactory organ in certain molluscs , linked with the respiration organ. Its main function is to test incoming water for silt and other possible food particles .

osphresiology.explanation: The science or study of the sense of smell; also, a treatise on smelling and odors.

osprey.explanation: A fish-eating raptor (Pandion haliaetus) found almost worldwide, having plumage that is dark on the back and mostly white below.
A plume formerly used to trim women's hats.
A diurnal bird of prey of the family Falconidæ and the genus Pandion ; a fish-hawk.
A bird of prey ( Pandion haliaetus ) that feeds on fish and has white underparts and long, narrow wings each ending in four finger -like extensions .
large harmless hawk found worldwide that feeds on fish and builds a bulky nest often occupied for years

ossarium.explanation: An urn or other receptacle for the bones or ashes of the dead; an ossuary.

ossature.explanation: In architecture , the framework or skeleton of a building or part of a building, as the ribs of a groined vault, the timber or metal frame of a roof, or the iron frame supporting a stained-glass window.
A skeletal framework ; an underlying structure.
Any supporting framework under a vault, roof etc.

ossein.explanation: The organic basis of bone; bone from which the earthy salts have been removed by macerating in acid. Also osteine and bone-cartilage.

The organic basis of bone tissue; the residue after removal of the mineral matters from bone by dilute acid; in embryonic tissue, the substance in which the mineral salts are deposited to form bone; bone collagen; -- called also ostein . Chemically it is the same as collagen.

osselet.explanation: A hard substance growing on the inside of a horse's knee.
The cuttlebone, pen, or calamary of some squids or cuttlefish.
The internal bone, or shell, of a cuttlefish.
The internal bone , or shell , of a cuttlefish .

osseoaponeurotic.explanation: Pertaining to an object composed of bone and aponeurosis ; at the end of a muscle where it becomes tendon.

osseofibrous.explanation: histology , combining the characters of fibrous connective tissue and bone, or representing a transition between these two kinds of tissue.

osseomucoid.explanation: A mucoid which is peculiar to osseous tissue.

osseous.explanation: Composed of, containing, or resembling bone; bony.
osseous tissue. See bone and ossein.
Composed of bone; resembling bone; capable of forming bone; bony; ossific.
Of, relating to, or made of bone ; bony .

osseter.explanation: A large European sturgeon, Acipenser güldenstädti. See Acipenser .

ossia.explanation: Or else. Used as a direction to the performer to designate an alternate section or passage.
music , a direction indicating an alternative form of a passage, either one that is easier or one suited to a different variety of instrument. Also oppure and ovvero.
In a musical score an ossia is an alternative version of the music, often just a few measures long.

ossianism.explanation: The literary characteristics of Ossianie poetry; partiality for the Ossianie style.

ossicle.explanation: A small bone, especially one of the three bones of the middle ear.
A small hard nodule of chitin or some substance resembling bone.
One of numerous small calcareous structures forming the skeleton of certain echinoderms, as the starfishes.
A small bone (or bony structure), especially one of the three of the middle ear .
a small bone; especially one in the middle ear

ossicular.explanation: Of or pertaining to an ossicle.
pertaining to the ossicles in the middle ear

ossiculate.explanation: Of or pertaining to an ossicle.
pertaining to the ossicles in the middle ear

ossiculectomy.explanation: Excision of the ossicles of the ear.

ossiculotomy.explanation: Section through one or more of the ossicles of the middle ear.

ossiculum.explanation: a small bone; especially one in the middle ear

ossific.explanation: Capable of producing bone; having the power to change cartilage or other tissue into bone.
Capable of producing bone ; having the power to change cartilage or other tissue into bone.

ossification.explanation: The natural process of bone formation.
The hardening or calcification of soft tissue into a bonelike material.
A mass or deposit of such material.
The process of becoming set in a rigidly conventional pattern, as of behavior, habits, or beliefs.
The formation of bone; the act or process of changing or of being changed into bone, or into a bony substance; the change so effected: as, the ossification of cartilage. See osteogenesis .
That which is ossified, or the result of ossification; bone in general.
The state or quality of being ossified.
The formation of bone; the process, in the growth of an animal, by which inorganic material (mainly lime salts) is deposited in cartilage or membrane, forming bony tissue; ostosis.
The state of being changed into a bony substance; also, a mass or point of ossified tissue.
the normal process by which bone is formed
the calcification of tissue into a bonelike mass; the mass so formed
the process of becoming set in one's ways or beliefs; rigid conventionality
the developmental process of bone formation
the calcification of soft tissue into a bonelike material
the process of becoming rigidly fixed in a conventional pattern of thought or behavior

ossified.explanation: Changed to bone or something resembling bone; hardened by deposits of mineral matter of any kind; -- said of tissues.
Of ideas or attitudes , inflexible , old-fashioned .
Simple past tense and past participle of ossify .
set in a rigidly conventional pattern of behavior, habits, or beliefs

ossifies.explanation: Third-person singular simple present indicative form of ossify .

ossifrage.explanation: The young of the sea eagle or bald eagle.
The young of the sea eagle or bald eagle .

ossify.explanation: To change into bone; become bony.
To become set in a rigidly conventional pattern.
To convert (a membrane or cartilage, for example) into bone.
To mold into a rigidly conventional pattern.
To form into bone; to change from a soft animal substance into bone, as by the deposition of lime salts.
To become bone; to change from a soft tissue to a hard bony tissue.
To transform (or cause to transform) from a softer animal substance into bone ; particularly the processes of growth in humans and animals.
To become (or cause to become) inflexible and rigid in habits or opinions .
To grow (or cause to grow) formulaic and permanent .
make rigid and set into a conventional pattern
cause to become hard and bony

ossivorous.explanation: Bone eating, of an animal given to chewing on bones.

ossuary.explanation: A container or receptacle, such as an urn or a vault, for holding the bones of the dead.
A place where the bones of the dead are deposited; a charnel-house.
A vase, casket, or other vessel for the reception of the bones or calcined remains of the dead.
A bone-cave, or deposit formed largely of bones, belonging to late geological times.
A place where the bones of the dead are deposited; a charnel house.
A container or receptacle, such as an urn or vault, for holding the bones of the dead .
any receptacle for the burial of human bones

ostariophysi.explanation: in some classifications considered a superorder comprising the Cypriniformes and the Siluriformes

osteal.explanation: Relating to bone or to the skeleton.
relating to bone or to the skeleton

osteectomy.explanation: The surgical removal of a bone .

osteitis.explanation: Inflammation of bone or bony tissue.
inflammation of a bone as a consequence of infection or trauma or degeneration

ostensibility.explanation: The quality or state of being ostensible.
The quality or state of being ostensible.

ostensible.explanation: Represented or appearing as such; ostensive.
ostensible reason or motive for doing something.
Capable of being shown; proper or intended to be shown.
Outwardly appearing to be; shown to be; exhibited; apparent; evident.
Declared; avowed; professed; pretended; -- often used as opposed to real or actual .
alleged , having an intention that is possibly but not obviously true
appearing as such but not necessarily so
represented or appearing as such; pretended

ostensibly.explanation: In an ostensible manner; avowedly; professedly; apparently.

ostension.explanation: Eccles. , the exposition of the sacrament or host. See exposition .
The showing of the sacrament on the altar in order that it may receive the adoration of the communicants.
The act of ostending , of presenting an ostensive definition
An act of showing or demonstrating
The showing of the sacrament on the altar in order that it may receive the adoration of the communicants.

ostensive.explanation: a direct or positive demonstration, as opposed to the apagogical or indirect method.
Apparently true, but not necessarily; ostensible
represented or appearing as such; pretended

ostensorium.explanation: (Roman Catholic Church) a vessel (usually of gold or silver) in which the consecrated Host is exposed for adoration

ostent.explanation: The act of showing, or an act which shows; hence, manifestation; indication; display; profession.
That which is pointed out as strange or alarming; a sign; portent; wonder; prodigy.

ostentate.explanation: To make an ambitious display of; to show or exhibit boastingly.
To make an ambitious display of; to show or exhibit boastingly .
display proudly; act ostentatiously or pretentiously

ostentation.explanation: Pretentious display meant to impress others; pretentious showiness.
The act or an instance of showing; an exhibition.
A sight or spectacle; show; ceremony.
Ambitious display; pretentious parade; vain show; display intended to excite admiration or applause.

Synonyms Show, Display, Parade, Ostentation , flourish, dash. Show is the most general word for the purposed exhibition of that which might have been kept private; as such, it includes the others. Ostentation is always bad; the others may be good in certain relations. Parade and display are more suggestive of the simple act, ostentation of the spirit: as, to make a parade of one's learning; it was ostentation that led the Pharisees to make a parade or display of their charities and prayers. Parade is a matter of vanity; ostentation , of vanity, pride, or ambition.
The act of ostentating or of making an ambitious display; unnecessary show; pretentious parade; -- usually in a detractive sense.
Ambitious display; vain show; display intended to excite admiration or applause.
pretentious or showy or vulgar display
lack of elegance as a consequence of being pompous and puffed up with vanity

ostentatious.explanation: Characterized by or given to ostentation. synonym : showy .
Fond of, or evincing, ostentation; unduly conspicuous; pretentious; boastful.
intended to attract notice and impress others

ostentatiously.explanation: In an ostentatious manner; extravagantly or flamboyantly .
with ostentation; in an ostentatious manner

ostentatiousness.explanation: The state or quality of being ostentatious; vain display; boastfulness; vanity; ostentation.
The property or characteristic of being ostentatious .
lack of elegance as a consequence of being pompous and puffed up with vanity

osteoarthritis.explanation: A form of arthritis, occurring mainly in older persons, that is characterized by chronic degeneration of the cartilage of the joints.
Inflammation of a joint in which the bones are involved as well as the soft tissues: sometimes employed as synonymous with arthritis deformans.
A form of arthritis , affecting mainly older people, caused by chronic degeneration of the cartilage and synovial membrane of the joints, leading to pain and stiffness.
chronic breakdown of cartilage in the joints; the most common form of arthritis occurring usually after middle age

osteoarthropathy.explanation: A disease of a joint in which the bones as well as the soft parts are affected.
Any disease of a joint between bones

osteoarthrotomy.explanation: Division through the articular end of a bone within the capsule of the joint.

osteoblast.explanation: A cell from which bone develops; a bone-forming cell.
A cell concerned in the formation of bone.
One of the protoplasmic cells which occur in the osteogenetic layer of the periosteum, and from or around which the matrix of the bone is developed; an osteoplast.
A mononucleate cell from which bone develops.
a cell from which bone develops

osteoblastic.explanation: Of or pertaining to an osteoblast

osteoblastoma.explanation: an uncommon osteoid tissue-forming primary neoplasm of the bone
benign tumor of bone and fibrous tissue; occurs in the vertebrae or femur or tibia or arm bones (especially in young adults)

osteocartilaginous.explanation: Relating to or composed of bone and cartilage.

osteochondritis.explanation: Inflammation of cartilage and adjacent bone.

osteochondroma.explanation: A tumor composed of intermingled bony and cartilaginous tissue.
A benign tumor consisting of bone or cartilage
benign tumor containing both bone and cartilage; usually occurs near the end of a long bone

osteochondrosarcoma.explanation: A tumor formed of sarcomatous masses inclosed in a framework of bone and cartilage.

osteoclasis.explanation: The process of dissolution and resorption of bony tissue.
Surgical fracture of a bone, performed to correct a deformity.
The dissolution or resorption of osseous tissue; the destruction of bone.
In surgery , the fracturing, especially the refracturing, of a bone to remedy deformity.
The operation of breaking a bone in order to correct deformity.
The surgical fracture of a bone in order to correct a deformity
treatment of a skeletal deformity by intentionally fracturing a bone

osteoclast.explanation: A large multinucleate cell found in growing bone that resorbs bony tissue, as in the formation of canals and cavities.
An instrument used in surgical osteoclasis.
In surgery , an apparatus for fracturing bones in order to correct deformities.
A large multinucleated cell supposed to be concerned in the absorption of bone-tissue. Originally osteoklast ( Kölliker ). Also called giant cell, myeloplax , and myeloplaque.
Same as myeloplax , a large multinucleate cell within the bone, which functions in the absroption and removal of bone tissue.
A large multinuclear cell associated with the resorption of bone
cell that functions in the breakdown and resorption of bone tissue

osteoclastic.explanation: Of or pertaining to an osteoclast

osteocolla.explanation: A deposited carbonate of lime, forming an incrustation on the roots and stems of plants, found in some parts of Germany in loose sandy grounds. It takes its name from an erroneous opinion that it has the quality of uniting fractured bones.
An inferior kind of glue obtained from bones; bone-glue.
A kind of glue obtained from bones.
A cellular calc tufa, which in some places forms incrustations on the stems of plants, -- formerly supposed to have the quality of uniting fractured bones.
A kind of glue obtained from bones .
A cellular calc tufa , found as incrustations on plant stems , once believed to have the power to unite fractured bones.

osteocomma.explanation: A bone-segment: one of a segmented series of bones, as a vertebra. Also called osteomere .
A metamere of the vertebrate skeleton; an osteomere; a vertebra.

osteocranium.explanation: The bony cranium, as distinguished from the cartilaginous cranium.
The bony cranium , as distinguished from the cartilaginous cranium.

osteocyte.explanation: A branched cell embedded in the matrix of bone tissue.
A mature bone cell involved with the maintenance of bone.

osteodentine.explanation: One of the varieties of dentine, resembling bone; that modification of dentine observed in the teeth of the cachalot and some other cetaceans, also in those of many existing and extinct fishes, in which the tissue is traversed by irregularly ramified vascular or medullary canals.
A hard substance, somewhat like bone, which is sometimes deposited within the pulp cavity of teeth.
A hard bony substance that is sometimes deposited within the pulp cavity of teeth .

osteoderm.explanation: A bone or ossicle developed in the skin of an animal. Typical examples are the bony plates of crocodiles and the ossicles of the great extinct sloth, the Grypotherium.
A bony deposit in the dermal layers of the skin

osteodynia.explanation: Pain in a bone, especially persistent pain.

osteodystrophy.explanation: Any abnormal or defective development of a bone
defective bone development; usually attributable to renal disease or to disturbances in calcium and phosphorus metabolism

osteofibroma.explanation: A tumor composed of osseous and fibrous elements.

osteogen.explanation: The substance of which the osteogenic fibers are composed.
The soft tissue, or substance, which, in developing bone, ultimately undergoes ossification.
The soft tissue , or substance, which, in developing bone , ultimately undergoes ossification .

osteogenesis.explanation: The formation and development of bony tissue.
The genesis, origination, or formation of bone; osteogeny; ossification.
The formation or growth of bone.
The formation and development of bone

osteogenetic.explanation: Connected with osteogenesis, or the formation of bone; producing bone
Connected with osteogenesis , or the formation of bone .

osteogenic.explanation: Derived from or composed of bone-forming tissue.

osteoglossidae.explanation: a family of large fishes that live in freshwater; includes bandfish and bonytongues

osteoglossoid.explanation: Osteoglossidæ , or pertaining to the Osteoglossoidea.

osteoglossum.explanation: The typical genus of Osteoglossidæ , having the abdomen trenchant, a broad tongue-like bone, and two barbels on the lower jaw. There are 3 species, South American, East Indian, and Australian. Also called Ischnosoma .

osteography.explanation: The scientific description of bones ; osteology .

osteohalisteresis.explanation: Loss of the mineral portion of bone.

osteoid.explanation: The bone matrix, especially before calcification.
Of, pertaining to, or characteristic of bone ; bonelike
An organic matrix of protein and polysaccharides , secreted by osteoblasts , that becomes bone after mineralization

osteolepis.explanation: A genus of fossil ganoid fishes of the Old Red Sandstone, having a cartilaginous endoskeleton, an enameled and sculptured bony exoskeleton, two anal and two dorsal fins alternating in position with one another, and an extremely heterocercal tail.

osteolite.explanation: An earthy kind of calcium phosphate, probably resulting from the alteration of apatite, occurring near Hanau in Prussia and at Amberg in Bavaria.
A massive impure apatite, or calcium phosphate.
A massive impure apatite , or calcium phosphate .

osteologer.explanation: One versed in osteology; an osteologist.
One versed in osteology ; an osteologist .
an anatomist who is skilled is osteology

osteologist.explanation: One who is versed in osteology; an osteological anatomist.
One who is skilled in osteology; an osteologer.
A scientist or physician whose speciality is osteology .
an anatomist who is skilled is osteology

osteology.explanation: The branch of anatomy that deals with the structure and function of bones.
The bone structure or system of an animal.
That branch of anatomy which treats of bone or of bones.
The science which treats of the bones of the vertebrate skeleton.
the scientific study of the morphology and pathology of bones
the bone structure of a particular individual, or species
the branch of anatomy that studies the bones of the vertebrate skeleton

osteolysis.explanation: Dissolution or degeneration of bone tissue through disease.
The resorption or dissolution of bone tissue
lysis of bone caused by disease or infection or inadequate blood supply

osteolytic.explanation: Of, pertaining to, or causing osteolysis

osteoma.explanation: A benign tumor composed of bony tissue, often developing on the skull.
In pathology , a tumor composed of bony tissue.
A tumor composed mainly of bone; a tumor of a bone.
A benign bony tumour that typically grows on the skull
a slow growing benign tumor of consisting of bone tissue; usually on the skull or mandible

osteomalacia.explanation: A bone disease in adults analogous to rickets in children, marked by bone demineralization caused by impaired metabolism or deficiency of vitamin D or phosphorus.

In pathology , a disease, most frequent in women, but also occurring in men, in which there is progressive disappearance of the earthy salts from the bones, which in consequence become soft and misshapen. Also called malacosteon , and mollities ossium.
A disease of the bones, in which they lose their earthy material, and become soft, flexible, and distorted. Also called malacia .
A softening of adult bones due to inadequate mineralization ; the adult equivalent of rickets
abnormal softening of bones caused by deficiencies of phosphorus or calcium or vitamin D

osteomanty.explanation: Divination by means of bones. Selden , Illustrations on Drayton's Polyolbion, vi.

osteometry.explanation: That part of zoömetry or anthropometry which has to do with the relative proportions or differences of the skeleton or its individual parts.
The measurement of the bones of the skeleton (both human and animal)

osteomyelitis.explanation: A usually bacterial infection of bone and bone marrow in which the resulting inflammation can lead to a reduction of blood supply to the bone.
an inflammation of bone and bone marrow (usually caused by bacterial infection)

osteopath.explanation: A believer in the treatment of disease by osteopathy; specifically, one who professes to cure disease by that method.
A physician who practices osteopathy by manipulating the skeleton and muscles
a therapist who manipulates the skeleton and muscles

osteopathist.explanation: One who practices osteopathy; an osteopath.
a therapist who manipulates the skeleton and muscles

osteopathy.explanation: A system of medicine based on the theory that disturbances in the musculoskeletal system affect other bodily parts, causing many disorders that can be corrected by various manipulative techniques in conjunction with conventional medical, surgical, pharmacological, and other therapeutic procedures.

A theory of disease and a method of cure, advocated by Dr. A. T. Still, resting upon the supposition that most diseases are traceable to deformation of some part of the skeleton (often due to accident) which, by mechanical pressure on the adjacent nerves and vessels, interferes with their action and the circulation of the blood. As a remedy a form of manipulation is used.

A system of treatment based on the theory that diseases are chiefly due to deranged mechanism of the bones, nerves, blood vessels, and other tissues, and can be remedied by manipulations of these parts. Modern practitioners use the therapeutic and diagnostic techniques of modern medicine as well as manipulative procedures.
The branch of therapy based on manipulation of bones and muscles
therapy based on the assumption that restoring health is best accomplished by manipulating the skeleton and muscles

osteoperiosteal.explanation: Relating to both bone and its periosteum

osteoperiostitis.explanation: Periostitis involving the bone to a marked extent.
Inflammation of a bone and its periosteum.

osteopetrosis.explanation: A rare hereditary disorder characterized by hard, dense bones .
an inherited disorder characterized by an increase in bone density; in severe forms the bone marrow cavity may be obliterated

osteophlebitis.explanation: Inflammation of the veins of a bone.

osteophone.explanation: An instrument for transmission of auditory vibrations through the bones of the head, so as to be appreciated as sounds by persons deaf from causes other than those affecting the nervous apparatus of hearing.

An instrument for transmission of auditory vibrations through the bones of the head , so as to be appreciated as sounds by persons deaf from causes other than those affecting the nervous apparatus of hearing.

osteophyte.explanation: An abnormal bony excrescence or osseous outgrowth.
Any small, abnormal growth of bone , often near a joint

osteoplasty.explanation: Surgical repair or alteration of bone.
A plastic operation by which a loss of bone is remedied; the transplanting of bone to make good a loss by disease, accident, or operation.
An operation or process by which the total or partial loss of a bone is remedied.
Surgery to repair , modify or graft bone or bony structures.

osteoporosis.explanation: A disease characterized by a decrease in bone mass and density, occurring especially in postmenopausal women, resulting in a predisposition to fractures.
Morbid absorption of bone proceeding from the Haversian canals, so that it becomes abnormally porous.
An absorption of bone so that the bone tissue becomes unusually porous. It occurs especially in elderly men and postmenopausal women, and predisposes the elderly to fractures of the bones.
A disease , occurring especially in women following menopause , in which the bones become extremely porous and are subject to fracture .
abnormal loss of bony tissue resulting in fragile porous bones attributable to a lack of calcium; most common in postmenopausal women

osteosarcoma.explanation: A tumor composed of intermingled bony and sarcomatous tissue.
A tumor having the structure of a sarcoma in which there is a deposit of bone; sarcoma connected with bone.
A type of cancer of the bone
malignant bone tumor; most common in children and young adults where it tends to affect the femur

osteosclerosis.explanation: The excessive formation of bone-tissue in the Haversian canals and other spaces of bone, so that it becomes denser.
Abnormal hardness and density of bone.
abnormal hardening or eburnation of bone

osteosclerotic.explanation: Exhibiting osteosclerosis ; thus, showing an abnormal increase in bone density

osteosis.explanation: The formation of bony tissue, especially within other tissue such as connective tissue.

osteostracan.explanation: extinct jawless fish of the Devonian with armored head

osteostraci.explanation: extinct group of armored fish-like vertebrates; taxonomy is not clear

osteosynthesis.explanation: The reduction and fixation of a bone fracture with implantable devices , usually made of metal .

osteotome.explanation: In surgery , a sawlike instrument for cutting bones, specifically one for cutting the bones of the fetal cranium when it is necessary to reduce it considerably to permit delivery.
A form of chisel used to divide the bone in the operation of osteotomy for the correction of deformity.
Strong nippers or a chisel for dividing bone.
a medical tool used for cutting or marking bone , used in dental implantation
a kind of bone saw used in the 19th and early 20th centuries

osteotomy.explanation: Surgical division or sectioning of bone.
In surgery , the division of or incision into a bone.
The dissection or anatomy of bones; osteology.
The operation of dividing a bone or of cutting a piece out of it, -- done to remedy deformity, etc.
The surgical procedure of cutting a bone . This is often performed to either lengthen, shorten, or straighten a bone.

osteria.explanation: An inn; a tavern: especially in Italy.

ostiarius.explanation: the lowest of the minor Holy Orders in the unreformed Western Church but now suppressed by the Roman Catholic Church

ostiary.explanation: One who is ordained in the lowest of the former minor orders.
In the early church and in the Roman Catholic Church , the doorkeeper of a church.
The mouth of a river; an estuary.
One who keeps the door, especially the door of a church; a porter.
The mouth of a river ; an estuary .
One who keeps the door, especially the door of a church; a porter .
the lowest of the minor Holy Orders in the unreformed Western Church but now suppressed by the Roman Catholic Church

ostic.explanation: Pertaining to, or applied to, the language of the Tuscaroras, Iroquois, Wyandots, Winnebagoes, and a part of the Sioux Indians.

ostinato.explanation: A short melody or pattern that is constantly repeated, usually in the same part at the same pitch.
A piece of melody , a chord progression , or a bass figure that is repeated over and over as a musical accompaniment .
a musical phrase repeated over and over during a composition

ostiolar.explanation: botany and zoology , of or pertaining to any ostiole: as, the ostiolar filaments of certain lichens; the ostiolar canal or the channel connected with the ostioles of bugs. Also spelled osteolar .
Of or pertaining to the ostiole .

ostiolate.explanation: botany and zoology , furnished with an ostiole or small orifice.

ostiole.explanation: A small opening or pore, as of a fruiting body.
A small opening or entrance; a little ostium.
In zoology : One of the small inhalant pores or orifices of sponges.
The exterior opening of a stomate. See stomate .
A small hole or opening through which certain fungi release their mature spores .
A similar hole or opening in plants , such as the opening of the involuted fig inflorescence through which fig wasps enter to pollinate and breed .
a small pore especially one in the reproductive bodies of certain algae and fungi through which spores pass

ostium.explanation: A small opening or orifice, as in a body organ or passage.
Any of the small openings or pores in a sponge, through which water is drawn in.
An opening or entrance; a mouth; an os.
In zoology : In sponges, the opening of an incurrent canal.
A small opening or orifice , as in a body organ or passage .
Any of the small openings or pores in a sponge .

ostler.explanation: A person employed at an inn , hostelry , or stable to look after horses ; a groom
someone employed in a stable to take care of the horses

ostmark.explanation: A former unit of currency in East Germany worth 100 pfennigs.
The currency unit of the former German Democratic Republic (aka GDR , DDR , East Germany ) until 1990, abbreviated DDM.

ostmen.explanation: East men; Danish settlers in Ireland, formerly so called.

ostomy.explanation: Surgical construction of an artificial excretory opening, as a colostomy or ileostomy.
A surgical procedure to provide an exit point for the waste of an organism.
An exit point created by such surgical procedure.
surgical procedure that creates an artificial opening for the elimination of bodily wastes

ostosis.explanation: Bone formation; ossification. See ectostosis , and endostosis .

ostracea.explanation: A division of bivalve mollusks including the oysters and allied shells.

ostracean.explanation: A member of the Ostracea ; an oyster. Also ostracine .
Any one of a family of bivalves, of which the oyster is the type.
Any of a family of bivalves of which the oyster is the type .

ostracise.explanation: avoid speaking to or dealing with
expel from a community or group

ostracism.explanation: The act of banishing or excluding.
Banishment or exclusion from a group; disgrace.
In Athens and other cities of ancient Greece, the temporary banishment by popular vote of a citizen considered dangerous to the state.

A political measure employed under restrictions of law among the ancient Athenians, by which citizens whose presence seemed embarrassing to the state were banished by public vote for a term of ten years, with leave to return to the enjoyment of their estates at the end of the period.
Hence Banishment in general; expulsion; separation: as, social ostracism (banishment from good society).
Banishment by popular vote, -- a means adopted at Athens to rid the city of a person whose talent and influence gave umbrage.
Exclusion from a community or society.
the act of excluding someone from society by general consent
the state of being banished or ostracized (excluded from society by general consent)

ostracite.explanation: A fossil oyster or some similar shell; a fossil referred to an old genus Ostracites.

ostracization.explanation: The process or practice of ostracizing.

ostracize.explanation: To exclude from a group or society.
To banish by ostracism, as in ancient Greece.
To exile by ostracism; to banish by a popular vote, as at Athens.

To banish from society, by a general consent; to exclude from social, political, or private favor; to exclude from conversation or friendship; to shun. A person may be ostracized by a formal vote or by a widespread but informal agreement.
To exclude (a person) from society or from a community, by not communicating with them or by refusing to acknowledge their presence; to refuse to talk to or associate with; to shun .
avoid speaking to or dealing with
expel from a community or group

ostracized.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of ostracize .

ostracizer.explanation: One who ostracizes, exiles, banishes, or excludes from favor.

ostracizes.explanation: Third-person singular simple present indicative form of ostracize .

ostracizing.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of ostracize .

ostracod.explanation: Any of numerous small chiefly aquatic crustaceans of the class Ostracoda, having a bivalve carapace and including many extinct species that are commonly found as fossils.
A member of the Ostracoda, an order of tiny marine and freshwater crustaceans with a shrimplike body enclosed in a bivalve shell.
Any of many small crustaceans , of the class Ostracoda , that resemble shrimps enclosed in a bivalve shell
tiny marine and freshwater crustaceans with a shrimp-like body enclosed in a bivalve shell

ostracoderm.explanation: Any of various extinct primitive jawless fishes of the Ordovician through the Devonian periods, having bodies encased in an armor of bony plates.
An ostraciont fish, as a member of the Ostracodermi ; a plectognath of the suborder Ostracodermi.
Any of several extinct fishlike jawless vertebrates having a heavily armored body; of the Paleozoic.
extinct fish-like jawless vertebrate having a heavily armored body; of the Paleozoic

ostracoid.explanation: One of the Entomostraca allied to the Ostracoda.
Of or pertaining to the Ostracoidea (now Ostracoda).
Of or pertaining to the Ostracoidea.

ostracoidea.explanation: An order of Entomostraca possessing hard bivalve shells. They are of small size, and swim freely about. Now usually written Ostracoda .

ostracon.explanation: In Greek antiquity , a potsherd or tile; a square plaque of terra-cotta on which an inscription is written.
A piece of pottery or stone , usually broken off from a vase or other earthenware vessel .

ostracum.explanation: the middle layer of a molluscan shell.

ostrea.explanation: The typical and leading genus of the oyster family, Ostreidæ having the shell inequilateral and inequivalve, with one valve flatter than the other.
A genus of bivalve Mollusca which includes the true oysters.
type genus of the family Ostreidae

ostreaceous.explanation: Of or pertaining to an oyster, or to a shell; shelly.
Of or pertaining to an oyster , or to a shell .

ostreiculture.explanation: Oyster-culture; the artificial breeding and cultivation of oysters. Also ostreaculture .

ostreiculturist.explanation: One who cultivates oysters, or is engaged in the industry of propagating these bivalves.

ostreophagist.explanation: An oyster-eater; one who or that which eats or feeds upon oysters.

ostrich.explanation: Either of two large, swift-running flightless birds (Struthio camelus or S. molybdophanes) of Africa, characterized by a long bare neck, small head, and two-toed feet. Ostriches are the largest living birds.
One who tries to avoid disagreeable situations by refusing to face them.
A very large ratite bird of the genus Struthio.

Four species of ostriches are now recognized, the name Struthis camelus being restricted to the northern species that ranges into Arabia. S. molybdophanes is from Somaliland, and S. meridionalis or masaicus from Central Africa. The southern species, S. australis , is the one that has been partially domesticated and is kept in ostrich-farms for the sake of its feathers. The eggs of these species differ quite as much as do the birds themselves, that of S. camelus being quite smooth while the others are more or less deeply pitted.

A large bird of the genus Struthio, of which Struthio camelus of Africa is the best known species. It has long and very strong legs, adapted for rapid running; only two toes; a long neck, nearly bare of feathers; and short wings incapable of flight. The adult male is about eight feet high.
a farm on which ostriches are bred for the sake of their feathers, oil, eggs, etc.
the occupation of breeding ostriches for the sake of their feathers, etc.
a kind of fern ( Onoclea Struthiopteris ), the tall fronds of which grow in a circle from the rootstock. It is found in alluvial soil in Europe and North America.
A large flightless bird ( Struthio camelus ) native to Africa .
fast-running African flightless bird with two-toed feet; largest living bird
a person who refuses to face reality or recognize the truth (a reference to the popular notion that the ostrich hides from danger by burying its head in the sand)

ostrichlike.explanation: Resembling an ostrich or some aspect of one.

ostrogothic.explanation: Of or pertaining to the Ostrogoths.

ostrya.explanation: A genus of apetalous trees, the hop-hornbeams, of the order Cupuliferæ , or oak family, and the tribe Coryleæ , known by the cone-like fruit of flattish-inflated membranaceous bracts inclosing small sessile bony nuts.
deciduous monoecious trees of Europe and Asia and America; sometimes placed in subfamily or family Carpinaceae

otacoustic.explanation: An instrument to facilitate hearing; especially, an ear-trumpet.
An instrument to facilitate hearing, as an ear trumpet.

otacousticon.explanation: An instrument to aid hearing , such as an ear trumpet or hearing aid .

otalgia.explanation: an ache localized in the middle or inner ear

otaria.explanation: The typical genus of Otariidæ. See cut under otary .

otariidae.explanation: eared seals: sea lions and fur seals

otarine.explanation: phocine , and from rosmarine or trichechine.

otary.explanation: An eared seal; a seal of the family Otariidæ.

otate.explanation: In Mexico, Chusquea Nelsoni (= Guadua amplexifolia ), and several other giant grasses used by the ancient Mexicans for making darts and lances, and now used for making baskets and for other domestic purposes.

othematoma.explanation: Effusion of blood beneath the perichondrium of the pinna of the ear. Also called hæmatoma auris , and, from its frequency in the insane, insane ear.

otheoscope.explanation: An instrument akin to the radiometer.
An instrument for exhibiting the repulsive action produced by light or heat in an exhausted vessel; a modification of the radiometer.
An instrument for exhibiting the repulsive action produced by light or heat in a vacuum ; a modification of the radiometer .

other.explanation: Being the remaining one of two or more.
Being the remaining ones of several.
Different from that or those implied or specified.
Of a different character or quality.
Of a different time or era either future or past.
The remaining one of two or more.
A person or thing considered to represent or epitomize difference or an outgroup. Used with the.
A different or an additional person or thing.
the. The antecedent correlative to the other is one or the one. In these combinations a possessive pronoun may take the place of the. Also used absolutely without repetition of the noun referred to.
than or but following, expressed or understood.

the, that, an, any, some , etc.) preceding, and often followed (as a comparative) by a clause with than : frequently used also as correlative to this, one , or some preceding: as, he was occupied with other reflections; this man I know, the other man I never saw before; some men seek wealth, other men seek fame.
each and other; either and other ; the one and the other. See each .
Either; -- used with other or or for its correlative (as either … or are now used).
Different from that which, or the one who, has been specified; not the same; not identical; additional; second of two.
Not this, but the contrary; opposite.
Alternate; second; -- used esp. in connection with every .
at a certain time past, not distant, but indefinite; not long ago; recently; rarely, the third day past.
Not the one previously referred to.
Apart from; in the phrase "other than".

otherism.explanation: Regard for the rights, welfare, and point of view of others; altruism; in evolutionary philosophy, “the struggle for the life of others,” especially for the life of offspring.

otherness.explanation: The quality or condition of being different or of belonging to an outgroup.
The state or quality of being other; alterity.
The quality or state of being other or different; alterity; oppositeness.
The quality of being different or distinct .
The result or product of being different or distinct .
the quality of being not alike; being distinct or different from that otherwise experienced or known

others.explanation: Those remaining after one or more people or items have left , or done something else, or been excluded .

otherways.explanation: Otherwise ; by another means; differently ; in other respects; contrarily .
In a similar or comparable way; similarly .

otherwhere.explanation: In or to some other place, or places; elsewhere.
In or to some other place, or places; elsewhere.

otherwhile.explanation: At another time, or other times; sometimes; occasionally.

otherwhiles.explanation: At another time, or other times.

otherwise.explanation: Used to indicate a category to which the preceding adverb does not apply.
In a different manner; in another way, or in other ways; differently; contrarily.
In different circumstances; under other conditions.
other than as supposed or expected

otherworld.explanation: A world or existence beyond earthly reality.
A world beyond death; an afterlife .
A world other than the everyday world.
an abstract spiritual world beyond earthly reality

otherworldliness.explanation: The character of being otherworldly; a disposition to act in this life with reference to another or future world; conduct of life prompted by a hope of heaven.
Reference to or insistence upon the existence of another world beyond the present; ideality; spirituality; the quality of being visionary.
concern with things of the spirit

otherworldly.explanation: Of, relating to, or characteristic of another world, especially a mystical or transcendental world.
Devoted to the world of the mind; concerned with intellectual or imaginative things.
Concerned with an afterlife, especially when inattentive to the present.
existing outside of or not in accordance with nature.
Not worldly; preparing for or concerned primarily with the afterlife; -- of people.
Of, concerned with, or preoccupied with a different world than that of the tangible here and now , such as a heavenly , spiritual , or imaginary world.
Not belonging to the real world; unnatural ; odd and unfamiliar .
existing outside of or not in accordance with nature

othonna.explanation: A genus of plants of the order Compositæ and the tribe Senecionideæ , type of the subtribe Othonneæ , and known by its sterile disk-flowers and copious pappus.
A South African plant of the genus Othonna having smooth often fleshy leaves and heads of yellow flowers.
a South African plant of the genus Othonna having smooth often fleshy leaves and heads of yellow flowers

otic.explanation: Of, relating to, or located near the ear; auricular.
Of, pertaining to, or in the region of, the ear; auricular; auditory.
of, relating/pertaining to, or located near the ear
of or relating to near the ear

oticodinia.explanation: Dizziness associated with disease of the ear; Ménière's disease.

otidiphaps.explanation: A remarkable genus of Papuan pigeons, probably belonging to the Columbidæ , but not related to the ground-pigeons of the genus Goura.

otidium.explanation: The typical ear of a mollusk; the form of otocyst or auditory organ which occurs in the Mollusca.

otiose.explanation: Of no use; pointless or superfluous.
Being at leisure or ease; unemployed; indolent; idle.
Reluctant to work or to exert oneself.
Having no reason for being ( raison d’être ); having no point , reason, or purpose .
serving no useful purpose; having no excuse for being

otiosity.explanation: The state or quality of being otiose or of having nothing to do; ease; relief from labor; idleness.
Perfunctoriness; easy negligence; carelessness; ineffectiveness; futility.
The state or quality of being otiose .

oto.explanation: a member of the Siouan people inhabiting the valleys of the Platte and Missouri rivers in Nebraska
a dialect of the Chiwere language spoken by the Oto

otoconial.explanation: Of or partaining to an otoconium .

otoconite.explanation: An otoconium; a small otolith or calcareous concretion of the labyrinth of the ear.

otoconium.explanation: One of the small otoliths, or gritty particles in the membranous labyrinth: used practically only in the plural.

otocrane.explanation: The bony structure of the middle and inner ear of a vertebrate, containing the essential parts of the organ of hearing.
The cavity in the skull in which the parts of the internal ear are lodged.
The cavity in the skull in which the parts of the internal ear are located.

otocranial.explanation: Of or pertaining to the otocrane.
Of or pertaining to the otocrane .

otocyon.explanation: A remarkable genus of African foxes of the alopecoid or vulpine series of the family Canidæ , typical of the subfamily Otocyoninæ.
[ lowercase ] Any animal of this genus; a megalote.

otocyst.explanation: The structure formed by invagination of the embryonic ectodermal tissue that develops into the inner ear.

In zoology , an auditory vesicle; any cavity or cyst which contains the essential parts of an organ of hearing; especially, the auditory vesicle or capsule of some of the Invertebrata , often containing otoliths, and subservient to the function of audition.

An auditory cyst or vesicle; one of the simple auditory organs of many invertebrates, containing a fluid and otoliths; also, the embryonic vesicle from which the parts of the internal ear of vertebrates are developed.
An organ involved in balance and orientation .
The precursor of the inner ear .

otography.explanation: The descriptive anatomy of the ear.
The scientific description of the ear .

otogyps.explanation: A genus of Old World vultures of the family Falconidæ and the sub-family Vulturinæ , having ear-like flaps of skin: the eared vultures.

otolaryngologist.explanation: a specialist in the disorders of the ear or nose or throat

otolaryngology.explanation: The branch of medicine that deals with diagnosis and treatment of diseases of the ear, nose, and throat.
Otology and laryngology regarded as a single specialty in medical practice.
the medical specialty that deals with diseases of the ear, nose and throat

otolith.explanation: One of the small calcareous particles found in the inner ear of many vertebrates, especially fishes, which are involved in determining body orientation and sometimes in perceiving sound.
A calcareous concretion within the membranous labyrinth of the ear.
One of the proper otic bones of some animals, as certain fishes; an otosteon. See cuts under Esox and Python.

One of the small bones or particles of calcareous or other hard substance in the internal ear of vertebrates, and in the auditory organs of many invertebrates; an ear stone. Collectively, the otoliths are called ear sand and otoconite .
A small particle, comprised mainly of calcium carbonate , found in the inner ear of vertebrates , being part of the balance sense.

otolithic.explanation: otolithic capsule or lithocyst. Also otolitic .
Of or partaining to an otolith

otolithus.explanation: A genus of sciænoid fishes; weakfish: now commonly called Cynoscion .

otologist.explanation: One who is versed in otology, especially in its medical and surgical aspects; an aurist.
One skilled in otology; an aurist.
a physician who specializes in the ear and its diseases

otology.explanation: The branch of medicine that deals with the structure, function, and pathology of the ear.
That branch of science which deals with the human ear, its anatomy and functions, in health and disease.
The branch of science which treats of the ear and its diseases.
The branch of medicine that deals with the ear , its structure , function and pathology .
the branch of medicine concerned with the ear

otomian.explanation: A member or the language of the Otomi stock.

otomycosis.explanation: The presence of fungi, such as Aspergillus nigricans , in the external auditory meatus.

otopathy.explanation: A diseased condition of the ear.
A diseased condition of the ear .

otopiesis.explanation: A sinking in of the drum membrane consequent upon a partial vacuum in the middle ear; also, pressure from any cause on the labyrinth, or internal ear, and the consequent deafness.

otoplasty.explanation: A procedure of plastic surgery used to change the appearance or shape of a person’s ears .
reconstructive surgery of the auricle of the external ear

otopyosis.explanation: The presence of pus in the ear.

otorhinolaryngologist.explanation: Doctor specializing in otorhinolaryngology , the study of ear, nose, and throat.
a specialist in the disorders of the ear or nose or throat

otorhinolaryngology.explanation: The medical specialty which deals with diseases of the ear, nose, and larynx.
the study of diseases of the ear , nose and throat
the medical specialty that deals with diseases of the ear, nose and throat

otorrhea.explanation: Discharge of fluid from an external ear .

otosclerosis.explanation: A disease of the ear in which the movement of the stapes within the oval window becomes impeded by abnormal deposits of spongy bone, leading to a progressive loss of hearing.
A hardening of the tissues and ankylosis of the ossicles of the middle ear.
A growth of spongy bone substance in the capsule of the internal ear.
hereditary disorder in which ossification of the labyrinth of the inner ear causes tinnitus and eventual deafness

otoscopy.explanation: Inspection of the ear; clinical examination of the ear.
The examination of the ear; the art of using the otoscope.
The visual examination of the inner ear using an otoscope

otosis.explanation: Mishearing; false impression as to sounds uttered by others, or a word-form so originated.

otosphenal.explanation: The basioccipital, a bone at the posterior base of the cranium, in fishes, to which the vertebral column is attached.

otosteon.explanation: An ear-stone; an otolith; a hard concretion in the cavity of the labyrinth of the ear, as in the cod and many other fishes: not to be confounded with any of the bones proper of the ear.
An ear-bone proper; an otic or periotic bone.

ototoxic.explanation: Having a toxic effect on the structures of the ear, especially on its nerve supply.
toxic to the organs of hearing or balance or to the auditory nerve

ottar.explanation: essential oil or perfume obtained from flowers

ottava.explanation: At an octave higher or lower than the notes written. Used chiefly as a direction, positioned above or below a staff.
One octave higher. Marking indicates a passage to be transposed up one octave. Abbreviation: 8va .

ottawas.explanation: A tribe of Indians who, when first known, lived on the Ottawa River. Most of them subsequently migrated to the southwestern shore of Lake Superior.

otter.explanation: Any of various aquatic or semiaquatic carnivorous mammals of the mustelid subfamily Lutrinae, having webbed feet and dense, dark brown fur.
The fur of one of these animals.
Same as attar .
otter-board .
otter , n. , 4.
A corruption of arnotto.
An aquatic digitigrade carnivorous mammal of the order Feræ , family Mustelidæ and subfamily Lutrinæ.
The sea-otter. See Enhydris .
The larva of the ghost-moth, Epialus humuli , which is very destructive to hop-plantations.
A tackle with line and flies, used for fishing below the surface in lakes and rivers.
A breed of sheep: same as ancon , 3.
A corruption of annotto .

Any carnivorous animal of the genera Lutra, Enhydra, and related genera of the family Mustelidae . Several species are described. They have large, flattish heads, short ears, and webbed toes. They are aquatic, and feed on fish. The sea otter ( Enhydra lutris ) also eats clams, crabs, starfish, abalone, and other marine animals; they may come to the surface, and lying on their backs using the stomach as a table, may be seen cracking open the shell of its prey with a rock. The common otter of Europe is Lutra vulgaris ; the North American otter (or American otter) is Lutra Canadensis , which inhabits marshes, streams and rivers; other species inhabit South America and Asia. The North American otter adult is about three to four feet long (including the tail) and weighs from 10 to 30 pounds; the sea otter is commonly four feet long and 45 pounds (female) or 60 pounds (male). Their fur is soft and valuable, and in the nineteenth century they were hunted extensively. The sea otter was hunted to near extinction by 1900, and is now protected. Fewer than 3,000 sea otters are believed to live along the central California coast.

Synonyms Outline, Contour, Profile, Sketch, Delineation. Outline is, literally, the outer or exterior line; but the word is freely used for a representation by the principal or distinguishing lines. Contour and profile retain this distinctive meaning of the outside line, the former referring to the boundary of the whole figure in any position, and the latter to the boundary of face or figure when seen directly from one side, with figurative uses in architecture and surveying. A sketch fills up the outline to a greater or less degree, not completely, but so that a lively idea of the original object or scene is conveyed. Delineation is rather indefinite, but is more than an outline and may be complete. Outline, sketch , and delineation bear the same relation to one another when used to express the representation of a subject in words.

Overturn, Overthrow, Subvert, Invert , upset, throw down, beat down, prostrate. The first three of the italicized words indicate violence and destructiveness. Invert is rarely used where the action is not careful and with a purpose: as, to invert a goblet to prevent its being filled. That which is overturned or overthrown is brought down from a standing or erect position to lie prostrate. Overthrow indicates more violence or energy than overturn , as throw is stronger than turn. That which is subverted is reached to the very bottom and goes to wreck in the turning: as, to subvert the very foundations of justice. To invert is primarily to turn upside down, but it may be used figuratively, of things not material, for turning wrong side before or reversing: as, to invert the order of a sentence. See defeat , v. t., and demolish.

A believer in the theory (called encasement theory ), current during the last century, that the egg was the real animal germ, and that at the time of fecundation the spermatozoa simply gave the impetus which caused the unfolding of the egg, in which all generations were inclosed one within the other. Also called ovist .

A believer in the theory (called "encasement theory") that the egg was the real animal germ , and that at the time of fecundation the spermatozoa simply gave the impetus which caused the unfolding of the egg, in which all generations were enclosed one within the other.
