oxidulated.explanation: chem. , applied to a compound containing oxygen.
oxidulated iron ore (magnetite) in contradistinction to red iron ore or ferric oxid.
Existing in the state of a protoxide; -- said of an oxide.
Existing in the state of a protoxide ; said of an oxide .

oximation.explanation: Reaction with, or conversion into an oxime

oxime.explanation: Any of a group of compounds containing a hydroxyl group bonded to a carbon atom, which in turn is doubly bonded to a nitrogen atom. An oxime is formed by treating an aldehyde or ketone with hydroxylamine.

A compound formed by the action of hydroxylamine on an aldehyde (aldoxime) or a ketone (ketoxime). The oximes contain the atomic grouping=C:N.OH. They have played an important part in the study of the stereochemistry of nitrogen. Their formation indicates the presence of carbonyl oxygen in the substances from which they are derived.
One of a series of isonitroso derivatives obtained by the action of hydroxylamine on aldehydes or ketones.
Any of a class of organic compounds , of general formula RR'C=NOH, derived from the condensation of an aldehyde (R' = H) or ketone with hydroxylamine .

oximeter.explanation: A device for measuring the oxygen saturation of arterial blood, especially a pulse oximeter.
A device that measures the oxygen saturation of arterial blood .
a measuring instrument that measures the oxygen in arterial blood

oximetry.explanation: The measurement of the oxygen level in arterial blood

oxindole.explanation: A bicyclic aromatic heterocycle containing a benzene ring fused with five-membered cyclic amide

oxlike.explanation: Characteristic of, or like, an ox.
Resembling an ox or some aspect of one: strong , foolish , etc.

oxlip.explanation: A Eurasian primrose (Primula elatior) having yellow flowers clustered in a one-sided umbel.

The variety elatior of the common primrose, Primula veris , in which the limb of the corolla is broader and flatter and the flowers are raised on a common peduncle. By many it is considered a distinct species.
The great cowslip ( Primula veris , var. elatior).
The plant Primula elatior, similar to cowslip but with larger, pale yellow flowers.
Eurasian primrose with yellow flowers clustered in a one-sided umbel

oxman.explanation: A man who drives or tends a yoke of oxen.

oxonic.explanation: Pertaining to, or designating, a complex nitrogenous acid (C4H5N3O4) not known in the free state, but obtained, in combination with its salts, by a slow oxidation of uric acid, to which it is related.

oxonium.explanation: A radical, , containing a quadrivalent oxygen atom and possessing salt-forming properties.
Any univalent oxygen cation derived from water , the simplest of which is the hydronium ion (H3O+).

oxpecker.explanation: Either of two African starlings (Buphagus africanus or B. erythrorhyncus) that feed on ticks and other insects found on the hides of large wild or domestic animals.
An African bird of the genus Buphaga , or family Buphagidæ : so called from its habit of alighting on cattle to peck for food. See cut under Buphaga .

It is somewhat smaller than a robin, of a grayish-brown color, with dark wings and a yellow bill. This bird is found in northern and eastern Africa. A second species, the red-billed oxpecker, B. erythrorhyncha , inhabits central Africa. See Buphaga , with cut.
An African bird of the genus Buphaga; the beefeater.
Either of two species of passerine bird in the genus Buphagus , in the monotypic family Buphagidae , endemic to sub-Saharan African savannah .

oxshoe.explanation: A flat piece of iron, with or without calks, shaped to one part of the hoof of an ox and pierced with holes near the outer edge to receive the wrought-iron flat-headed clinch-nails used to fasten it.
A shoe for oxen, consisting of a flat piece of iron nailed to the hoof.
A shoe for oxen , consisting of a flat piece of iron nailed to the hoof .

oxtail.explanation: The tail of any kind of cattle, traditionally an ox and especially when used for food.
a cut of meat taken from the tail of a cow or calf ; it requires long slow braising , and is used to prepare the classic oxtail soup
the skinned tail of cattle; used especially for soups

oxter.explanation: The armpit; also, the embrace of the arms.
In coal-mining , a reëntrant corner in a working face.

oxtongue.explanation: One of several plants with rough tongue-shaped leaves, especially Picris ( Helminthia ) echioides , and the alkanet, Anchusa officinalis. Compare bugloss .
A name sometimes given to the anlace, braquemart, and similar short broadswords.

A widespread European weed ( Picris echioides formerly Helminthia echioides ) with spiny tongue-shaped leaves and yellow flowers. The name is applied to several plants, from the shape and roughness of their leaves; as, Anchusa officinalis , a kind of bugloss, and Helminthia echioides , both European herbs. It has been naturalized in the U. S.
A flowering plant of the genus Picris, especially Picris echioides, the bristly oxtongue.
widespread European weed with spiny tongue-shaped leaves and yellow flowers; naturalized in United States

oxy.explanation: the bivalent R-O-R functional group found in ethers

oxyacanthine.explanation: A crystalline compound, C 19 H 21 NO 3 , obtained from the bark of the root of the barberry, Berberis vulgaris. Also called vinetine .

oxyacanthous.explanation: botany , furnished with many sharp thorns or prickles.

oxyacetylene.explanation: Of or using a mixture of acetylene and oxygen.
Of or pertaining to a mixture of oxygen and actylene.
A mixture of oxygen and acetylene ; burns at a high temperature and is used for cutting and welding metals .
Using this mixture e.g. an oxyacetylene torch
a mixture of oxygen and acetylene; used to create high temperatures for cutting or welding metals

oxyacid.explanation: An acid containing oxygen. Also called oxacid .

This term was formerly used to distinguish an acid containing oxygen from one in which this element is not present, as sulphuric acid, H 2 SO 4 , from hydrochloric; acid, HCl. In modern organic chemistry the same term is often applied to an acid which contains both a carboxyl and a hydroxyl group, as oxyacetic or glycolic acid, CH 2 .HO.COOH. Substances of this kind are perhaps better called hydroxyacids or alcohol acids.
An acid containing oxygen, as chloric acid or sulphuric acid; -- contrasted with the hydracids , which contain no oxygen, as hydrochloric acid. See acid , and hydroxy- .
An acid containing oxygen , as opposed to a hydracid .

oxyaster.explanation: A regular polyact sponge-spicule, whose long acute rays radiate from one point.

oxyazo.explanation: In chem. , a prefix showing that the compound named is an azo compound containing hydroxyl in one of the radicals, as in oxyazobenzene , C 6 H 5 N 2 C 6 H 4 .OH: same as hydroxyazo- , which is to be preferred.

oxybaphon.explanation: In Greek antiquity , a large, deep, wide-mouthed wine-vase, tapering interiorly to a point at the base and resembling in use and somewhat in shape the crater, but in the main convex instead of concave in vertical profile, and having its two handles immediately below the rim.
In Greek antiquity , a vinegarcruet; a small shallow vase for holding condiments.

oxybaphus.explanation: A genus of apetalous plants of the order Nyctagineæ , the tribe Mirabilieæ , and the subtribe Boerhaavieæ , having a short perianth and involucre with connate bracts.

oxybenzene.explanation: a toxic white soluble crystalline acidic derivative of benzene; used in manufacturing and as a disinfectant and antiseptic; poisonous if taken internally

oxybenzoic.explanation: Hydroxybenzoic; pertaining to, or designating, any one of several hydroxyl derivatives of benzonic acid, of which the commonest is salicylic acid.

oxybromide.explanation: A substance containing oxygen and bromine united to the same element or radical: as, carbon oxybromide or carbonyl bromide, COBr 2 .

oxybutyric.explanation: Hydroxybutyric; designating any one of a group of metameric acids ((C3H6.OH).CO2H).

oxycalcium.explanation: Of or pertaining to oxygen and calcium. See drummond light .
Of, pertaining to, or produced by a combination of calcium (or lime ) and oxygen

oxycamphor.explanation: Alpha-oxycamphor , C 10 H 16 O 2 , formed by reducing camphoquinone. it melts at 203–205° C.

Beta-oxycamphor , C 10 H 16 O 2 , made by the action of nitrous acid on β-amino-camphor. It is a crystalline substance which melts at 154–155° C. Other varieties are made by oxidizing camphene and borneol.

oxycarbonate.explanation: Any substance which is both an oxide and a carbonate

oxycellulose.explanation: A white amorphous compound, C 18 H 26 O 16 or C 36 H 60 O 31 , made by boiling cellulose with nitric acid. Other varieties have been made by the action of potassium chlorate (C 24 H 38 O 21 )(?), bromine water (C 12 H 20 O 11 ), and hydrogen peroxid (C 36 H 62 O 31 ). The composition of these compounds is uncertain. See celloxin .

oxycephaly.explanation: A congenital abnormality of the skull in which the top of the head assumes a conical or pointed shape.
The character of a skull having a high vertical index; hypsicephaly.

In anthropology , the head-form resulting from artificial deformation applied all around the head and preventing lateral and occipital growth, thus making the head very high in the region of the bregma. Similar forms result from premature synostosis of the parietals with the occipital or temporal bones.
A kind of cephalic disorder : sometimes the premature closure of the coronal suture plus any other suture, such as the lambdoid ; sometimes the premature fusing of all sutures.
a congenital abnormality of the skull; the top of the skull assumes a cone shape

oxychlorate.explanation: An early name for what is now called perchlorate , a salt of perchloric acid.

oxychloric.explanation: Of, pertaining to, or designating in general, certain compounds containing oxygen and chlorine.
Formerly designating an acid now called perchloric acid . See perchloric .

oxychlorid.explanation: A compound of a metallic chlorid with oxygen: as, oxychlorids of iron, tin, etc.

oxychloride.explanation: A ternary compound of oxygen and chlorine.
A ternary compound of oxygen and chlorine .

oxychromatin.explanation: That portion of the nuclear substance of the cell which is stained by acid aniline dyes: equivalent to linin.

oxycoccus.explanation: A genus of gamopetalous plants of the order Vacciniaceæ and the tribe Euvaccinieæ , known by its eight bluntawnless anthers, four-celled berries, and deeply or completely four-parted revolute corolla; the cranberry.

oxycrate.explanation: A mixture of water and vinegar.
A Mixture of water and vinegar.
A mixture of water and vinegar .

oxycyanide.explanation: A substance containing oxygen and the radical cyanogen united to the same element or radical: as, mercuric oxycyanide , or oxycyanide of mercury, Hg 2 (Cn) 2 O.

oxydendrum.explanation: A genus of the gamopetalous order Ericaceæ and the tribe Andromedeæ , characterized by the needle-shaped seeds and two-bracted persistent unchanged calyx of separate sepals.

oxyethyl.explanation: Ethyl in which one hydrogen atom is replaced by hydroxyl, as CH 2 (OH).CH 2 or CH 3 .CH-(OH). It occurs only as a substituting group in compounds.

oxyfatty.explanation: 2 H 4 (OH)CO 2 H, glyceric acid, C 2 H 3 (OH) 2 -CO 2 H, and saccharic acid, C 5 H 7 (OH) 4 CO 2 H.

oxyfluoride.explanation: A compound of an oxid and a fluoride: as, the oxyfluoride of lead.
A ternary compound of oxygen and fluorine .

oxygen.explanation: A nonmetallic element constituting 21 percent of the atmosphere by volume that occurs as a diatomic gas, O 2 , and in many compounds such as water and silica, and in iron ore. It combines with most elements, is essential for plant and animal respiration, and is required for nearly all combustion. Ozone, O 3 , is an allotrope of this element. Atomic number 8; atomic weight 15.9994; melting point −218.79°C; boiling point −182.9°C; gas density at 0°C 1.429 grams per liter; valence 2. cross-reference : Periodic Table .
Chemical symbol, O; atomic weight, 16. An element discovered by Priestley in 1774, who called it dephlogisticated air.

A colorless, tasteless, odorless, gaseous element of atomic number 8, occurring in the free state in the atmosphere, of which it forms about 23 per cent by weight and about 21 per cent by volume, being slightly heavier than nitrogen. Symbol O. Atomic weight 15.9994.
A chemical element (symbol O) with an atomic number of 8 and relative atomic mass of 15.9994.
Molecular oxygen (O2), a colorless , odorless gas at room temperature.
A mixture of oxygen and other gases, administered to a patient to help him or her to breathe .

a nonmetallic bivalent element that is normally a colorless odorless tasteless nonflammable diatomic gas; constitutes 21 percent of the atmosphere by volume; the most abundant element in the earth's crust

oxygenant.explanation: A substance that produces or is capable of producing oxidation.

oxygenase.explanation: An oxidoreductase that catalyzes the incorporation of molecular oxygen into its substrate.
An enzyme which catalyses biochemical reactions with oxygen .
an oxidoreductase that catalyzes the incorporation of molecular oxygen

oxygenate.explanation: To treat, combine, or infuse with oxygen.
To unite, or cause to combine, with oxygen; to treat with oxygen; to oxidize.
To treat or infuse with oxygen
impregnate, combine, or supply with oxygen

oxygenated.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of oxygenate .
Containing oxygen , or oxygen-containing radicals, as substituents

oxygenates.explanation: Third-person singular simple present indicative form of oxygenate .

oxygenation.explanation: The process or act of oxygenating, or impregnating or saturating with oxygen.
The act or process of combining or of treating with oxygen; oxidation.
the process of reacting or treating something with oxygen
the process of providing or combining or treating with oxygen

oxygenator.explanation: any device that releases oxygen (or air ) into water , especially one in an aquarium

oxygenic.explanation: Pertaining to, containing, or resembling, oxygen; producing oxygen.
of, relating to, containing or producing oxygen

oxygenize.explanation: impregnate, combine, or supply with oxygen

change (a compound) by increasing the proportion of the electronegative part; or change (an element or ion) from a lower to a higher positive valence: remove one or more electrons from (an atom, ion, or molecule)

oxygenized.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of oxygenize .

oxygenizer.explanation: That which oxidates or converts into an oxid. Also spelled oxygeniser .

oxygeusia.explanation: Morbid acuteness of the sense of taste.

oxygnathous.explanation: conchology , having the jaws smooth or only finely striated: noting the Limacidæ, Vitrinidæ , etc.

oxygon.explanation: In geometry , atriangle having three acute angles.
A triangle having three acute angles.
A triangle with three acute angles.

oxyhaemoglobin.explanation: The form of haemoglobin , loosely combined with oxygen , present in arterial and capillary blood .
the bright red hemoglobin that is a combination of hemoglobin and oxygen from the lungs

oxyhalide.explanation: Any anion (and corresponding salt ) in which a central atom is bonded to both oxygen and a halogen

oxyhemocyanin.explanation: The oxy compound of hemocyanin: analogous to oxyhemoglobin. See hemocyanin .

oxyhemoglobin.explanation: A bright-red chemical complex of hemoglobin and oxygen that transports oxygen to the tissues.
Hemoglobin united with oxygen in loose combination, 1 gram of hemoglobin taking up 1.76 cubic centimeters of oxygen.
the bright red hemoglobin that is a combination of hemoglobin and oxygen from the lungs

oxyhexaster.explanation: In sponges, a hexaster whose rays are pointed.

oxyhydrate.explanation: Same as hydroxid : sometimes applied to an oxyhydroxid or compound of the same metal with both oxygen and hydroxyl, as the mineral limonite, Fe 4 O 3 (HO) 6 .

oxyhydrogen.explanation: Of or using a mixture of hydrogen and oxygen.
Of, pertaining to, or consisting of, a mixture of oxygen and hydrogen at over 5000° F.
a form of microscope arranged so as to use the light produced by burning lime or limestone under a current of oxyhydrogen gas.
of, or using a mixture of hydrogen and oxygen
A potentially explosive mixture of hydrogen and oxygen

oxyiodide.explanation: A substance which contains oxygen and iodine united to the same element or radical: as, mercuric oxyiodide , Hg 4 O 3 I 2 .

oxyketone.explanation: A ketone in which part of the hydrogen is replaced by hydroxyl, as acetol, CH 3 .CO.CH 2 (OH). More correctly called hydroxykelone .

oxyl.explanation: A compound or radical bound to an oxygen by a single bond

oxyluciferin.explanation: The luminescent product of the oxidation of luciferin by luciferase

oxymel.explanation: A mixture of vinegar or acetic acid and honey.
A mixture of honey, water, vinegar, and spice, boiled to a sirup.
A mixture of honey , water , and vinegar , boiled to a syrup , sometimes mixed with herbs or spices .

oxymethylene.explanation: A polymerization-product (CH 2 O)n of formic aldehyde, made by heating paraformaldehyde.
Formic aldehyde, regarded as a methylene derivative.
Formic aldehyde , regarded as a methylene derivative .

oxymoron.explanation: A rhetorical figure in which incongruous or contradictory terms are combined, as in a deafening silence and a mournful optimist.

In rhetoric , a figure consisting in adding to a word an epithet or qualification apparently contradictory; in general, close connection of two words seemingly opposed to each other (as, cruel kindness ; to make haste slowly ); an expression made epigrammatic or pointed by seeming self-contradictory.
A figure in which an epithet of a contrary signification is added to a word; e. g., cruel kindness ; laborious idleness .
A figure of speech in which two words with opposing meanings are used together intentionally for effect.

oxymoronic.explanation: Of or pertaining to an oxymoron , in which contradictory terms are combined.

oxymuriate.explanation: Same as chlorid : formerly so called on the erroneous assumption that muriatic acid was an oxygen acid, and that chlorin differed from it in containing more oxygen.
A salt of the supposed oxymuriatic acid; a chloride.

oxymuriatic.explanation: Pertaining to, or consisting of, oxygen and muriatic acid, that is, hydrochloric acid.
chlorine, formerly so called on the supposition that it was a compound of oxygen and muriatic acid.
Pertaining to, or consisting of, oxygen and hydrochloric acid .

oxynitrate.explanation: A substance which contains oxygen and the radical of nitric acid united to the same metal or electropositive radical: as, mercuric oxynitrate , Hg 3 O 2 (NO 3 ) 2 .

oxyntic.explanation: Acid; producing acid; -- applied especially to certain glands and cells in the stomach.

oxyopia.explanation: Abnormal acuteness of sight, arising from increased sensibility of the retina.

oxyosphresia.explanation: Morbid acuteness of the sense of smell. Also oxyosphrasia .

oxyphenol.explanation: A phenol, C6H4(OH)2, produced by the distillation of catechin; called also oxyphenic acid , and now pyrocatechin .
A phenol produced by the distillation of catechin ; oxyphenic acid or pyrocatechin .

oxypropionic.explanation: 3 .CH(OH).CO 2 H, and β-oxypro-pionic acid, CH 2 (OH).CH 2 .CO 2 H.

oxypurine.explanation: A substance derived from purine by replacing hydrogen by hydroxyl, as 6-oxypurine or hypoxanthine (C 5 H 4 ON 4 ), 2,6-dioxypurine or xanthine (C 5 H 4 O 2 N 4 ), and 2,6,8-trioxy-purine or caffeine (C 5 H 4 O 3 N 4 ).

oxypycnos.explanation: In ancient Greek and medieval music , a tetrachord in which the short step or semitone lay at the upper end; also, a mode composed of such tetrachords.

oxyquinaseptol.explanation: A trade-name for quinoline orthophonol-sul-phonate,, a powerful but little used antiseptic. It forms, amber-colored transparent hexagonal crystals and melts at 185° F. Also called diaphtherin .

oxyquinoline.explanation: A substance derived from quinoline by replacing hydrogen by hydroxyl, as α-oxyquinoline or carbostyril, C 9 H 6 N(OH).
Hydroxy quinoline; a phenol derivative of quinoline, -- called also carbostyril .
Hydroxy quinoline; a phenol derivative of quinoline .

oxyrhynch.explanation: Oxyrhyncha ; having a sharp or pointed rostrum, as a spider-crab.
A crab with a sharp or pointed rostrum, as a spider-crab or maioid; any member of the Oxyrhyncha.
The oxyrhynchus, a fish; the mizdeh.

oxysalt.explanation: A salt of an oxyacid. See oxyacid . Also spelled oxisalt .
A salt of an oxyacid, as a sulphate.

oxysulfide.explanation: A sulfide compound in which part of the sulfur has been replaced by oxygen.

oxysulphate.explanation: A substance which contains oxygen and the radical of sulphuric acid united to the same metal or electropositive radical, as ferric oxysulphate (Monsell's salt), Fe 2 O-(SO 4 ) 2

oxysulphid.explanation: A sulphid in which one atom of sulphur is replaced by oxygen: as, antimony oxysulphid , Sb 2 OS 2 .

oxysulphide.explanation: A ternary compound of oxygen and sulphur.

oxytetracycline.explanation: A broad-spectrum antibiotic, C 22 H 24 N 2 O 9 , derived from the actinomycete Streptomyces rimosus and used to treat a variety of bacterial infections.
A tetracycline antibiotic that works by interfering with bacteria 's ability to produce essential proteins .
a yellow crystalline antibiotic (trademark Terramycin) obtained from a soil actinomycete; used to treat various bacterial and rickettsial infections

oxytocic.explanation: Hastening or facilitating childbirth, especially by stimulating contractions of the uterus. Used of a drug.
A medicine or drug that tends to accelerate parturition.
Serving to promote uterine contractions , thus accelerating childbirth.
a drug that induces labor by stimulating contractions of the muscles of the uterus

oxytocin.explanation: A short polypeptide hormone, C 43 H 66 N 12 O 12 S 2 , released from the posterior lobe of the pituitary gland, that stimulates the contraction of smooth muscle of the uterus during labor and facilitates ejection of milk from the breast during nursing.
A hormone that stimulates contractions during labour / labor , and then the production of milk .
hormone secreted by the posterior pituitary gland (trade name Pitocin); stimulates contractions of the uterus and ejection of milk

oxytoluene.explanation: One of three hydroxy derivatives of toluene, called the cresols . See cresol .
Any of three hydroxy derivatives of toluene .

oxytone.explanation: Relating to or being a Greek word that has an acute accent on its last syllable.
Relating to or being a word that has a heavy stress accent on its last syllable.
A word having the stress or the acute accent on the last syllable.
grammar , especially Greek grammar : Having or characterized by the acute accent on the last syllable.
A word which has the acute accent on the last syllable.
grammar , to pronounce or write with the acute accent on the final syllable: as, to oxytone a word.
Having an acute sound; (Gr. Gram.), having an acute accent on the last syllable.
A word having the acute accent on the last syllable.
Pertaining to a word with the stress or an acute accent on the last syllable .
A word with the stress or an acute accent on the last syllable .
word having stress or an acute accent on the last syllable

oxytonesis.explanation: Pronunciation or notation of a word with the acute accent on the final syllable.

oxytonic.explanation: Having a stress on the last syllable

oxytricha.explanation: The typical genus of Oxytrichidæ. Several species of these animalcules are found both in fresh and in salt water.
[ lowercase ] Any member of this genus.

oxytropis.explanation: A genus of leguminous plants of the tribe Galegeæ and the subtribe Astragaleæ , distinguished from Astragalus by the sharp appendage on the keel-petals.
large widely-distributed genus of evergreen shrubs or subshrubs having odd-pinnate leaves and racemose or spicate flowers each having a pea-like corolla with a clawed petal

oxytylote.explanation: A sponge-spicule of the simple rhabdous type, tylotate or knobbed at one end and sharp at the other, like a common pin.

oxyuricide.explanation: Any anthelmintic which is destructive to worms of the genus Oxyuris , or pinworms.

oxyurid.explanation: Any of the order Oxyurida of nematode worms .

oy.explanation: Used especially to express irritation, dismay, sorrow, or self-pity.
An exclamation typically expressing mild frustration or expressing feelings of uncertainty or concern .

oyapock.explanation: A Brazilian opossum: same as yapok .

oyer.explanation: In law , a hearing or trial of causes.

The production of a document or copy of a document which an adversary has mentioned in his pleading; anciently, the hearing of the reading of such document. In early times often called oyer and determiner .
A hearing or an inspection, as of a deed, bond, etc., .

a term used in England in commissions directed to judges of assize about to hold court, directing them to hear and determine cases brought before them. In the U.S. the phrase is used to designate certain criminal courts.
A hearing in a civil case which is based on the content of a document, in which the plaintiff is required to produce the document.

oyes.explanation: Hear! the introduction to a proclamation made by an officer of a law-court, or other public crier, in order to secure silence and attention: it is thrice repeated: occasionally used as a substantive, in the sense of ‘exclamation’ or ‘proclamation.’

oyez.explanation: Said loudly three times in succession to call a court to order when the session begins.
Hear; attend; -- a term used by criers of courts to secure silence before making a proclamation. It is repeated three times.
Hear ye . Attend. (Called by public criers or in court usually three times to secure silence).

oyster.explanation: Any of several edible bivalve mollusks of the family Ostreidae, having a rough, irregularly shaped shell attached to the substrate in shallow marine waters. Oysters are widely cultivated for food.
Any of various similar or related bivalve mollusks, such as the pearl oyster.
An edible bit of muscle found in the hollow of the pelvic bone of a fowl.
A special delicacy.
Something from which benefits may be extracted.
A close-mouthed person.
To gather, dredge for, or raise oysters.
An edible bivalve mollusk of the family Ostreidæ , such as Ostrea edulis , the common species of Europe, and O. virginica , that of the Atlantic coast of the United States.
One of many other bivalves of the same order, but of a different family. Thus, the pearl-oyster belongs to the Aviculidæ.
The oyster-shaped bit of dark meat in the front hollow of the side-bone of a turkey or similar bird.
Figuratively, some profit or advantage which one may seize and hold.
Among packers, steamed oysters packed in hermetically sealed cans: a trade-name.

Any marine bivalve mollusk of the genus Ostrea. They are usually found adhering to rocks or other fixed objects in shallow water along the seacoasts, or in brackish water in the mouth of rivers. The common European oyster ( Ostrea edulis ), and the American oyster ( Ostrea Virginiana ), are the most important species.
A name popularly given to the delicate morsel contained in a small cavity of the bone on each side of the lower part of the back of a fowl.

any species of the genus Etheria, and allied genera, found in rivers of Africa and South America. They are irregular in form, and attach themselves to rocks like oysters, but they have a pearly interior, and are allied to the fresh-water mussels.
a breeding place for oysters; a place in a tidal river or other water on or near the seashore, where oysters are deposited to grow and fatten for market. See 1st Scalp , n.
See oystercatcher in the vocabulary.
a small crab ( Pinnotheres ostreum ) which lives as a commensal in the gill cavity of the oyster.
a rake or small dragnet for bringing up oysters from the bottom of the sea.
The toadfish.
A plant found on the seacoast of Northern Europe, America and Asia ( Mertensia maritima ), the fresh leaves of which have a strong flavor of oysters.
Same as oystercatcher .
the shell of an oyster.
a women who deals in oysters.
See under Pearl .
any spiny marine shell of the genus Spondylus.
Any marine bivalve mollusk of the Family Ostreidae, usually found adhering to rocks or other fixed objects in shallow water along the seacoasts, or in brackish water in the mouth of rivers.
A name popularly given to the delicate morsel of dark meat contained in a small cavity of the bone on each side of the lower part of the back of a fowl.
A pale beige color tinted with grey or pink, like that of an oyster.
A person who keeps secrets and private information to him- or herself.
Of a pale beige colour tinted with grey or pink, like that of an oyster.
To fish for oysters.
a small muscle on each side of the back of a fowl
edible body of any of numerous oysters
marine mollusks having a rough irregular shell; found on the sea bed mostly in coastal waters
gather oysters, dig oysters

oystercatcher.explanation: Any of several shorebirds of the genus Haematopus, having black or black-and-white plumage and a long, heavy orange bill and feeding on mollusks, crustaceans, and other small invertebrates.
A maritime wading bird of the family Hæmatopodidæ : so called from the habit of feeding upon small oysters and other mollusks.

Any one of several species of wading birds of the genus Hæmatopus having stout legs and bill and mostly black-and-white plumage, which frequent seashores and feed upon oysters and other shellfish. The European species ( Hæmatopus ostralegus ), the common American species ( Hæmatopus palliatus ), and the California, or black, oyster catcher ( Hæmatopus Bachmani ) are the best known.
Any of several black or pied coastal wading birds in the genus Haematopus that have a long red or orange bill and feed on shellfish .
black-and-white shorebird with stout legs and bill; feed on oysters etc.
black-and-white shorebird with stout legs and bill; feed on oysters etc.

oystered.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of oyster .

oystering.explanation: The act or business of dredging for or otherwise taking oysters.

oysterlike.explanation: Resembling an oyster or some aspect of one.

oysterling.explanation: A young oyster; an oyster not fully grown.

oysterman.explanation: One who gathers, cultivates, or sells oysters.
A man engaged in rearing, taking, or selling oysters; an oysterer.
A person who cultivates , harvests or sells oysters
A boat used to dredge for oysters

oz.explanation: Ounce ; any of various units of weight and volume.
a unit of weight equal to one sixteenth of a pound or 16 drams or 28.349 grams

ozaena.explanation: a chronic disease of the nose characterized by a foul-smelling nasal discharge and atrophy of nasal structures

ozarkite.explanation: A massive variety of thomsonite from Magnet Cove in the Ozark Mountains, Arkansas.
A type of rock ( hydrous aluminum - silicate ) that is native to the Arkansas ; also called thomsonite .
The mineral mozarkite of the Missouri, Ozark region.

ozena.explanation: A discharge of fetid matter from the nostril, particularly if associated with ulceration of the soft parts and disease of the bones of the nose.
a chronic disease of the nose characterized by a foul-smelling nasal discharge and atrophy of nasal structures

ozocerite.explanation: A yellow-brown to black or green hydrocarbon wax, found in irregular veins in sandstones and used in making electrical insulation and polishes.
A mixture of natural paraffins existing in the bituminous sandstones of coal-measures.
A waxlike mineral resin; -- sometimes called native paraffin , and mineral wax .
A dark waxy mineral , found associated with petroleum in some sandstones , used to make polishes .
a waxy mineral that is a mixture of hydrocarbons and occurs in association with petroleum; some varieties are used in making ceresin and candles

ozokerite.explanation: a waxy mineral that is a mixture of hydrocarbons and occurs in association with petroleum; some varieties are used in making ceresin and candles

ozonate.explanation: To treat or react with ozone ; to ozonize
Any of several compounds or complexes of ozone

ozonation.explanation: The process or act of treating with ozone, often as part of a purification process.
The act or process of treating with ozone.
The act of treating with ozone; also, the act of converting into, or producing, ozone; ozonization.
The act of treating with ozone .
The act of converting into, or producing , ozone .

ozonator.explanation: The trade-name of an apparatus for the production of ozone by means of an electrical brush-discharge in air.

ozone.explanation: An unstable, poisonous allotrope of oxygen, O 3 , that is formed naturally in the ozone layer from atmospheric oxygen by electric discharge or exposure to ultraviolet radiation, also produced in the lower atmosphere by the photochemical reaction of certain pollutants. It is a highly reactive oxidizing agent used to deodorize air, purify water, and treat industrial wastes.
A modification of oxygen, having increased chemical activity; a colorless gas having a peculiar odor like that of air which contains a trace of chlorin.

In the gaseous state, ozone, if seen through a column of sufficient depth or under considerable pressure, has a blue color like that of ordinary oxygen, but more marked, and when liquefied appears dark blue. The liquid boils under atmospheric pressure at—100° C. (—159° F.). It is magnetic, and more soluble in water than ordinary oxygen. Animals breathing air which contains ozone in appreciable quantity present the phenomena of slow respiration, enfeebled circulation, lowering of bodily temperature, venous condition of the blood, and ultimately death. Air charged with ozone has been applied to the treatment of distilled spirits with a view to the removal of fusel-oil, but with only partial success.

A colorless gaseous substance (O3) obtained (as by the silent discharge of electricity in oxygen) as an allotropic form of oxygen, containing three atoms in the molecule. It is a strong oxidizer, and probably exists in the air, though by the ordinary tests it is liable to be confused with certain other substances, as hydrogen dioxide, or certain oxides of nitrogen. It derives its name from its peculiar odor, which resembles that of weak chlorine.

An allotrope of oxygen (symbol O3) having three atoms in the molecule instead of the usual two; it is a blue gas , generated from oxygen by electrical discharge ; it is poisonous and highly reactive , but in the upper atmosphere it protects life on Earth from ultraviolet radiation .
Fresh air , especially that breathed at the seaside and smelling of seaweed .

a colorless gas (O3) soluble in alkalis and cold water; a strong oxidizing agent; can be produced by electric discharge in oxygen or by the action of ultraviolet radiation on oxygen in the stratosphere (where it acts as a screen for ultraviolet radiation)

ozonic.explanation: Pertaining to, resembling, or containing, ozone.

ozonide.explanation: Any of various, often chemical molecules formed by the attachment of ozone to a double bond or triple bond in an organic compound as an intermediate in ozonolysis.
A substance formerly supposed to contain as a constituent ozone or the specially active form of oxygen. The term is sometimes rather vaguely applied to a substance capable of producing ozone.
the univalent anion , O3-, derived from ozone
any dark red salt of this anion and a metal
any of a number of explosive organic compounds containing a -O-O-O- group

any of a class of heterocycles , containing two carbon atoms (in positions 3 and 5) and three oxygen atoms (in positions 1, 2 and 4) produced by the reaction of ozone with a carbon to carbon double bond ; the 1,2,4- trioxolanes
any of a class of unstable chemical compounds resulting from the addition of ozone to a double bond in an unsaturated compound

ozonification.explanation: The act of producing or converting into ozone.
The act or process of producing, or of subjecting to the action of, ozone.
The process of producing, or of subjecting to the action of, ozone .

ozonised.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of ozonise .

ozonises.explanation: Third-person singular simple present indicative form of ozonise .

ozonium.explanation: A name applied to certain forms of sterile fungous mycelia whose connection with fruiting forms is either doubtful or unknown. The root-rot of cotton and various other cultivated and wild plants in the southwestern United States has been attributed to O. auricomum. See root-rot .

ozonization.explanation: The operation of impregnating with ozone; the state of being impregnated with ozone. Also spelled ozonisation .

ozonize.explanation: To treat or impregnate with ozone.
To convert into ozone, as oxygen.
To treat or react with ozone ; to ozonate
To convert oxygen into ozone, especially by using an ozonizer

ozonized.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of ozonize .

ozonizer.explanation: An apparatus for the continuous production of ozone. Also spelled ozoniser .
An apparatus or agent for the production or application of ozone.
A device that converts oxygen into ozone , normally by means of a silent electrical discharge; an ozone generator

ozonizes.explanation: Third-person singular simple present indicative form of ozonize .

ozonolysis.explanation: A chemical reaction of ozone with another substance, usually an unsaturated organic compound, resulting in bond cleavage, used in synthesis and in analysis to locate the position of double and triple bonds in organic molecules.
Any reaction with ozone , especially to a double bond , in which cleavage of a bond occurs

ozonometer.explanation: A scale of tints with which ozonic test-papers are compared in order to determine the relative amount of ozone in the air.
An instrument for ascertaining the amount of ozone in the atmosphere, or in any gaseous mixture.
An instrument for measuring how much ozone is present in a mixture of gases .

ozonometry.explanation: The art of measuring the relative amount of ozone in the atmosphere.
The measurement or determination of the quantity of ozone.

ozonoscope.explanation: A test-paper which is oxidized and discolored by ozone.
An apparatus employed to indicate the presence, or the amount, of ozone.
An apparatus used to detect ozone .

ozonoscopic.explanation: Serving to indicate the presence or the amount of ozone.
Of or pertaining to the measurement of the amount of ozone .

ozonosphere.explanation: A layer in part of the stratosphere that has a larger than normal concentration of ozone ; the ozone layer
a layer in the stratosphere (at approximately 20 miles) that contains a concentration of ozone sufficient to block most ultraviolet radiation from the sun

ozonospheric.explanation: Of or pertaining to the ozonosphere .

ozostomia.explanation: A condition in which the breath has an offensive odor.

ozotype.explanation: In photography , a method of carbon- or pigment-printing invented by T. Manly.
